paragraphs.content: Ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ τὰ μὲν ζώων σώματα κέκραται, καὶ ὡς οὐκ ἴση πάντων ἐστὶν ἐν τῇ κράσει μοῖρα, παλαιοῖς ἀνδράσιν ἱκανῶς ἀποδέδεικται, φιλοσόφων τε καὶ ἰατρῶν τοῖς ἀρίστοις· εἴρηται δὲ καὶ πρὸς ἡμῶν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν τὰ εἰκότα δι’ ἑτέρου γράμματος, ἐν ᾧ περὶ τῶν καθ’ Ἱπποκράτην στοιχείων ἐσκοπούμεθα. νυνὶ δὲ, ὅπερ ἐστὶν ἐφεξῆς ἐκείνῳ, τῶν κράσεων ἁπάσας ἐξευρεῖν τὰς διαφορὰς, ὁπόσαι τέ εἰσι καὶ ὁποῖαι, κατ’ εἴδη τε καὶ γένη διαιρούμενος, ἐν τῷδε τῷ γράμματι δίειμι, τὴν ἀρχὴν ἀπὸ τῆς τῶν ὀνομάτων ἐξηγήσεως ποιησάμενος. ἐπειδὰν μὲν γὰρ ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ κεκρᾶσθαι λέγωσι τὰ σώματα, τῶν ἄκρως τοιούτων ἀκούειν φασὶ χρῆναι, τοῦτ’ ἔστι τῶν στοιχείων αὐτῶν, ἀέρος, καὶ πυρὸς, καὶ ὕδατος, καὶ γῆς. ἐπειδὰν δὲ ζῶον, ἢ φυτὸν, ἢ θερμὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν, ἢ ὑγρὸν, οὐκέθ’ ὡσαύτως. οὐδὲ γὰρ δύνασθαι ζῶον οὐδὲν οὔτ’ ἄκρως θερμὸν ὑπάρχειν, ὡς πῦρ, οὔτ’ ἄκροις ὑγρὸν, ὡς ὕδωρ· ὡσαύτως δὲ οὐδὲ ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἐσχάτως· ἀλλ’ ἀπὸ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ἐν τῇ κράσει γίνεσθαι τὰς προσηγορίας, ὑγρὸν μὲν καλούντων ἡμῶν, ἐν ᾧ πλείονος ὑγρότητός ἐστι μοῖρα, ξηρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ ξηρότητος· οὕτω δὲ καὶ θερμὸν μὲν, ἐν ᾧ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖ, ψυχρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ τὸ ψυχρὸν τοῦ θερμοῦ. αὕτη μὲν τῶν ὀνομάτων χρῆσις.
paragraphs.claude_translation: That the bodies of living creatures are compounded from hot and cold and dry and moist, and that the portion of each in the mixture is not equal in all cases, has been adequately demonstrated by the men of old, by the best of both philosophers and physicians. Reasonable arguments concerning these matters have also been stated by us in another work, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. But now, which is the next step after that work, I shall proceed in this present writing to discover all the differences of mixtures [temperaments]—how many they are and of what kind—dividing them by species and genera, beginning with an explanation of the terms. For whenever they say that bodies are mixed from hot and cold and dry and moist, they assert that one must understand these in their extreme form, that is, the elements themselves: air, fire, water, and earth. But whenever they speak of an animal, or a plant, as hot, or cold, or dry, or moist, it is no longer in the same way. For no animal can be extremely hot, like fire, nor extremely moist, like water; and likewise neither extremely cold nor extremely dry. Rather, the designations arise from what predominates in the mixture: we call "moist" that in which there is a greater portion of moisture, and "dry" that in which there is more dryness; and similarly "hot" that in which the hot predominates over the cold, and "cold" that in which the cold predominates over the hot. This, then, is the usage of the terms.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
That the bodies of animals are compounded from the hot and the cold and the dry and the moist, and that the share of each is not equal in the mixture, has been sufficiently demonstrated by men of old, the best among both philosophers and physicians. And I too have stated what is plausible on these matters in another treatise, in which I examined the elements according to Hippocrates. Now, however, as what follows upon that inquiry, I will in this book go through all the differences of mixtures—how many they are and of what sort—distinguishing them by species and by genus, beginning from an explanation of the terms.

For whenever people say that bodies are mixed from the hot and the cold and the dry and the moist, they claim that one should understand these in their extremity, that is, as the elements themselves—air, fire, water, and earth. But when they speak of an animal, or a plant, or of something as hot or cold or dry or moist, it is not in the same way. For no living thing can possess heat in the extreme, like fire, nor moisture in the extreme, like water; and likewise it cannot be cold or dry in the uttermost degree. Rather, the names are assigned from that which prevails in the mixture [krasis: blending/temperament]: we call “moist” that in which the portion of moisture is greater, and “dry” that in which dryness is; and so too “hot” where the hot prevails over the cold, and “cold” where the cold prevails over the hot. Such, then, is the usage of these terms.

paragraphs.content: Ὥρα δ’ ἂν εἴη λέγειν ἤδη καὶ περὶ τῶν κράσεων αὐτῶν. ἡ μὲν δὴ πλείστη δόξα τῶν ἐπιφανεστάτων ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων, ὑγρὰν εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν κρᾶσιν, ἑτέραν τῆς ὑγρᾶς καὶ ψυχρᾶς, καὶ τρίτην ἐπὶ ταύταις τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ ψυχρὰν, ἑτέραν τῆς ξηρᾶς τε ἅμα καὶ θερμῆς. ἔνιοι δ’ ἐξ αὐτῶν ὑγρὰν μέν τινα καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα κρᾶσιν ὑπάρχειν φασὶ, θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν· οὐ μὴν οὔτε τὴν ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν, οὔτε τὴν ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηράν. οὐ γὰρ ἐγχωρεῖν οὔθ’ ὑγρότητα πλεονεκτούσῃ θερμότητι συνδραμεῖν, οὔτε ξηρότητα ψυχρότητι. δαπανᾶσθαι μὲν γὰρ ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος τὴν ὑγρότητα, καὶ οὕτως θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν γίνεσθαι τὸ σῶμα, μένειν δὲ ἄπεπτόν τε καὶ ἀκατέργαστον, ἐν οἶς ἂν σώμασιν ἀῤῥωστῇ τὸ θερμὸν, ὥστ’ ἀναγκαῖον εἶναι, θερμότητος μὲν ἐπικρατούσης, ἕπεσθαι ξηρότητα, ψυχρότητος δὲ πλεονεκτούσης, ἀκολουθεῖν ὑγρότητα. οὗτοι μὲν οὖν κατὰ τάδε πεπείκασι σφᾶς αὐτοὺς, ὡς δύο εἰσὶ πᾶσαι τῶν κράσεων αἱ διαφοραί. ὅσοι δὲ τέτταρας εἶναι νομίζουσι, διχῶς τούτοις ἀντιλέγουσιν· ἔνιοι μὲν εὐθὺς τὸ πρῶτον ἀξίωμα μὴ συγχωροῦντες, ὡς ἐξικμάζεσθαι τὴν ὑγρότητα πρὸς τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν· ἔνιοι δὲ τοῦτο μὲν συγχωροῦσιν, ἀμφισβητοῦσι δὲ ἑτέρως. οἱ μὲν δὴ πρῶτοι τοῦ θερμοῦ μὲν ἔργον εἶναί φασι τὸ θερμαίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ψυχροῦ τὸ ψύχειν, τοῦ ξηροῦ δ’ αὖ τὸ ξηραίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ὑγροῦ τὸ ὑγραίνειν. καὶ διὰ τοῦτο, ὅσα μὲν σώματα θερμὰ τὴν φύσιν ἐστὶν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰ, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, ᾗ μὲν θερμὰ, θερμαίνει, ᾗ δὲ ξηρὰ, ξηραίνει.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Now it would be time to speak also about the mixtures [temperaments] themselves. The prevailing opinion of the most distinguished physicians and philosophers is that there is a moist and hot mixture, another that is moist and cold, and a third in addition to these that is dry and cold, and another that is both dry and hot. But some of them say that there exists a mixture that is both moist and cold, and another that is both hot and dry; however, neither one that is both moist and hot, nor one that is both cold and dry. For it is not possible either for moisture to accompany predominant heat, or for dryness to accompany coldness. For moisture is consumed by dominant heat, and thus the body becomes both hot and dry, while in those bodies in which heat is weak, it remains undigested and unprocessed, so that it is necessary that when heat predominates, dryness follows, and when coldness prevails, moisture follows. These people, then, have convinced themselves on these grounds that there are altogether two varieties of mixtures. But those who believe there are four oppose them in two ways: some by immediately not conceding the first premise, namely that it is necessary for moisture to be dried out by dominant heat; while others concede this point but dispute it in another way. Now the first group say that the function of heat is to heat, just as that of cold is to cool, and likewise the function of dryness is to dry, just as that of moisture is to moisten. And for this reason, those bodies that are by nature both hot and dry, like fire, insofar as they are hot, heat, and insofar as they are dry, dry.
paragraphs.openai_translation: It would now be time to speak also about their mixtures [kraseis: the temperaments or combinations of qualities]. The most prevalent opinion among the most eminent physicians and philosophers is that there is one mixture that is moist and warm, another that is moist and cold, and, in addition to these, a third that is dry and cold, distinct from that which is at once dry and warm. But some of them say that there does indeed exist a mixture that is at once moist and cold, and another that is at once warm and dry; yet neither the moist-and-warm nor the cold-and-dry. For, they claim, it is not possible for moisture to go along with predominating heat, nor dryness with cold. For when heat is dominant, the moisture is expended, and thus the body becomes at once warm and dry, yet remains unripe and unworked [apepton and akatergaston: not properly “cooked” or processed], in those bodies in which the warm factor is infirm; so that it is necessary, when heat prevails, that dryness follow, and when cold has the upper hand, that moisture accompany it. These people, then, have on these grounds persuaded themselves that all the differences of mixtures are only two. But those who think there are four oppose them in two ways: some do not grant the initial premise, namely that it is necessary for the moisture to be dried out by the prevailing heat; others grant this, but dispute the matter otherwise. The first

paragraphs.content: ὅσα δ’ ὑγρὰ καὶ θερμὰ, καθάπερ ὕδωρ θερμὸν, ὑγραίνειν ταῦτα καὶ θερμαίνειν πέφυκεν ἀεὶ, ἓν ἑκατέρας κᾀνταῦθα ποιότητος ἔργον ἐχούσης ἀχώριστον. οὐκ οὖν συγχωροῦσιν, εἴ τι θερμαῖνόν ἐστιν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ξηραίνειν· ἀλλ’ εἰ μὲν ὑγρότης προσείη τῇ θερμότητι, θερμαίνειν ἅμα καὶ ὑγραίνειν, ὥσπερ τὰ λουτρὰ τῶν γλυκέων ὑδάτων· εἰ δ’, ὥσπερ θερμὸν, οὕτω καὶ ξηρὸν εἴη, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, οὐ θερμαίνειν μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ ξηραίνειν εὐθὺς, οὐκ ἐκ τῆς θερμότητος τοῦτο λαβὸν, ἀλλ’ ἐκ τῆς συνούσης αὐτῇ ξηρότητος. ὑπομιμνήσκουσι δ’ ἐνταῦθα τῶν ἐν ἡλίῳ θερινῷ διατριψάντων ἐπιπλέον, εἶθ’, ὡς εἰκὸς, αὐανθέντων, ὅλον τε τὸ σῶμα καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ αὐχμηρὸν ἐχόντων, καὶ διψώντων οὐκ ἀνεκτῶς.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Those things which are moist and hot, such as hot water, are naturally disposed always to moisten and to heat, each quality having in this case too a single inseparable function. Therefore, they do not concede that if something is heating, it immediately also dries; rather, if moisture is present along with the heat, it heats and moistens at the same time, just as baths of fresh water do; but if, just as it is hot, it is also dry, like fire, it not only heats but also immediately dries, deriving this not from the heat but from the dryness that accompanies it. And here they remind us of those who have spent excessive time in the summer sun and then, as is natural, have become parched, having their whole body both dry and withered, and suffering from unbearable thirst.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Whatever things are moist and hot, like hot water, are by nature always fitted to moisten and to heat—each quality having here a single effect inseparable from itself. It is therefore not admissible, if something is heating, to say that it immediately also dries; rather, if moisture is joined to heat, it both heats and moistens at the same time, as in baths of fresh [i.e., “sweet”] water. But if, as it is hot, it is also dry, like fire, then it not only heats but also immediately dries—deriving this not from its heat, but from the dryness that accompanies it. They further remind us here of those who have spent time in the summer sun and then, as is likely, have been parched, their whole body being in a dry and rough condition, and thirsting intolerably.

paragraphs.content: ἴασιν γὰρ αὐτοῖς εἶναί φασιν ἑτοίμην τε καὶ ῥᾴστην, οὐκ εἰ πίοιεν μόνον, ἀλλὰ εἰ καὶ λούσαιντο θερμοῖς ὕδασι καὶ γλυκέσιν, ὡς τῆς ὑγρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ ψυχρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ θερμότητος εἴη, τὸ ἑαυτῆς δρᾷν δυναμένης, ὑγραίνειν γὰρ τὰ πλησιάζοντα. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν λόγον φασὶ καὶ τὴν ξηρότητα ξηραίνειν ἀεί. τὸν γοῦν βοῤῥᾶν, ξηρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἄνεμον τυγχάνοντα, ξηραίνειν ἅπαντα καὶ ψύχειν. καὶ τοῦτ’ εἶναι τὸ πρὸς Ὁμήρου λεγόμενον, Ὡς δ’ ὅτ’ ὀπωρινὸς βορέης νεοαρδέ’ ἀλωὴν Αἶψα ξηραίνει. Κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ τὸν τοῦ μήκωνος ὀπὸν καὶ ἄλλα μυρία φάρμακα ξηραίνειν ἅμα καὶ ψύχειν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For they say that the cure for them is both ready at hand and very easy, not only if they should drink [the waters], but also if they should bathe in warm and sweet waters, on the grounds that moisture, whether it be accompanied by coldness or by heat, is able to perform its own function, namely to moisten things that come near it. And according to the same reasoning, they say that dryness always dries. At any rate, the north wind [Boreas], being a dry and cold wind, dries and cools everything. And this is what is said by Homer: "As when the autumn north wind quickly dries the newly watered threshing floor." And in the same manner both poppy juice [opium] and countless other drugs dry and cool at the same time.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For they say that a cure for them is ready to hand and very easy, not only if they should drink, but even if they should bathe in hot and “sweet” waters [i.e., fresh, non-saline], on the grounds that moisture, whether accompanied by cold or by heat, is able to act according to its own nature—for it moistens whatever it comes near. And on the same principle they say that dryness always dries. For indeed the north wind, being as it happens a dry and cold wind, dries everything and chills; and this is what is said with reference to Homer: “As when the autumnal Boreas quickly dries the newly-watered threshing-floor.” And in the same way the juice of the poppy [opium] and countless other drugs both dry and cool at once.

paragraphs.content: ὥστ’ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον, οὔτ’ εἴ τι ψυχρὸν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχειν, οὔτ’, εἴ τι θερμὸν, εὐθὺς καὶ ξηρόν· οὔκουν οὐδὲ τὴν θερμὴν κρᾶσιν ἐξ ἀνάγκης εἶναι καὶ ξηρὰν, ἀλλὰ δύνασθαί ποτε τὸ μὲν θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖν ἐν τῇ κράσει τοῦ ζώου, τὸ δ’ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ τὴν γένεσιν, καὶ τὴν ἀλλοίωσιν, καὶ τὴν μεταβολὴν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γίνεσθαι. τίς γὰρ οὖν εἰπὼν, ὅτι τὸ λευκὸν ἠλλοιώθη τε καὶ μετέβαλεν, ἐγένετο γὰρ θερμὸν, οὐκ ἂν εἴη καταγέλαστος; ἐπιζητεῖ γὰρ ὁ λόγος, οὐ τὴν κατὰ ψυχρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀντίθεσιν, ἀλλὰ τὴν κατὰ τὸ χρῶμα μεταβολήν· μεταβάλλει γὰρ τὸ μὲν λευκὸν εἰς τὸ μέλαν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ μέλαν εἰς τὸ λευκὸν, καὶ τὸ θερμὸν αὖ εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν εἰς τὸ θερμόν. οὕτω δὲ καὶ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν εἰς τὸ ξηρὸν, τὸ δ’ αὖ ξηρὸν εἰς τὸ ὑγρόν. εἰ γὰρ δὴ φάσκει τις ἠλλοιῶσθαι τὸ σῶμα τῷ τέως ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχον εἶναι νῦν λευκὸν, ἢ τῷ τέως ξηρὸν ὂν τὸ νῦν φαίνεσθαι μέλαν, οὐκ ἂν ὑγιαίνειν δόξειεν. εἰ δέ γε τὸ τέως ὑγρὸν τὸ νῦν ξηρὸν φαίη γενέσθαι, ἢ τὸ πρότερον ὑπάρχον μέλαν νῦν εἶναι λευκὸν, ἢ ἐκ θερμοῦ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ἐκ ψυχροῦ θερμὸν γεγονέναι, σωφρονεῖν ἂν δόξειεν ὁ τοιοῦτος, καὶ λέγειν τὰ εἰκότα. τὸ γὰρ μεταβάλλον, ᾗ μεταβάλλει, ταύτῃ μεταχωρεῖν δεῖ πρὸς τοὐναντίον. ἐγένετο γοῦν ἢ γίγνεται μουσικὸς ὅδε, φαμὲν, ἐξ οὐ μουσικοῦ δηλονότι, καὶ γραμματικὸς ἐξ οὐ γραμματικοῦ, καὶ ῥητορικὸς ἐξ οὐ ῥητορικοῦ· τὸ δ’ ἐκ μουσικοῦ γραμματικὸν, ἢ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸν, ἢ ἐξ ἄλλου τινὸς τῶν ἑτερογενῶν γίνεσθαί τι λέγειν ἄτοπον. ἐγχωρεῖ γὰρ τὸν τέως γραμματικὸν νῦν μουσικὸν γεγονέναι, προσκτησάμενον τῇ γραμματικῇ τὴν μουσικὴν, οὐκ ἀποβαλόντα τὴν γραμματικήν. καὶ μὴν εἰ προσεκτήσατό τι, μένοντος τοῦ προτέρου, παντί που δῆλον, ὡς οὐκ ἠλλοιώθη κατὰ τὸ μένον. ὥστ’ οὐκ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸς ἐγένετο· καὶ γὰρ καὶ νῦν ἔτι γραμματικός ἐστιν· ἀλλ’ ἐξ ἀμούσου μουσικός· οὐ γὰρ ἔτ’ ἐγχωρεῖ μένειν αὐτὸν ἄμουσον, μουσικόν γε ἤδη γεγονότα. πασῶν γοῦν τῶν μεταβολῶν ὑπὸ τῶν ἐναντίων τε κᾀκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γιγνομένων, δηλονότι καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν, εἰ μεταβάλλει ποτὲ, καθ’ ὅσον ὑγρὸν, αὐτό τε ξηρανθήσεται καὶ τὸ ξηραῖνον αὐτὸ ξηρὸν λεχθήσεται. μὴ τοίνυν λεγόντων, φασὶν, ὡς θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ γενέσθαι. θερμὴν μὲν γὰρ ἅμα καὶ ψυχρὰν εἶναι τὴν αὐτὴν, ἢ ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ· συνυπάρχειν γὰρ ἀλλήλαις οὐχ οἷόν τε καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὰς ἐναντίας ποιότητας· ἅμα δ’ ὑγρόν τι καὶ θερμὸν, καὶ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν εἶναι δυνατὸν, ὡς ὅ τε λόγος ἀπέδειξε καὶ τὰ σμικρῷ πρόσθεν εἰρημένα παραδείγματα. τοιοῦτος μὲν οὖν ὁ τῶν προτέρων λόγος.
paragraphs.claude_translation: So it is not necessary that if something is cold, it must immediately also be moist, nor if something is hot, must it immediately also be dry. Therefore, neither is it necessary that a hot mixture must also be dry, but it is possible that sometimes the hot may predominate over the cold in the mixture of a living creature, while the moist predominates over the dry. For indeed, generation, alteration, and change occur from contraries to contraries. For who, having said that the white thing has been altered and changed—for it has become hot—would not be ridiculous? For the argument seeks not the opposition between cold and hot, but the change in color. For the white changes into the black, just as the black also changes into the white, and the hot in turn into the cold, just as the cold also into the hot. And likewise the moist into the dry, and the dry in turn into the moist. For if someone should claim that a body has been altered because what was formerly moist is now white, or because what was formerly dry now appears black, he would not seem to be in his right mind. But if he should say that what was formerly moist has now become dry, or that what was previously black is now white, or that it has become cold from hot, or hot from cold, such a person would seem to be sensible and to speak reasonably. For what changes, insofar as it changes, must in that respect move toward its opposite. At any rate, we say that this person has become or is becoming musical, obviously from being non-musical, and literate from being non-literate, and skilled in rhetoric from being non-rhetorical. But to say that something becomes literate from being musical, or musical from being literate, or that something comes to be from some other heterogeneous quality is absurd. For it is possible that one who was formerly literate has now become musical, having acquired music in addition to literacy, not having lost his literacy. And yet if he has acquired something while the former quality remains, it is surely clear to everyone that he has not been altered with respect to what remains. So he has not become musical from being literate—for indeed he is still literate even now—but he has become musical from being non-musical. For it is no longer possible for him to remain non-musical, having already become musical. Since, then, all changes occur by contraries, from contraries, and into contraries, clearly the moist too, if it ever changes, insofar as it is moist, will itself be dried and what dries it will be called dry. Therefore, they say, let them not claim that it is impossible for a mixture to be both hot and moist at the same time. For it is impossible for the same thing to be both hot and cold at the same time, or both moist and dry at the same time; for contrary qualities cannot coexist in one and the same body. But it is possible for something to be both moist and hot at the same time, and both cold and dry at the same time, as both the argument has demonstrated and the examples given a little earlier. Such, then, is the argument of the earlier thinkers.

paragraphs.content: ὁ δὲ τῶν δευτέρων οὐδὲν ἄτοπον εἶναί φησιν, ὑποκειμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ δραστικωτάτου τῶν τεττάρων, ὡς μὴ μόνον εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ἀλλὰ καὶ εἰς τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐνεργεῖν, εἶναι κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ὅταν ἐς ταὐτὸ ἅμα συνέλθῃ πλῆθος ὑγρότητός τε καὶ θερμότητος εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου. ὁ δὲ λόγος ἐκείνων οὐχ, ὡς οὐκ ἄν ποτε γένοιτο καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, τὸ δὲ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ, δείκνυσιν, ἀλλ’ ὡς οὐκ ἂν διαμείναι τοιοῦτο ἄχρι παντός· ἀεὶ γὰρ ἐξικμαζόμενον ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἀποδείξει τὸ σῶμα· καὶ οὕτως οὐκ ἂν ἔτι θερμὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν, ἀλλὰ θερμὸν εἴη καὶ ξηρόν· αὐτὸ δ’ οὖν πάλιν τοῦτο, τὸ θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, ἐπὶ προήκοντι τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἔσται καὶ ψυχρόν. ἐπειδὰν γὰρ ἐκβοσκήσηται τὴν ἰκμάδα πᾶσαν αὐτοῦ τὸ θερμὸν, ἄρχεται τοὐντεῦθεν ἤδη, φασὶ, καὶ αὐτὸ μαραίνεσθαι, μηκέτ’ εὐποροῦν τροφῆς, ὅθεν ἐξήπτετο. θαυμαστὸν οὖν οὐδὲν εἶναι νομίζουσι, καὶ κατ’ ἀρχὰς μὲν εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου συνδραμεῖν εἰς ταὐτὸ ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, ἢ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ. δυνατὸν δὲ κᾀν τῷ χρόνῳ προϊόντι γίνεσθαι τὴν τέως θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν αὖθις θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν, ὥσπερ γε καὶ αὖθις πάλιν τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ἀποσβεννυμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ, ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἀποτελεσθῆναι.
paragraphs.claude_translation: The proponent of the second view says there is nothing absurd in this, given that heat is the most active of the four [qualities], so that it acts not only upon the cold but also upon the moist, and that there can be a mixture that is moist and hot whenever an abundance of both moisture and heat come together at the same time right at the first generation of the living creature. But the argument of those others does not demonstrate that there could never be in one and the same body the moist in excess of the dry and the hot in excess of the cold, but rather that such a condition could not persist forever. For the moisture, being constantly evaporated by the heat, will in time render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but would be hot and dry. Then again, this very condition itself—the hot and dry—as time advances will become dry and cold. For when the heat has consumed all its moisture, from that point on, they say, it too begins to wither away, no longer having an abundant supply of the nourishment from which it was kindled. Therefore they consider it not at all remarkable that both at the beginning, right at the first generation of the living creature, either the moist runs together in excess of the dry, or the hot in excess of the cold, into the same place. And it is also possible that as time progresses, the mixture that was previously hot and moist becomes in turn hot and dry, just as again in turn the dry and hot mixture, when the heat is extinguished, becomes cold and dry.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But the advocate of the second view says there is nothing absurd in this, since heat, being the most active of the four, is assumed to act not only upon the cold but also upon the moist, so that there is a hot-and-moist mixture [krasis], whenever a great amount of both moisture and heat come together to the same point straightway at the animal’s first coming-to-be. Their argument does not show that it could never occur in one and the same body that the moist exceeds the dry and the hot exceeds the cold, but rather that such a condition would not endure forever. For as the moisture is continually being dried out by the heat, in time it will render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but hot and dry. And this very state, hot and dry, in due course will become dry and cold. For whenever the heat has consumed all its sap [ikmada, “natural moisture”], from that point, they say, it too begins to wither, no longer having an ample supply of nourishment from which it had been kindled. They therefore think there is nothing surprising if, at the beginning, immediately at the first generation of the animal, either the moist exceeds the dry or the hot [exceeds] the cold come together in the same subject. And it is possible also, as time advances, for the mixture that was previously hot and moist to become again hot and dry, just as again the dry and hot, when the heat is quenched, is brought to completion as cold and dry.
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
The proponent of the second view, however, says that there is nothing strange in this, on the assumption that the hot is the most active of the four qualities, such that it acts not only upon the cold but also upon the moist. Thus, a moist and hot temperament [κρᾶσις] can exist, whenever a great amount of both moisture and heat comes together at the same time, right at the first genesis of a living being. The argument of the other party, however, does not show that it could never happen in one and the same body that the moist exceeds the dry and the hot exceeds the cold, but rather that such a state would not last forever. For the moist, being constantly dried out by the hot, will in time render the body dry; and so it would no longer be hot and moist, but would be hot and dry. Then this state itself—the hot and dry—will in turn, over a long period of time, become dry and cold. For once the hot has consumed all of the body's moisture [ἰκμάς], from that point on, they say, the heat itself also begins to wither away, no longer having a ready supply of the nourishment from which it was kindled.

They believe, therefore, that it is not at all surprising if, at the very beginning, right at the first genesis of a living being, a greater amount of the moist than the dry, or of the hot than the cold, should come together in the same body. And it is possible, as time proceeds, for the temperament that was for a time hot and moist to become, in turn, hot and dry, just as it is also possible for the hot and dry temperament, in its turn, to be rendered cold and dry as its heat is extinguished.

paragraphs.content: ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν εἶναί τινα, καὶ ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν τῆσδε κρᾶσιν, ἐκ τούτων ἀποδεικνύουσιν. ὅτι δὲ πλείους τῶν τεττάρων διαφορὰς κράσεων ἀδύνατον ὑπάρχειν, ἐκ τῶνδε πειρῶνται διδάσκειν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

That it is possible for a certain mixture [krasis] to be both hot and moist at the same time, and for another mixture different from this one to be cold and dry, they demonstrate from these arguments. But that it is impossible for there to exist more than four varieties of mixtures, they attempt to teach from the following considerations.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, that it is possible for something to be at once hot and moist, and that another mixture [krâsis: mixture/temperament] is cold and dry, they demonstrate from the following considerations. And that it is impossible for there to be differences of mixtures [krâseis] exceeding four, they attempt to show from what follows.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: So then, from these points they demonstrate that it is possible for one mixture [krasis] to be at once hot and moist, and another cold and dry. But from the following points they attempt to teach that it is impossible for more than the four varieties of mixtures to exist.

paragraphs.content: ὑποκειμένων γὰρ, φασὶ, τεττάρων ποιοτήτων, εἰς ἀλλήλας τε τὸ δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ἐχουσῶν, θερμότητός τε καὶ ψυχρότητος, καὶ ξηρότητος καὶ ὑγρότητος, ἀντιθέσεις γίνεσθαι δύο, τὴν μὲν ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ θερμὸν ἀντίκειται τῷ ψυχρῷ, τὴν δ’ ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ ξηρὸν τῷ ὑγρῷ, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο τέτταρας ἀποτελεῖσθαι τὰς πάσας συζυγίας. ἓξ μὲν γὰρ γίνεσθαι τῶν τεττάρων ἀλλήλαις ἐπιπλεκομένων τὰς συζεύξεις, ἀλλὰ τὰς δύο τούτων ἀδυνάτους ὑπάρχειν. οὔτε γὰρ ὑγρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν, οὔτε ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ θερμὸν δύναται γενέσθαι σῶμα. λείπεται γοῦν τέτταρας εἶναι συζυγίας κράσεων, ὑγρὰς μὲν δύο, ξηρὰς δὲ δύο, θερμότητι καὶ ψυχρότητι διῃρημένας. ἃ μὲν οὖν οἱ χαριέστατοι τῶν πρὸ ἡμῶν ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων εἰρήκασι, ταῦτά ἐστιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For they say that there being four underlying qualities, which have the power both to act upon and be acted upon by one another—namely heat and coldness, and dryness and moisture—two oppositions arise: one in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other in which the dry is opposed to the moist, and for this reason four combinations in all are produced. For when the four are interwoven with one another, six couplings result, but two of these turn out to be impossible. For a body can become neither moist and dry at the same time, nor cold and hot at the same time. Therefore, it remains that there are four combinations of mixtures [or blendings]: two moist and two dry, distinguished by heat and coldness. These, then, are the things that the most elegant of the physicians and philosophers before us have said.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For, they say, since there are four underlying qualities, which have the power to act upon and be affected by one another—heat and cold, and dryness and wetness—two oppositions arise: in the one, the hot is opposed to the cold; in the other, the dry to the moist; and for this reason all the pairings [syzygies: couplings/combinations] amount to four. For when the four interweave with one another, six couplings come to be, but two of these are impossible. For a body cannot at the same time be both moist and dry, nor both cold and hot. Accordingly, it follows that there are four pairings of mixtures [kraiseis: blends/temperaments], two moist and two dry, distinguished by heat and by cold. Such, then, are the things said by the most refined of the physicians and philosophers before us.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: For they say that, given four underlying qualities which are able to act and be acted upon by one another—namely, heat and cold, and dryness and wetness—two oppositions arise: the one, in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other, in which the dry is opposed to the wet. And for this reason, four total combinations [συζυγίαι] are produced. For six pairings arise from the interweaving of the four, but two of these are impossible. For a body cannot be at the same time wet and dry, nor at the same time cold and hot. Therefore, four combinations of mixtures [κράσεις] are left: two wet and two dry, distinguished by heat and cold. So, this is what the most elegant of the physicians and philosophers before us have said.

paragraphs.content: ἃ δ’ ἐγὼ παραλιπεῖν αὐτοὺς νομίζω, λέγειν ἤδη καιρός.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But as for the things which I believe they have omitted, it is now time to speak.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But as for the things I think they have omitted, it is now time to speak.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: Ἕν μὲν δὴ καὶ πρῶτον, ὅτι τὴν εὔκρατον φύσιν, ὥσπερ οὐκ ἀρετῇ τε ἅμα καὶ δυνάμει προὔχουσαν, ἐπελάθοντό τε καὶ τελέως παρέλιπον, ὥσπερ μηδ’ ὅλως οὖσαν, καίτοι μηδὲ φθέγξασθαί τι χωρὶς ἐκείνης ὑπὲρ τῶν ἄλλων δυνάμενοι. τὸ γοῦν ἐν τῇ θερμῇ κράσει πλεονεκτεῖν τὸ θερμὸν, ἢ ἐν τῇ ψυχρᾷ τὸ ψυχρὸν, οὐδ’ ἐπινοῆσαι δυνατὸν ἄνευ τοῦ πρότερον ἐπιθέσθαι τὴν εὔκρατον. οὐδὲ γὰρ οὐδὲ τὴν ὑγιεινὴν δίαιταν εἰς ἄλλο τι βλέποντες ἐξευρίσκουσιν, ἢ τὴν εὔκρατον ἐκείνην φύσιν· τὸ μὲν θερμότερον τοῦ δέοντος σῶμα κελεύοντες ἐμψύχειν, τὸ δ’ αὖ ψυχρότερον θερμαίνειν· ὡσαύτως τὸ μὲν ὑγρότερον ξηραίνειν, τὸ δὲ ξηρότερον ὑγραίνειν, ἀντεισάγοντες ἀεὶ δηλονότι τῷ πλεονάζοντι τὸ λεῖπον, ὡς εὔκρατόν τινα καὶ μέσην ἐργάσασθαι κατάστασιν. ἣν οὖν ἀεὶ μεταδιώκουσιν, καὶ πρὸς ἣν ἀποβλέποντες ἐπανορθοῦνται τὰς δυσκράτους, ἐγὼ μὲν ἠξίουν ἁπασῶν πρῶτον λέγεσθαι πρὸς αὐτῶν. οἳ δ’ ἄρα τοσοῦτον ἀποδέουσι τοῦ μεμνῆσθαι ταύτης, ὥσθ’ ὅλως παραλείπουσιν αὐτήν. ἀλλ’ οὐ παραλέλειπται, φασὶν ἐξ αὐτῶν ἔνιοι, ἐν γὰρ τῇ θερμῇ καὶ ὑγρᾷ περιέχεται. καὶ πῶς οὐχὶ πέντε λέγετε τὰς πάσας εἶναι κράσεις, ἀλλὰ τέτταρας, εἴπερ τῆς ἀρίστης μέμνησθε; δυοῖν γὰρ θάτερον, ἢ τῶν δυσκράτων ἀνάγκη παραλελεῖφθαι μίαν, ἢ τὴν εὔκρατον. ἐγὼ μὲν δὴ σαφῶς οἶδα τὴν εὔκρατον αὐτοὺς παραλιπόντας, ἐξ ὧν ἀξιοῦσιν. ἐπειδὰν γὰρ θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν, καὶ ψυχρὰν καὶ ὑγρὰν, ἤ τινα ἄλλην λέγωσι κρᾶσιν, οὐ τῶν ἄκρων ἀκούειν ἡμᾶς χρῆναι ποιοτήτων, ἀλλὰ κατὰ τὴν πλεονεκτοῦσαν ἀεὶ γίνεσθαι προσηγορίαν. εἰ δ’ οὐ βούλονται τὴν εὔκρατον παραλελεῖφθαι, τῶν ἄλλων τινὰ δειχθήσονται παραλιπόντες. ἔστω γὰρ εὔκρατον εἶναι τὴν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ὥσπερ αὐτοὶ βούλονται. παραλελοίπασιν ἄρα σαφῶς τὴν ἀντικειμένην τῇ ψυχρᾷ καὶ ξηρᾷ δυσκρασίᾳ, ἐν ᾗ τὸ ὑγρὸν πλεονεκτεῖ καὶ τὸ θερμόν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: One thing first and foremost: that they have forgotten and completely omitted the well-tempered nature [eucrasia], as if it did not exist at all—despite the fact that it excels simultaneously in both virtue and power—even though they cannot say anything about the other conditions without reference to it. For indeed, the notion that heat predominates in the hot temperament, or cold in the cold temperament, cannot even be conceived without first having grasped the well-tempered condition. For they discover the healthful regimen with reference to nothing other than that well-tempered nature: they prescribe cooling for a body that is hotter than it should be, and conversely heating for one that is colder; likewise drying for one that is more moist, and moistening for one that is drier—clearly always introducing what is deficient to counteract what is in excess, so as to produce a certain well-tempered and middle state. Therefore, I thought it proper that this condition, which they are always pursuing and with reference to which they correct the ill-tempered states, should be mentioned first by them. But they are so far from remembering it that they omit it entirely. "But it has not been omitted," some of them say, "for it is included in the hot and moist temperament." Then how is it that you do not say there are five temperaments in all, but rather four, if indeed you remember the best one? For one of two things must be the case: either one of the ill-tempered conditions has necessarily been omitted, or the well-tempered one has. Now I clearly know that they have omitted the well-tempered condition, based on what they maintain. For when they speak of a hot and dry, or cold and moist, or some other temperament, they claim that we should not understand these as referring to the extreme qualities, but that the designation is always made according to the predominating quality. But if they do not wish to admit that the well-tempered condition has been omitted, they will be shown to have omitted one of the others. For let it be granted that the moist and hot temperament is well-tempered, as they themselves wish. Then they have clearly omitted the condition opposite to the cold and dry ill-temperament, in which both the moist and the hot predominate.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
To begin with, first and foremost, they have forgotten and entirely left out the well-tempered nature [eucrasia: balanced mixture], as though it did not even exist at all—despite the fact that they cannot so much as say anything about the others apart from it, and although it surpasses the rest both in excellence and in power. For the notion that, in a hot mixture [krásis], the hot element predominates, or in a cold one the cold element, cannot even be conceived unless one has first posited the well-tempered [state]. Indeed, when they devise a healthful regimen [diaita] they look to nothing else than that well-tempered nature: they bid the body that is hotter than is fitting to be cooled, and that which is colder to be warmed; likewise, the wetter to be dried and the drier to be moistened—always, plainly, introducing against the excess what is lacking, in order to produce a certain well-tempered and intermediate condition.

Accordingly, that condition which they always pursue, and to which they look when they set right disequilibria [dyscrasiai], I thought ought to be mentioned first of all by them. Yet they fall so far short of remembering it that they leave it out entirely. “But it has not been omitted,” some of them say; “for it is included under the hot-and-moist.” And how is it that you say there are in all not five mixtures, but four, if you do in fact remember the best one? For of the two alternatives, either one of the disequilibria must have been omitted, or the well-tempered state. I, for my part, know clearly from what they maintain that it is the well-tempered state they have omitted. For whenever they speak of a hot-and-dry, or a cold-and-moist, or any other mixture, we should not understand them to be referring to the extreme qualities as such; rather, the designation is always derived according to what predominates. If, however, they are unwilling to let the well-tempered state be omitted, they will be shown to have omitted one of the others. Let the hot-and-moist, then, be well-tempered, as they wish. Plainly, then, they have omitted the mixture opposed to the cold-and-dry disequilibrium, in which the moist and the hot predominate.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ αὐτὴ, φασὶν, ἐστὶν ἥδε. καὶ πῶς ἐνδέχεται καὶ πλεονεκτεῖν ἅμα τὸ θερμὸν καὶ μὴ πλεονεκτεῖν, καὶ κρατεῖσθαι καὶ μὴ κρατεῖσθαι τὸ ψυχρόν; εἰ μὲν γὰρ εὔκρατός ἐστιν, οὐδὲν οὐδενὸς ἀμέτρως ἐπικρατεῖ, εἰ δὲ δύσκρατος, ἀνάγκη πλεονεκτεῖν τι τῶν ἐκ τῆς ἀντιθέσεως. ἀλλ’ αὐτὸ τοῦτο, φασὶν, ἴδιόν ἐστι τῆς εὐκράτου, τὸ κρατεῖν ἐν αὐτῇ τὸ μὲν θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ, τὸ δ’ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ· κρατήσαντος γὰρ τοῦ ψυχροῦ, μετρίως μὲν, οὐκ ἀγαθὴν εἶναι τὴν κρᾶσιν, ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον, νόσον ἤδη γίνεσθαι, καθάπερ, εἰ καὶ σφοδρῶς κρατήσειε, θάνατον· οὕτω δὲ κᾀπὶ τοῦ ξηροῦ συμπίπτειν ἐν ἀρχῇ μὲν δυσκρασίαν, ἐπὶ πλέον δὲ νόσον, ἐπὶ πλεῖστον δὲ κρατήσαντος, θάνατον· ὥσπερ οὐχὶ κᾀπὶ τῆς ὑγρᾶς καὶ θερμῆς ταῦτα συμπίπτοντα. τίς γὰρ ἂν οὐχ ὁμολογήσειεν, ὡς, ἐπειδὰν μὲν ἐπ’ ὀλίγον ἢ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ τύχοι πλεονεκτῆσαν, ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ, δυσκρασίαν οὕτως γιγνομένην· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἐπὶ πλέον, νόσον· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἐπὶ πλεῖστον, θάνατον.
paragraphs.claude_translation: "But this very thing," they say, "is the case." And how is it possible for the hot both to prevail at the same time and not to prevail, and for the cold both to be overcome and not to be overcome? For if it is well-tempered [eukratos], nothing prevails immoderately over anything else, but if it is ill-tempered [dyskratos], one of the opposites must necessarily prevail. "But this very thing," they say, "is characteristic of the well-tempered [mixture], that in it the hot prevails over the cold, and the moist over the dry; for if the cold prevails, even moderately, the mixture is not good, and if still more, disease already occurs, just as, if it should prevail violently, death results; and likewise in the case of the dry it happens that at first there is ill-temperament [dyskrasia], with greater [prevalence] disease, and with the greatest prevalence, death"—as if these same things do not also occur in the case of the moist and the hot! For who would not agree that, whenever the hot happens to prevail slightly over the cold, or the moist over the dry, ill-temperament thus occurs; and whenever to a greater degree, disease; and whenever to the greatest degree, death?
paragraphs.openai_translation: “But the point itself, they say, is this. And how is it possible that the hot should both have the advantage and not have it at the same time, and that the cold should both be mastered and not be mastered? For if the mixture is well-balanced [eukratos: in a state of eukrasia, i.e., a balanced mixture], nothing prevails over anything else to an excessive degree; but if it is ill-balanced [dyskrasia], then necessarily one of the opposing qualities has the upper hand. ‘But this very thing,’ they say, ‘is the special property of the well-balanced state: that in it the hot prevails over the cold and the moist over the dry.’ For if the cold prevails, then—if only moderately—the mixture [krasis] is not good; if to a greater extent, it already becomes a disease; and if it should prevail violently, it is death. And so too in the case of the dry: at the outset there results an ill-balance [dyskrasia], with more, disease, and if it should prevail to the utmost, death—surely not as if these same outcomes did not also occur in the case of the moist and the hot. For who would not agree that whenever the hot happens to have a slight advantage over the cold, or the moist over the dry, an ill-balance [dyskrasia] thus arises; when to a greater extent, disease; and when to the greatest extent, death?”
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
But this, they say, is what it [the well-tempered state] is. And how is it possible for the hot to both predominate and not predominate at the same time, and for the cold to be both overcome and not be overcome? For if a state is well-tempered [eukratos], nothing prevails over anything else immoderately; but if it is ill-tempered [dyskratos], it is necessary for one of the opposites to predominate.

But this very thing, they say, is characteristic of the well-tempered state: for the hot to prevail in it over the cold, and the

paragraphs.content: ὁ γὰρ αὐτὸς ἐπ’ ἀμφοῖν λόγος. ἢ μηδὲ τὰς ἀμέτρως ὑγρὰς καὶ θερμὰς καταστάσεις αἰτιώμεθα, μηδ’ ὅσα μεθ’ ὑγρότητος ἀμέτρου νοσήματα συνίσταται θερμὰ, μηδὲ ταῦτ’ ὁμολογῶμεν εἶναι νοσήματα. πρὸς δὴ τοὺς τοιούτους λόγους ἀπομαχόμενοί τινες τῶν ἀπ’ Ἀθηναίου τοῦ Ἀτταλέως ὁμόσε χωροῦσιν, οὔτε κατάστασιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν μέμφεσθαι λέγοντες, οὔθ’ εὑρεθῆναί τι νόσημα φάσκοντες ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν, ἀλλὰ πάντως ἢ θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν ὑπάρχειν, ὡς τὸν πυρετὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν, ὡς τὸν ὕδερον, ἢ ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, ὡς τὴν μελαγχολίαν. ἐπιμέμνηνται δ’ ἐνταῦθα καὶ τῶν ὡρῶν τοῦ ἔτους, ὑγρὸν μὲν καὶ ψυχρὸν εἶναι τὸν χειμῶνα φάσκοντες, ξηρὸν δὲ καὶ θερμὸν τὸ θέρος, καὶ ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν τὸ φθινόπωρον, εὔκρατον δ’ ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν ὥραν καλοῦσι τὸ ἔαρ· οὕτω δὲ καὶ τῶν ἡλικιῶν τὴν παιδικὴν εὔκρατόν τε καὶ θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν εἶναί φασι. δηλοῦσθαι δὲ τὴν εὐκρασίαν αὐτῆς νομίζουσι κᾀκ τῶν ἐνεργειῶν τῆς φύσεως, ἐῤῥωμένων τηνικαῦτα μάλιστα. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τὸν θάνατόν φασιν εἰς ξηρότητα καὶ ψύξιν ἄγειν τὰ τῶν ζώων σώματα. καλεῖσθαι γοῦν ἀλίβαντας τοὺς νεκροὺς, ὡς ἂν μηκέτι λιβάδα καὶ ὑγρότητα κεκτημένους οὐδεμίαν, ἐξατμισθέντας ἅμα διὰ τὴν ἀποχώρησιν τοῦ θερμοῦ, καὶ παγέντας ὑπὸ τῆς ψύξεως. ἀλλ’ εἴπερ ὁ θάνατος, φασὶ, τοιοῦτος, ἀναγκαῖον ἤδη τὴν ζωὴν, ὡς ἂν ἐναντίαν ὑπάρχουσαν αὐτῷ, θερμήν τε εἶναι καὶ ὑγράν· καὶ μὴν εἴπερ ἡ ζωὴ, φασὶ, θερμόν τι χρῆμα καὶ ὑγρόν ἐστιν, ἀνάγκη πᾶσα, καὶ τὴν ὁμοιοτάτην αὐτῇ κρᾶσιν ἀρίστην ὑπάρχειν, εἰ δὲ τοῦτο παντί που δῆλον, ὡς εὐκρατοτάτην, ὥστ’ εἰς ταὐτὸ συμβαίνειν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν φύσιν εὐκράτῳ, καὶ μηδὲν ἄλλο εἶναι τὴν εὐκρασίαν, ἢ τῆς ὑγρότητός τε καὶ θερμότητος ἐπικρατούσης. οἱ μὲν δὴ τῶν ἀμφὶ τὸν Ἀθήναιον λόγοι τοιοίδε. δοκεῖ δέ πως ἡ αὐτὴ δόξα καὶ Ἀριστοτέλους εἶναι τοῦ φιλοσόφου, καὶ Θεοφράστου γε μετ’ αὐτὸν, καὶ τῶν Στωϊκῶν, ὥστε καὶ τῷ πλήθει τῶν μαρτύρων ἡμᾶς δυσωποῦσιν. ἐγὼ δὲ περὶ μὲν Ἀριστοτέλους, ὅπως ἐγίνωσκεν ὑπὲρ θερμῆς καὶ ὑγρᾶς κράσεως, ἴσως ἂν, εἰ δεηθείη, ἐπὶ προήκοντι τῷ λόγῳ δείξαιμι· δοκοῦσι γάρ μοι παρακούειν αὐτοῦ.
paragraphs.claude_translation: For the same argument applies to both cases. Or else let us not blame excessively moist and hot conditions, nor acknowledge as diseases those hot ailments that are constituted with excessive moisture, nor agree that these are diseases at all. Now in fighting back against such arguments, some of the followers of Athenaeus of Attaleia engage directly, saying that they do not criticize a moist and hot condition, nor do they claim that any disease has been found that is moist and hot, but that every disease is necessarily either hot and dry, like fever, or cold and moist, like dropsy [edema], or cold and dry, like melancholy. And here they also call to mind the seasons of the year, asserting that winter is moist and cold, summer is dry and hot, and autumn is cold and dry, while they call spring a well-tempered season that is both hot and moist; and likewise among the ages of life, they say that childhood is well-tempered and hot and moist. They believe that its good temperament is demonstrated also by the activities of nature, which are especially vigorous at that time. And indeed they say that death leads the bodies of living creatures to dryness and coldness. At any rate, they say, corpses are called "alibantes" [without moisture], as no longer possessing any moisture or wetness, having been evaporated simultaneously through the departure of heat and frozen by the coldness. But if death is of such a nature, they say, it is now necessary that life, as being opposite to it, be both hot and moist; and moreover if life, they say, is something hot and moist, it is entirely necessary that the mixture most similar to it be the best, and if this is clear to everyone, that it be the most well-tempered, so that it turns out that a moist and hot nature is the same as a well-tempered one, and that good temperament is nothing other than the predominance of moisture and heat. Such then are the arguments of the followers of Athenaeus. And this same opinion seems somehow to belong also to the philosopher Aristotle, and to Theophrastus after him, and to the Stoics, so that they try to shame us by the multitude of witnesses. But as for Aristotle, how he understood the matter concerning hot and moist mixture, I could perhaps, if it should be necessary, demonstrate as the argument proceeds; for they seem to me to misunderstand him.

paragraphs.content: Τὸ δέ γε νῦν εἶναι, πειράσομαι πρῶτον ἐνδείξασθαι τοῖς λέγουσι ταῦτα, πῆ ποτε σοφίζονται σφᾶς αὐτοὺς, εἶτ’ ἐφεξῆς ἐπιδεῖξαι τὸν ἅπαντα λόγον, εἰς ἓν ἀθροίσας κεφάλαιον. ὅτι μὲν δὴ τὸ ἔαρ οἴονται θερμὸν εἶναι καὶ ὑγρὸν ἅμα καὶ εὔκρατον, ἐντεῦθεν σοφίζονται προφανῶς. οὔτε γὰρ ὑγρὸν ὡς χειμὼν, οὔτε θερμὸν ὡς τὸ θέρος, ὥστ’ οὐδέτερον ἀμέτρως.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But as things stand now, I shall attempt first to demonstrate to those who say these things in what way they are deceiving themselves, and then in turn to set forth the entire argument, having gathered it into a single summary. Now then, that they believe spring to be both hot and moist at the same time and well-tempered [εὔκρατον - having a good mixture or balance], in this respect they are clearly deceiving themselves. For it is neither moist like winter, nor hot like summer, so that neither quality is present immoderately.
paragraphs.openai_translation: As to the matter now before us, I shall first try to show those who say these things how they are contriving their argument, and then, in due course, to set out the whole account, gathered into a single summary. That they suppose spring to be at once warm and moist and well-tempered [eukraton: of a balanced mixture] is plainly the way they reason. For it is neither moist like winter nor hot like summer, so that neither quality is excessive.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: As for the present matter, I will first attempt to show those who say these things how they are deceiving themselves, and then, in turn, to set forth the entire argument, gathered into a single summary. That they think spring is hot and wet and at the same time well-tempered [of a good mixture]—it is from this point, clearly, that they deceive themselves. For it is neither wet like winter, nor hot like summer, so that neither of these qualities is present in excess.

paragraphs.content: ἀμετρίας δ’ ἦν ἕκαστον τῶν τοιούτων ὀνομάτων, καὶ κατ’ αὐτοὺς ἐκείνους, δηλωτικόν. διχῶς δ’ ἐσφάλησαν, πρῶτον μὲν ἐκ τοῦ βούλεσθαι πάντως ἐν ταῖς ὥραις εὑρεῖν τὴν τετάρτην συζυγίαν τῶν κράσεων, ἔπειτα δ’ ἐκ τοῦ καὶ θερμότερον ἢ κατὰ τὸν χειμῶνα, καὶ ὑγρότερον ἢ κατὰ τὸ θέρος ὑπάρχειν αὐτό. ἀλλ’ οὔτ’ ἀναγκαῖον ἐν ταῖς ὥραις ὑποτίθεσθαι τὴν τετάρτην συζυγίαν τῶν κράσεων, εἰ μὴ καὶ φαίνοιτο, καὶ τὸ παραβάλλειν αὐτὸ ταῖς ἑκατέρωθεν ὥραις οὐδὲν μᾶλλον ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν ἀποδείξει καὶ ξηρόν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ἀμετρίας ἐστὶν ὀνόματα τὸ ὑγρὸν καὶ τὸ θερμὸν, οὐκ ἀληθεύεται κατ’ αὐτούς· σύμμετρον γὰρ ἐν ἅπασι τὸ ἔαρ. εἰ δ’, ὅτι θέρους μέν ἐστιν ὑγρότερον, χειμῶνος δὲ θερμότερον, ὑγρόν ἐστι καὶ θερμὸν, οὐδὲν ἦττον αὐτὸ ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν νομίζεσθαι προσήκει, διότι θέρους μέν ἐστι ψυχρότερον, χειμῶνος δὲ ξηρότερον. ἢ τίς ἀποκλήρωσις, ἓν μὲν τῶν ἐκ τῆς ἀντιθέσεως ἀπὸ τοῦ χειμῶνος, ἓν δὲ ἀπὸ τοῦ θέρους λαμβάνειν; ἐν ἑκατέραις γὰρ ἀμφοτέρων διαφέρον, οὐκ ἐξ ἡμίσεως ὀφείλει τὴν παραβολὴν, ἀλλ’ ὁλόκληρον ἴσχειν. καὶ μὴν εἴπερ οὕτως γίνοιτο, τἀναντία φήσομεν ὑπάρχειν αὐτῷ. θερμὸν μὲν γὰρ ἔσται καὶ ξηρὸν, εἰ τῷ χειμῶνι, ψυχρὸν δ’ αὖ καὶ ὑγρὸν, εἰ τῷ θέρει παραβάλλοιτο. κατ’ οὐδετέραν οὖν τῶν παραβολῶν ὁλοκλήρως γινομένην ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἔσται. εἰ δ’ ἔξεστιν ἐκείνοις ἐξ ἑκατέρας αὐτῶν ἥμισυ λαβοῦσιν ὑγρὸν ἀποφαίνειν αὐτὸ καὶ θερμὸν, ἐξέσται δήπου καὶ ἡμῖν ἐπὶ θάτερον ἥμισυ μετελθοῦσιν ξηρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἀποφῇναι, ξηρὸν μὲν ὡς πρὸς, τὸν χειμῶνα, ψυχρὸν δὲ ὡς πρὸς τὸ θέρος.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Each of such terms was, even according to those very people, indicative of immoderation. But they erred in two ways: first, from wishing to find by all means the fourth pairing of mixtures among the seasons, and second, from the fact that it [spring] is both warmer than winter and moister than summer. But it is neither necessary to posit the fourth pairing of mixtures among the seasons, unless it also appears to be so, nor will comparing it to the seasons on either side prove it to be moist and hot any more than cold and dry. For if "moist" and "hot" are names of immoderation, the statement is not true according to them; for spring is moderate in all respects. But if, because it is moister than summer and warmer than winter, it is moist and hot, it should no less properly be considered cold and dry, because it is colder than summer and drier than winter. Or what is the justification for taking one quality from the opposition with winter, and one from summer? For since it differs from both in both respects, it ought not to have the comparison by halves, but to have it complete. And yet if it were done in this way, we shall say that opposite qualities belong to it. For it will be hot and dry if compared to winter, but again cold and moist if compared to summer. Therefore, according to neither comparison made completely will it be moist and hot. But if it is permitted to them, having taken half from each of these comparisons, to declare it moist and hot, it will surely also be permitted to us, having proceeded to the other half, to declare it dry and cold—dry in relation to winter, and cold in relation to summer.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Each of these names of that sort was, even by their own account, indicative of excess [ametria: disproportion], and they went wrong in two ways: first, by wanting at all costs to find in the seasons the fourth pairing [syzygia: combination] of the temperaments [kraseis: mixtures of qualities], and then by asserting that it is both warmer than winter and wetter than summer. But it is neither necessary to posit in the seasons the fourth pairing of the mixtures, unless it should also be evident, nor will comparing it with the seasons on either side prove it to be any more wet and warm, rather than cold and dry. For if “wet” and “warm” are names of excess, they are not speaking truly on their own terms; for spring is proportionate [summetros: balanced/temperate] in all respects. But if, because it is wetter than summer and warmer than winter, it is wet and warm, then no less should it also be thought cold and dry, since it is colder than summer and drier than winter. Or what sort of allotment is it, to take one item from the opposition with respect to winter and one from that with respect to summer? For in each comparison it differs in both respects; the comparison ought not to be made by halves, but as a whole. And indeed, if one proceeds that way, we will say that the contrary properties belong to it: it will be warm and dry, if compared to winter, but again cold and wet, if compared to summer. Therefore, on neither complete comparison will it turn out to be wet and warm. And if they are allowed, taking half from each comparison, to declare it wet and warm, then surely we too, taking the other half, will be allowed to declare it dry and cold—dry in relation to winter, and cold in relation to summer.

paragraphs.content: ἅπαντα οὖν οὕτως ἔσται τὸ ἔαρ, ὑγρὸν, ξηρὸν, θερμὸν, ψυχρόν. ἀλλ’ οὐδὲ κατ’ αὐτοὺς ἐκείνους οἶόν τέ ἐστιν ἐν ἑνὶ καὶ ταὐτῷ πράγματι τὰς τέτταρας ἐπικρατῆσαι ποιότητας· οὔκουν οὔτε θέρει παραβαλεῖν· οὔτε χειμῶνι τὸ ἔαρ, ἀλλ’ αὐτὸ καθ’ αὑτὸ σκοπεῖσθαι δίκαιον. οὐδὲ γὰρ οὐδὲ τὸν χειμῶνα διὰ τοῦτο λέγομεν ὑγρὸν εἶναι καὶ ψυχρὸν, ὅτι τῶν ἄλλων ὡρῶν ἐστιν ὑγρότατος καὶ ψυχρότατος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Therefore, in this way spring will be all things: moist, dry, hot, cold. But not even according to those very people is it possible for the four qualities to predominate in one and the same thing. Consequently, it is not right to compare spring either with summer or with winter, but rather to examine it by itself on its own terms. For indeed, we do not say that winter is moist and cold because it is the moistest and coldest of the other seasons.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Thus, on this reasoning, spring will be everything at once—moist, dry, hot, and cold. Yet even on their own terms it is not possible for the four qualities [i.e., the primary qualities: hot, cold, dry, moist] to prevail in one and the same subject. Therefore one ought not to compare spring either with summer or with winter, but to consider it on its own. For we do not even call winter moist and cold on the ground that, of the other seasons, it is the moistest and coldest.
