paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ τοῦτο μὲν καὶ ἄλλως αὐτῷ συμβέβηκεν· ὅτι δὲ πλεονεκτεῖ κατ’ αὐτὸν ἡ μὲν ὑγρότης τῆς ξηρότητος, ἡ δὲ ψυχρότης τῆς θερμότητος, διὰ τοῦτο ψυχρὸς εἶναι καὶ ὑγρὸς λέγεται. κατὰ ταὐτὸ δὲ καὶ τὸ θέρος, ὅτι κᾀν τούτῳ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν ἀπολείπεται τοῠ ξηροῦ, τὸ δὲ ψυχρὸν τοῦ θερμοῦ, διὰ τοῦτο θερμὸν εἶναι λέγεται καὶ ξηρόν. καὶ γὰρ δίκαιον, ἐκ τῆς οἰκείας φύσεως ἑκάστην τῶν ὡρῶν ἐξεταζομένην, οὐ πρὸς ἄλλην τινὰ παραβαλλομένην, ἢ θερμὴν, ἢ ψυχρὰν, ἢ ξηρὰν, ἢ ὑγρὰν ὀνομάζεσθαι. καὶ δὴ καὶ σκοπουμένῳ σοι κατὰ τάδε φανεῖται τὸ ἔαρ ἀκριβῶς μέσων ἁπασῶν τῶν ὑπερβολῶν. οὔτε γὰρ ὡς ἐν χειμῶνι πλεονεκτεῖ τὸ ψυχρὸν ἐν αὐτῷ τοῦ θερμοῦ, οὔθ’ ὡς ἐν θέρει πλεονεκτεῖται. κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ ξηρότητός τε καὶ ὑγρότητος ἰσομοιρία τίς ἐστιν ἐν αὐτῷ, μήθ’ ὡς ἐν θέρει κρατοῦντος τοῦ ξηροῦ, μήθ’ ὡς ἐν χειμῶνι τοῦ ὑγροῦ. διὰ τοῦτο ὀρθῶς εἴρηται πρὸς Ἱπποκράτους, ἦρ δὲ ὑγιεινότατον καὶ ἥκιστα θανατῶδες. ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸ φθινόπωρον ἧττον μὲν ἢ τὸ θέρος θερμὸν, ἧττον δὲ ἢ ὁ χειμὼν ψυχρόν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But this has happened to it [winter] in another way as well. However, because in it [winter] moisture prevails over dryness, and coldness over heat, for this reason it is said to be cold and moist. By the same principle also summer, because in this too the moist is deficient compared to the dry, and the cold compared to the hot, for this reason it is said to be hot and dry. For indeed it is right that each of the seasons, being examined according to its own nature and not being compared to some other season, should be named either hot, or cold, or dry, or moist. And indeed if you consider it in this way, spring will appear to be precisely in the middle of all the extremes. For neither does the cold prevail over the hot in it as in winter, nor is it prevailed over as in summer. In the same way also there is a certain equality of dryness and moisture in it, with neither the dry dominating as in summer, nor the moist as in winter. For this reason it has been correctly stated by Hippocrates: "Spring is the most healthful and least deadly." But autumn too is less hot than summer, and less cold than winter.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But this has also come about for it in another way: since, in its case, moisture has the advantage over dryness and cold over heat, it is therefore called cold and moist [sc. with respect to the four primary qualities]. Likewise with summer: because in it too the moist falls short of the dry and the cold of the hot, it is for this reason said to be hot and dry. For it is right that each of the seasons, examined from its own nature and not by comparison with some other, be called hot, or cold, or dry, or moist. And indeed, if you consider on these lines, spring will appear to you precisely the mean of all the extremes. For in it the cold does not prevail over the hot as in winter, nor is it at a disadvantage as in summer. Likewise, there is in it a certain equal share of dryness and moisture, neither with the dry dominating as in summer nor the moist as in winter. For this reason it has been rightly said by Hippocrates: “Spring is the most healthful and the least deadly.” But autumn too is less hot than summer and less cold than winter.
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
But this, in any case, is what happens with it [winter]; and because during this season wetness prevails over dryness and coldness over heat, it is for this reason said to be cold and wet. And in the same way with summer: because in it the wet is deficient compared to the dry, and the cold compared to the hot, for this reason it is said to be hot and dry. For it is right that each of the seasons be named hot, cold, dry, or wet by being examined according to its own nature, and not by being compared to any other.

And so, if you examine it in this way, spring will appear to you to be precisely in the middle of all the extremes. For in it [spring], the cold neither prevails over

paragraphs.content: ὥστε ταύτῃ μὲν οὔτε θερμὸν ἁπλῶς, οὔτε ψυχρὸν, ἀμφότερα γάρ ἐστι, καὶ οὐδέτερον ἄκρως. ἕτερον δέ τι πρόσεστιν αὐτῷ κακὸν, ὅπερ ἐπεσημήνατο καὶ Ἱπποκράτης ἐν ἀφορισμοῖς λέγων· ὁκόταν τῆς αὐτῆς ἡμέρης, ὁτὲ μὲν θάλπος, ὁτὲ δὲ ψύχος γίγνηται, φθινοπωρινὰ τὰ νοσήματα προσδέχεσθαι χρή. καὶ τοῦτό ἐστι τὸ μάλιστα νοσῶδες ἐργαζόμενον τὸ φθινόπωρον, ἡ ἀνωμαλία τῆς κράσεως. οὐκ ὀρθῶς οὖν εἴρηται ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, οὐ γάρ ἐστι ψυχρὸν αὐτὸ καθ’ αὑτὸ θεωρούμενον, ὥσπερ ὁ χειμὼν, ἀλλὰ τῷ θέρει παραβαλλόμενον, ἐκείνου ψυχρότερον. οὐ μὴν οὐδ’ ὁμαλῶς εὔκρατον, ὡς τὸ ἔαρ, ἀλλ’ ὅτι μάλιστα τούτῳ διενήνοχεν ἐκείνης τῆς ὥρας, ὅτι τὴν εὐκρασίαν τε καὶ τὴν ὁμαλότητα διὰ παντὸς ἴσην οὐ κέκτηται. πολὺ γὰρ θερμότερόν ἐστι κατὰ τὴν μεσημβρίαν, ἢ κατὰ τὴν ἕω τε καὶ τὴν ἑσπέραν. ὑγρότητι δὲ καὶ ξηρότητι μέσον μὲν οὐκ ἔστιν ἀκριβῶς, ὡς τὸ ἔαρ, ἀλλ’ ἐπὶ τὸ ξηρότερον ῥέπει. λείπεται δὲ κᾀν τούτῳ τοῦ θέρους, οὐ μὴν τοσοῦτόν γε, ὅσον θερμότητι. δῆλον οὖν, ὡς οὐδὲ τὸ φθινόπωρον ἁπλῶς οὕτως ῥητέον, ὡς ἐκεῖνοι λέγουσι, ψυχρόν τε εἶναι καὶ ξηρόν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: So in this respect it is neither simply hot nor cold, for it is both, and neither extremely. But there is another evil present in it, which Hippocrates also noted in the Aphorisms, saying: "Whenever on the same day there is at one time heat and at another time cold, one must expect autumnal diseases." And this is what especially makes autumn disease-producing: the irregularity of its mixture [temperament]. Therefore it has not been correctly stated that it is cold and dry, for it is not cold when considered in itself, as winter is, but only when compared to summer is it colder than that season. However, neither is it uniformly well-tempered, like spring, but it differs most from that season in this respect: that it does not possess an equal good temperament and uniformity throughout. For it is much hotter at midday than at dawn and evening. In moisture and dryness it is not exactly intermediate, like spring, but inclines toward the drier. Yet in this respect too it falls short of summer, though not by as much as it does in heat. It is clear, therefore, that autumn should not be described simply in the way those people describe it, as being cold and dry.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, in this respect it is neither simply hot nor simply cold; it is both, and neither to an extreme. But there is another disadvantage attached to it, which Hippocrates also marked in the Aphorisms when he said: whenever on the same day now heat, now cold occurs, one must expect autumnal diseases. And this is what does the most to make autumn diseased—the irregularity of the mixture [krasis: the balance of elemental qualities]. It is therefore not rightly called cold and dry; for it is not cold considered in itself, like winter, but only in comparison with summer is it the colder. Nor, moreover, is it evenly temperate, like spring; rather, it especially differs from that season in this, that it does not possess temperateness and uniformity [eukrasia and homalotēs] equally throughout. For it is much hotter at midday than in the morning and evening. As regards moisture and dryness, it is not exactly in the middle, as spring is, but inclines toward the drier. In this respect too it falls short of summer, though not so much as in heat. It is clear, then, that autumn too should not simply be described, as those people say, as being cold and dry.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἄκρως μὲν γὰρ οὐδέτερόν ἐστιν, ἐπικρατεῖ δ’ ἐν αὐτῷ τὸ ξηρὸν τοῦ ὑγροῦ. καὶ δικαίως ἂν λεχθείη ταύτῃ μὲν ξηρὸν, ἐν δὲ τῇ κατὰ θερμότητα καὶ ψυχρότητα διαφορᾷ μικτὸν ἐξ ἀμφοῖν καὶ ἀνώμαλον. ὥστ’ εἴπερ τὰς τέσσαρας συζυγίας τῶν κράσεων εἰς τὰς τέσσαρας ὥρας διανεῖμαι σπεύδουσιν, ἴστωσαν οὐ μόνον ἦρι κακῶς προσάψαντες ὑγρότητα καὶ θερμότητα κράσεως, ἀλλὰ καὶ φθινοπώρῳ ψυχρότητα καὶ ξηρότητα. καίτοι γε, εἰ καὶ τοῦτο συνεχωρεῖτο ξηρὸν εἶναι καὶ ψυχρὸν, οὐκ ἦν ἀναγκαῖον εὐθέως, ὑγρὸν εἶναι καὶ θερμὸν τὸ ἔαρ. οὐ γὰρ, εἰ τέτταρες αἱ πᾶσαι συζυγίαι τῶν ἀμέτρων κράσεων εἰσὶν, ἤδη πάσας ἀναγκαῖον εἰς τὰς τέσσαρας ὥρας νενεμῆσθαι.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For it is neither [hot nor cold] in the extreme, but in it the dry prevails over the moist. And it would justly be called dry in this respect, but in the difference relating to heat and cold, mixed from both and uneven. So if they are eager to distribute the four combinations of temperaments to the four seasons, let them know that they have not only wrongly assigned moistness and heat to the temperament of spring, but also coldness and dryness to autumn. And yet, even if it were granted that this [autumn] is dry and cold, it would not be necessary straightaway that spring be moist and hot. For it is not the case that, if there are four combinations in all of imbalanced temperaments, it is already necessary that all of them be distributed among the four seasons.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For it is not, strictly speaking, neutral, but in it dryness prevails over moisture. And one might rightly say that in this respect it is dry, whereas in the differentiation according to heat and cold it is a mixture from both and irregular. Therefore, if people are eager to distribute the four pairings [syzygies] of mixtures [kraiseis: temperaments] among the four seasons, let them recognize that they have wrongly attached moistness and heat as a temperament to spring, and likewise coldness and dryness to autumn. And yet, even if it were conceded that this season is dry and cold, it would not straightway be necessary that spring be moist and hot. For it does not follow that, because all four pairings of the immoderate mixtures [ametroi kra(se)is] exist, all of them must already have been apportioned among the four seasons.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ εἴπερ ἄρα τάξις τίς ἐστιν ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ, καὶ κατὰ τὸ βέλτιον, οὐ κατὰ τὸ χεῖρον ἅπαντα κεκόσμηται, πιθανώτερον ἦν, εὐκράτους μὲν τὰς πλείους ὥρας γεγενῆσθαι, μίαν δὲ ἐξ αὐτῶν, εἴπερ ἄρα, τὴν δύσκρατον. οἱ δέ γε τοὐναντίον ἀποδεῖξαι σπεύδουσιν, ὡς οὐδεμία τῶν ὡρῶν ἐστιν εὔκρατος, ἀλλ’ ἐξ ἀνάγκης ἐν αὐταῖς ἐπικρατεῖ νῦν μὲν τὸ θερμὸν, αὖθις δὲ τὸ ψυχρὸν, καὶ νῦν μὲν, εἰ τύχῃ, τὸ ξηρὸν, αὖθις δὲ τὸ ὑγρόν. ἐγὼ δὲ τοσοῦτον ἀποδέω τοῦ ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀποφαίνειν τὸ ἔαρ, ἢ, ὅ τί περ ἂν εὔκρατον ᾖ, θερμὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν εἶναι συγχωρεῖν, ὥστε πᾶν τοὐναντίον ἀποφαίνομαι, χειρίστην εἶναι κατάστασιν κράσεως τοῦ περιέχοντος ἀέρος τὴν θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν, ἣν ἐν μὲν ταῖς ὥραις οὐκ ἂν εὕροις ὅλως, ἐν δὲ ταῖς νοσώδεσί τε καὶ λοιμώδεσι καταστάσεσιν ἐνίοτε συμπίπτει, καθάπερ που καὶ ὁ Ἱπποκράτης ἐμνημόνευσε, λέγων· ὗεν ἐν καύμασιν ὕδατι λάβρῳ δι’ ὅλου. τοῦτο γάρ ἐστιν ἴδιον ὑγρᾶς καὶ θερμῆς καταστάσεως, ὕειν συνεχῶς ἐν καύμασιν. εἰ δ’ ἤτοι μόνον εἴη καῦμα, καθάπερ ἐπὶ τοῦ κατὰ φύσιν ἔχοντος θέρους, ἢ ὕει μὲν, ἀλλ’ ἐν κρύει, καθάπερ ἐν χειμῶνι, θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν οὐχ οἶόν τε τὴν τοιαύτην εἶναι κατάστασιν. ἆρ’ οὖν ἄνοσον ἐκεῖνο τὸ θέρος, ἐν ᾧ, φησὶν, ὗεν ἐν καύμασιν ὕδατι λάβρῳ δι’ ὅλου; καὶ μὴν ἄνθρακας ἐν αὐτῷ γενέσθαι διηγεῖται, σαπέντων δηλονότι τῶν ἐν τῷ σώματι περιττωμάτων, καί τινας ἰχῶρας θερμοὺς καὶ ὑγροὺς ἀμέτρως γεννησάντων. εἴσῃ δὲ ἐξ αὐτῆς τῆς ῥήσεως, εἰ πᾶσαν αὐτήν σοι παραγράψαιμι, τόνδε τὸν τρόπον ἔχουσαν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But if indeed there is some order in the cosmos, and all things have been arranged according to what is better, not according to what is worse, it would have been more plausible that most of the seasons had come to be well-tempered, and that one of them, if any at all, was ill-tempered. But they, on the contrary, hasten to demonstrate that none of the seasons is well-tempered, but that of necessity now the hot predominates in them, and then again the cold, and now, as it may happen, the dry, and then again the moist. But I am so far from declaring spring to be moist and hot, or from agreeing that whatever is well-tempered is hot and moist, that I declare quite the opposite: that the hot and moist condition is the worst state of mixture of the surrounding air, which you would not find at all in the seasons, but which sometimes occurs in diseased and pestilential conditions, just as Hippocrates also mentioned somewhere, saying: "It rained with violent water during heat waves throughout." For this is characteristic of a moist and hot condition, to rain continuously during heat waves. But if there were only heat, as in the case of summer when it is in its natural state, or if it rains but in cold, as in winter, it is not possible for such a condition to be hot and moist. Was that summer, then, in which, he says, "it rained with violent water during heat waves throughout," free from disease? And yet he relates that carbuncles occurred in it, clearly because the residues in the body putrefied and generated certain humors [ichors] that were excessively hot and moist. You will know this from the passage itself, if I should quote it all for you, which runs as follows.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
But if indeed there is some order in the world, and all things have been arranged according to the better and not the worse, it would be more plausible that most of the seasons have come to be well-tempered [eukratos], and that one of them, if any, is ill-tempered [dyskra tos/dyskrasia].

Yet they, on the contrary, are eager to prove that none of the seasons is well-tempered, but that of necessity now the hot predominates in them, then the cold, and now, if it so happens, the dry, then the moist.

For my part, I am so far from declaring spring to be moist and hot, or from conceding that whatever is well-tempered is hot and moist, that I assert quite the opposite: the worst condition of the mixture [krasis] of the surrounding air is the hot-and-moist one,

which you would not find at all among the seasons, but which sometimes occurs in diseased and pestilential states,

as Hippocrates somewhere also mentioned, saying: “It rained, in the midst of heat, with a violent downpour throughout.”

For this is characteristic of a moist and hot condition: to rain continually in a heat.

But if there were only heat, as in summer when it is in its natural state, or if it rained, but in cold, as in winter, such a condition could not be hot and moist.

Was that summer, then, in which, he says, it rained in heat with a violent downpour throughout, free from disease?

Indeed, he relates that carbuncles [anthrakes] arose during it—clearly because the bodily superfluities were putrefying and generated certain hot and moist ichors in excessive quantity.

And you will learn this from the very passage itself, if I were to transcribe it for you in full, which runs as follows.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: But if indeed there is some order in the cosmos, and all things have been arranged for the better and not for the worse, it would have been more plausible for most of the seasons to be well-tempered [eukratous], and only one of them, if any, to be ill-tempered [duskraton]. They, however, hasten to demonstrate the opposite: that no one of the seasons is well-tempered, but that of necessity in them at one time the hot prevails, and at another the cold, and at one time, as it may be, the dry, and at another the moist. For my part, I am so far from declaring spring to be moist and hot, or from conceding that whatever is well-tempered is hot and moist, that I declare the very opposite: that the worst constitution of the temperament [krasis] of the surrounding air is the hot and moist one. This is a constitution you would not find at all among the seasons, but which sometimes occurs in morbid and pestilential conditions, just as Hippocrates also mentioned somewhere, when he said: "It rained amid heatwaves with violent water continuously." For this is the characteristic property of a moist and hot constitution: to rain continuously amid heatwaves. But if there were only a heatwave, as is the case in a natural summer, or if it rained, but in the cold, as in winter, it is not possible for such a constitution to be hot and moist. Was that summer, then, free from disease, in which, he says, "it rained amid heatwaves with violent water continuously"? And yet he relates that carbuncles arose during it, clearly because the superfluities [perittomata] in the body putrefied and generated certain hot and moist ichors to an immoderate degree. But you will know this from the passage itself, which runs as follows, if I write it all out for you.

paragraphs.content: ἄνθρακες ἐν Κρανῶνι θερινοί. ὗεν ἐν καύμασιν ὕδατι λάβρῳ δι’ ὅλου. ἐγίνοντο δὲ μᾶλλον Νότῳ· καὶ ὑπεγίνοντο μὲν ὑπὸ τὸ δέρμα ἰχῶρες· ἐγκαταλαμβανόμενοι δὲ ἐθερμαίνοντο, καὶ κνησμὸν ἐνεποίεον· εἶτα φλύκταιναι ὥσπερ πυρίκαυστοι ἐπανίσταντο, καὶ ὑπὸ τὸ δέρμα καίεσθαι ἐδόκεον.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Carbuncles [anthrakes: malignant boils] in Crannon were a summer affliction. During the scorching heats it rained in torrential downpours throughout. They occurred especially with a south wind; and ichors [thin, acrid serous fluids] formed beneath the skin. When these were confined, they grew hot and produced itching; then blisters arose as if from fire-burns, and there seemed to be a burning beneath the skin.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Carbuncles in Cranon in summer. It rained with heavy water during the heat throughout. They occurred more frequently with a south wind; and watery discharges formed beneath the skin; when trapped they became heated and produced itching; then blisters like burns rose up, and they seemed to be burning beneath the skin.

---

**Brief notes:**
- [ἄνθρακες (anthrakes): carbuncles - inflammatory skin lesions, literally "coals"]
- [Κρανῶνι (Kranōni): Cranon - a city in Thessaly]
- [Νότῳ (Notōi): south wind - associated with heat and humidity in Greek medical thought]
- [ἰχῶρες (ichōres): watery discharges or serum]
- [φλύκταιναι (phlyktainai): blisters or pustules]
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐνταῦθα μὲν, ὡς ἂν μιᾶς ὥρας μετακοσμηθείσης, ἧττον τὸ κακόν· εἰ δὲ δύο ἢ τρεῖς ὑπαλλαχθεῖεν, ἢ καὶ σύμπαν τὸ ἔτος ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν γένοιτο, μέγιστον ἀνάγκη συμπεσεῖν οὕτω λοιμὸν, οἶον ἐν τῷ τρίτῳ τῶν ἐπιδημιῶν διηγεῖται. παραγράψω δὲ πρῶτον μὲν ἅ περὶ τῆς τῶν ὡρῶν ἀκοσμίας εἶπεν, ἐφεξῆς δὲ καὶ τὰ περὶ τῆς ἐπιγινομένης φθορᾶς τῶν ἀνθρώπων. ἐν ἅπασι δ’ αὐτοῖς προσέχειν σε τὸν νοῦν ἀκριβῶς ἀξιῶ καὶ σκοπεῖσθαι, πρῶτον μὲν, ὁποῖόν τι πρᾶγμα θερμὴ καὶ ὑγρὰ κρᾶσίς ἐστιν, ὡς οὐδὲν ἦρι παρόμοιον, εὐκράτῳ χρήματι· δεύτερον δὲ, ὡς ἀναγκαῖον ἐν αὐτῇ σήπεσθαι πάντα. ἄρχεται μὲν οὖν ὁ Ἱπποκράτης τῆς διηγήσεως ὧδε. ἔτος νότιον, ἔπομβρον, ἄπνοια διὰ τέλεος. εἶτα τούτοις ἐπιφέρει τὰ κατὰ μέρος ἁπάσης τῆς καταστάσεως, ὄμβρους πολλοὺς ἐν θερμῇ καὶ νοτίᾳ καταστάσει γενέσθαι γράφων, εἶτ’ αὖθις τὸν σύμπαντα λόγον εἰς ἕν ἐπὶ τέλει κεφάλαιον ἀγαγὼν οὕτως. γενομένου δὲ τοῦ ἔτεος ὅλου, φησὶ, νοτίου, καὶ ὑγροῦ, καὶ μαλακοῦ, τάδε καὶ τάδε συνέπεσεν, ἃ ξύμπαντα μὲν ἀναγράφειν ἐν τῷδε τῷ λόγῳ μακρόν· ἔνεστι δὲ τῷ βουλομένῳ, λαβόντι τὸ τρίτον τῶν ἐπιδημιῶν, ἀναγινώσκειν τὰ κατὰ μέρος, εἰς ἕν ἅπαντα κεφάλαιον ἀναγόμενα, σηπεδόνα μεγίστην, ἧς καὶ αὐτῆς ὀνομαστὶ πολλάκις ὁ Ἱπποκράτης ἐπιμέμνηται, ποτὲ μὲν ὡδί πως λέγων· ἦν δὲ καὶ τὸ ῥεῦμα τὸ συνιστάμενον οὐ πύῳ ἴκελον, ἀλλὰ σηπεδών τις ἄλλη, καὶ ῥεῦμα πολὺ καὶ ποικίλον· ὁτὲ δὲ πάλιν ὡδί· καὶ ἐν αἰδοίοισιν ἄνθρακες οἱ κατὰ θέρος, καὶ ἄλλα, ἃ σῆψις καλέεται, καὶ ὡς ἐκ τῆς σήψεως ταύτης πολλοῖσι μὲν βραχίων καὶ πῆχυς ὅλως ἀπεῤῥύη, πολλοῖσι δὲ μηρὸς ἢ τὰ περὶ τὴν κνήμην ἀπεψιλοῦτο, καὶ ποῦς ὅλος.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But in this case, since only one season has been disordered, the harm is less; however, if two or three should be altered, or even if the entire year should become wet and hot, it is inevitable that a very great plague should occur in this way, such as he describes in the third book of the Epidemics. I shall first quote what he said about the disorder of the seasons, and next also the matters concerning the resulting destruction of people. In all these things I consider it worthwhile for you to pay careful attention and to observe, first, what sort of thing a hot and wet mixture is, as it is nothing like spring, a temperate thing; second, that it is necessary for everything to putrefy in it. Now Hippocrates begins his account as follows: "A southerly year, rainy, with complete absence of wind throughout." Then to these things he adds the particulars of the entire condition, writing that many rains occurred in a hot and southerly condition, and then again bringing together the entire account into one summary at the end thus: "The year having become," he says, "entirely southerly, and wet, and mild, such and such things occurred"—all of which would be too long to record in this present discourse; but it is possible for anyone who wishes, taking the third book of the Epidemics, to read the particulars, all of which are brought together into one summary: a very great putrefaction, which Hippocrates himself also mentions by name many times, sometimes speaking in this manner: "And the discharge that formed was not like pus, but a certain other putrefaction, and the discharge was copious and varied"; and at other times again thus: "And carbuncles on the genitals during summer, and other things which are called putrefaction," and how from this putrefaction in many cases the entire arm and forearm fell off, and in many cases the thigh or the parts around the shin were stripped bare, and the entire foot.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But here, if only a single season is rearranged, the harm is less; but if two or three should be exchanged, or if the whole year should turn moist and warm, it is necessary that the greatest plague should then ensue, such as he relates in the third book of the Epidemics. I will first set down what he said about the disordering of the seasons, and then in order what concerns the ensuing destruction among human beings. In all of this I urge you to pay the closest attention and consider: first, what sort of thing a hot and moist mixture [krasis, “constitution/temperament”] is—how it is in no way like spring, which is a well-balanced condition; second, that in such a mixture it is necessary that all things putrefy. Accordingly, Hippocrates begins his account as follows: “A year southerly, rainy, windless throughout.” Then he adds to these the particulars of the whole condition, writing that many showers occurred in a warm and moist state; and then again he brings the whole account at the end into a single heading as follows. “And when,” he says, “the whole year proved southerly, and wet, and mild, such and such things ensued”—to record all of which in this discourse would be too long; but whoever wishes can, by taking up the third book of the Epidemics, read the particulars, all of them brought under a single heading: the greatest putrefaction [σηπεδών, “rotting”], which Hippocrates himself often mentions by name—at one time speaking thus
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ ὀστῶν, καὶ σαρκῶν, καὶ νεύρων, καὶ ἄρθρων ἐκπτώσεις ἐγίγνοντο μεγάλαι. καὶ ὅλως οὐδέν ἐστιν εὑρεῖν ὧν ἔγραψε παθημάτων, ὃ μὴ σηπεδόνος ἔγγονον ὑπάρχει, δεόντως. οὔτε γὰρ ὑπὸ τοῦ ξηροῦ τι σήπεσθαι πέφυκεν, οὔθ’ ὑπὸ τοῦ ψυχροῦ. μάθοις δ’ ἂν, εἰ θεάσαιο τά τε κρέα καὶ τὰ ἄλλα σύμπαντα τὰ πρὸς τῶν ἀνθρώπων ταριχευόμενα, τὰ μὲν ἁλσὶ, τὰ δ’ ἅλμῃ, τὰ δ’ ὄξει, τὰ δ’ ἄλλῳ τινὶ τῶν ξηραινόντων σκευαζόμενα καλῶς. μάθοις δὲ καὶ ὡς ἐν τῷ βοῤῥᾷ, ξηρῷ καὶ ψυχρῷ τὴν φύσιν ὑπάρχοντι, ἄσηπτα μέχρι πλεῖστον διαμένει πάντα· σήπεται δ’ ἑτοίμως ταῖς νοτίαις καταστάσεσιν. ἔστι γὰρ οὖν καὶ οὗτος ὁ ἄνεμος ὑγρὸς καὶ θερμός. ὥστε πᾶν τοὐναντίον ἡμεῖς ἀποφαινόμεθα τοῖς ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ὑπολαμβάνουσιν εἶναι τὸ ἔαρ. οὔτε γὰρ τοιοῦτό ἐστιν, οὔθ’ ὑγιεινὸν ἂν ἦν, εἴπερ ἦν τοιοῦτο. οἱ δὲ καὶ τοιοῦτο εἶναί φασιν αὐτὸ, καὶ διὰ τοῦθ’ ὑγιεινὸν ὑπάρχειν, ἐν ἀμφοτέροις ἁμαρτάνοντες, ὅσα τε ταῖς αἰσθήσεσιν ἔνεστι διαγνῶναι, καὶ ὅσα τῷ λόγῳ διασκέψασθαι. ταῖς μὲν γὰρ αἰσθήσεσιν ἔνεστιν ἐναργῶς μαθεῖν εὔκρατον ἀκριβῶς αὐτὸ, τῷ λόγῳ δ’ ἐξευρεῖν, ὡς διὰ τοῦτ’ ἔστιν ὑγιεινὸν, διότι μηδὲν ἐν αὐτῷ τῶν τεττάρων ἐπικρατεῖ. εἰ δέ γ’ ἤτοι τὸ θερμὸν ἐπεκράτει πολλῷ τοῦ ψυχροῦ, ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ, σηπεδόνων τε ἂν ἦν εὔφορον οὕτω καὶ πασῶν τῶν ὡρῶν νοσωδέστατον.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But also great dislocations of bones, flesh, sinews, and joints occurred. And in general, it is impossible to find any of the afflictions he described that is not the offspring of putrefaction, and rightly so. For nothing is naturally disposed to putrefy either by dryness or by cold. You would learn this if you observed both meats and all other things that are preserved by people—some prepared with salt, others with brine, others with vinegar, and others with some other drying agent—being preserved well. You would also learn that in the north wind, which is dry and cold by nature, all things remain free from putrefaction for the longest time; but they putrefy readily in southerly conditions. For this wind too is moist and warm. Consequently, we declare the complete opposite to those who suppose that spring is moist and warm. For it is neither such, nor would it be healthful if it were such. But they both say that it is such and that it is healthful for this reason, erring in both respects—both in what can be discerned by the senses and in what can be examined by reason. For by the senses one can clearly learn that it [spring] is precisely well-tempered, and by reason one can discover that it is healthful for this reason: because none of the four [qualities] predominates in it. But if either the hot greatly predominated over the cold, or the moist over the dry, it would thus be productive of putrefactions and the most disease-ridden of all the seasons.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But there also occurred great sloughings of bones, and of flesh, and of sinews [tendons/ligaments], and of joints. And, in general, there is nothing among the afflictions he has written about that is not, properly speaking, the offspring of putrefaction. For nothing is by nature inclined to rot because of what is dry, nor because of what is cold. You would learn this, if you observed meats and all other things that people preserve—some with dry salt, some with brine, some with vinegar, some by being properly prepared with some other drying agents. You would also learn how in the North wind’s quarter, where the nature is dry and cold, all things remain unputrefied for the longest time; whereas they rot readily under the conditions of the South winds. For this wind too is moist and warm. Thus we come to the exact opposite conclusion from those who suppose that spring is moist and warm. For it is neither such, nor would it be healthful if it were such. Yet they say it is of that sort, and for that reason healthful, going wrong on both counts—both in what can be discerned by the senses and in what can be examined by reasoning. For by the senses one can clearly learn that it is precisely well-balanced [eukraton], and by reasoning discover that for this reason it is healthful, because none of the four [qualities: hot, cold, dry, moist] predominates in it. But if either the hot had prevailed far over the cold, or the moist over the dry, then it would have been fertile in rots and the most disease-ridden of all the seasons.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἡ τῆς τῶν τεττάρων κράσεων ἰσομοιρία τῆς τε εὐκρασίας αὐτοῦ καὶ τῆς ὑγιείας αἰτία. πόθεν οὖν ἐπῆλθέ τισιν ἰατροῖς τε καὶ φιλοσόφοις ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀποφῄνασθαι τὸ ἔαρ; ἐκ τοῦ βουληθῆναι δηλονότι τὰς τέτταρας συζυγίας τῶν κράσεων εἰς τὰς τέτταρας ὥρας διανεῖμαι. τοῦτο δ’ αὐτὸ πάλιν ἐκ τοῦ παραλιπεῖν τὴν πρώτην ἁπασῶν, τὴν εὔκρατον, ἐγένετο. καὶ γὰρ οὖν καὶ διαιτημάτων, καὶ φαρμάκων, ἁπάντων τε τῶν ὄντων, εἰς τὰς τέτταρας ταύτας συζυγίας ἀνάγουσι τὰς διαφοράς.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But the equal balance of the four mixtures is the cause both of its good mixture and of health. From where, then, did it occur to certain doctors and philosophers to declare that spring is moist and hot? From the desire, evidently, to distribute the four combinations of mixtures among the four seasons. And this itself, in turn, came about from their omission of the first of all, the well-mixed [temperate] one. For indeed they also reduce the differences of regimens, and drugs, and all existing things to these four combinations.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But it is the equal share of the four mixtures [kraseis: combinations of qualities] that is the cause both of its well-tempered state [eukrasia: balanced mixture] and of health. Whence, then, did it come to certain physicians and philosophers to declare spring to be moist and warm? From their wish, plainly, to distribute the four pairings [syzygies] of the mixtures among the four seasons. And this, in turn, arose from their leaving out the first of them all—the well-tempered one. For they also refer the differences of regimens [diaitêmata], and of drugs, and indeed of all existing things, to these four pairings.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: But the equal proportion of the four temperaments is the cause both of its good temperament [eucrasia] and of health. How, then, did it occur to some physicians and philosophers to declare the spring moist and hot? Clearly, from the desire to assign the four pairings [syzygies] of the temperaments to the four seasons. And this, in turn, came about from their omitting the first of all, the well-tempered one. For indeed, they refer the differences of regimens, of drugs, and of all existing things to these four pairings.

paragraphs.content: Ὧι καὶ δῆλον, εἰς ὅσον οἱ περὶ φύσεως ἀνθρώπου λογισμοὶ, σφαλέντες τῆς ἀληθείας, εἰς τὰς ἰάσεις βλάπτουσι, καὶ βέλτιόν ἐστι δυοῖν θάτερον, ἢ μηδ’ ὅλως ἅπτεσθαι τῶν τοιούτων λόγων, ἀλλ’ ἐπιτρέψαι τῇ πείρᾳ τὸ πᾶν, ἢ πρότερον ἐν τῇ λογικῇ θεωρίᾳ γυμνάσασθαι. τὸ δὲ μήτε τῇ πείρᾳ προσέχειν τὸν νοῦν, ἐπιχειρεῖν τε θεωρίᾳ φυσικῇ πρὸ τοῦ τὸν λογισμὸν, ᾧ μέλλοιμεν εὑρίσκειν αὐτὴν, ἀσκῆσαι πρεπόντως, ἀναγκαῖον ἀπάγειν εἰς τὰ τοιαῦτα σοφίσματα, καὶ περί γε τῶν φαινομένων ὡς ἀναισθήτους ἀναγκάζει διαλέγεσθαι, μάρτυρά τε καλεῖν Ἀριστοτέλη, παρακούοντας ὧν διδάσκει. πολλαχῶς γὰρ ἐκεῖνος οἶδε καὶ τὸ θερμὸν λεγόμενον, καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν, καὶ τὸ ξηρὸν, καὶ τὸ ὑγρόν· οἱ δ’ οὐκ ἀκούουσιν αὐτοῦ πολλαχῶς, ἀλλ’ ὡσαύτως ἀεί. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ὡς οὐ ταὐτό ἐστιν, ἢ οἰκείῳ τινὶ καὶ συμφύτῳ θερμῷ θερμὸν ὑπάρχειν, ἢ ἐπικτήτῳ καὶ ἀλλοτρίῳ, διῆλθεν Ἀριστοτέλης· οἱ δέ γε καὶ τούτου παρακούουσιν. ἔτι τε πρὸς τούτοις ὁ μὲν Ἀριστοτέλης, ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ ὁ Θεόφραστος, ἐς ὅ τι χρὴ βλέποντας ἢ εὔκρατον ἢ δύσκρατον ὑπολαμβάνειν εἶναι τὴν φύσιν, ἀκριβῶς εἰρήκασιν. οἱ δ’ οὐδὲ τοῦτο γινώσκουσιν, ἀλλ’ ὅταν ἀκούσωσι λεγόντων αὐτῶν, ὑγρὸν εἶναι καὶ θερμὸν τὸ ζῶον, ἢ τὴν τοῦ παιδὸς κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, οὔθ’ ὅπως εἴρηται ταῦτα συνίασιν, ἐμπλήκτως τε μεταφέρουσι τὸν λόγον ἐπὶ τὰς ὥρας, ὥσπερ ταὐτὸ ὂν, ἀλλ’ οὐ μακρῷ διαφέρον, ἢ τὴν οἰκείαν κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν, ἢ τὴν τοῦ περιέχοντος ἡμᾶς ἀέρος. οὔτε γὰρ ταὐτό ἐστιν οὔθ’ ὁμοίως ὑγρὰ καὶ θερμὴ ζώου κρᾶσις ἀέρος ὑγρᾷ καὶ θερμῇ κράσει λέγεται. τί δ’ ἦν τὸ τούτων ἁπάντων αἴτιον, ἤδη διηγήσομαι, καὶ δείξω σαφῶς τοῖς προσέχειν τὸν νοῦν βουλομένοις, ὡς μικρὰ πταίσματα τῶν ἐν ἀρχῇ τῆς λογικῆς θεωρίας διδασκομένων αἴτια μεγίστων ἁμαρτημάτων γίνεται, καὶ κινδυνεύει πάντα τὰ κακῶς πραττόμενα κατά τε τὰς τέχνας ἁπάσας καὶ μέντοι καὶ κατὰ τὰς ἐν τῷ βίῳ πράξεις ἕπεσθαι σοφίσμασιν. ἕπεται τοιγαροῦν καὶ τάδε τὰ σοφίσματα τῷ μὴ διελέσθαι περὶ τῶν σημαινομένων ὀρθῶς. ἀλλ’ οἰηθῆναι τὸ θερμὸν λέγεσθαι διχῶς, τὸ μὲν ὡς ἄκρατον καὶ ἄμικτον καὶ ἁπλοῦν, τὸ δὲ ὡς ἐν τῇ πρὸς τὸ ἐναντίον ἐπιμιξίᾳ πλεονεκτοῦν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: From this it is also clear to what extent reasonings about the nature of man, having missed the truth, cause harm in medical treatments, and that it is better to choose one of two alternatives: either not to engage with such arguments at all, but to entrust everything to experience, or first to train oneself in logical theory. But to pay no attention to experience, and to attempt natural theory before having properly exercised the reasoning by which we would discover it, necessarily leads to such sophistries, and compels one to speak about observable phenomena as if insensible, and to call Aristotle as a witness while mishearing what he teaches. For he knows that "hot" is spoken of in many ways, as are "cold," "dry," and "wet"; but they do not hear him saying "in many ways," but rather always in the same way. And indeed Aristotle has explained that it is not the same thing to be hot by some proper and innate heat or by an acquired and foreign heat; but they mishear even this. Furthermore, both Aristotle and likewise Theophrastus have stated precisely with reference to what one should consider nature to be well-tempered [eukratos] or ill-tempered [dyskratos]. But they do not understand even this; rather, when they hear them saying that the animal is moist and hot, or that the temperament [krasis] of a child is moist and hot, they neither understand how these things are said, nor do they foolishly transfer the argument to the seasons, as if it were the same thing—and not vastly different—for one's own temperament to be moist and hot or for the air surrounding us to be so. For it is neither the same thing nor is the temperament of an animal said to be moist and hot in the same way as the temperament of air is said to be moist and hot. Now I shall explain what was the cause of all these errors, and I shall show clearly to those willing to pay attention that small mistakes in what is taught at the beginning of logical theory become the causes of the greatest errors, and that there is a danger that all things done badly both in all the arts and indeed also in the actions of life follow from sophistries. These sophistries, therefore, follow from not having correctly distinguished the meanings. Rather, they suppose that "hot" is spoken of in two ways: on the one hand as unmixed and unblended and simple, on the other hand as prevailing in mixture with its opposite.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
From this it is also clear how far reasonings about the nature of the human being, when they slip from the truth, do harm to treatments, and that it is better to choose one of two courses: either not to touch such discourses at all, but to entrust everything to experience [peira], or first to train oneself in logical inquiry [logikē theōria]. But to pay no heed to experience and to attempt natural theory [physikē theōria] before properly exercising the reasoning by which we are going to discover it must necessarily lead to such sophistries, and even compel one to speak about the phenomena [phainomena] as if without perception, and to call Aristotle as a witness while mishearing what he teaches. For he knows that what is called “hot,” and “cold,” and “dry,” and “wet” are said in many ways; but they do not hear him as speaking in many ways, but always in one and the same way. And Aristotle went through the point that it is not the same thing for the hot to belong either as something proper and inborn [oikeion/symphyton] or as something acquired and alien [epiktēton/allotriōn]; and they fail to hear this too. Moreover, Aristotle, and likewise Theophrastus, have stated precisely what one must look to when judging nature to be well-tempered or ill-tempered [eukratos/dyskrasia]. But they do not even know this; rather, whenever they hear them say that the living creature is moist and hot, or that a child’s mixture [krasis, “temperament/constitution”] is moist and hot, they neither understand in what sense these things are said, and, in a dazed way, they transfer the account to the seasons, as though it were the same, differing only a little, whether one says that one’s own proper mixture is moist and hot, or that of the air surrounding us. For it is neither the same nor is a living creature’s mixture called moist and hot in the same way as a mixture of air is called moist and hot.

What the cause of all these things was I will now set out, and I will show clearly to those willing to pay attention that small slips in the things taught at the beginning of logical theory become causes of the greatest errors, and that everything done badly—both in all the arts [technai] and, indeed, in the actions of life—tends to be accompanied by sophistries. Accordingly, the following sophistries also result from not having made a correct distinction about what the terms signify: namely, thinking that “hot” is said in two ways—on the one hand as unmixed, unblended, and simple, and on the other as predominant in the admixture with its opposite.

paragraphs.content: ὅτι δὲ καὶ παραβάλλοντες ἑτέρᾳ κράσει πολλάκις ἑτέραν ἀποφαινόμεθα τὴν ἑτέραν αὐτῶν εἶναι θερμὴν, ἐπιλανθάνονται καὶ τοῦδε. καὶ μὴν οὕτω τὰ ζῶα θερμὰ καὶ ὑγρὰ λέγεται πρὸς τῶν παλαιῶν, οὐ κατὰ τὴν ἰδίαν κρᾶσιν ἁπλῶς, ἀλλὰ τοῖς γε φυτοῖς καὶ τοῖς τεθνεῶσι παραβαλλόμενα. καὶ γὰρ τῶν τεθνεώτων ζῶα καὶ τῶν φυτῶν ἐστι θερμότερα καὶ ὑγρότερα. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τῶν ζώων αὐτῶν ἀλλήλοις κατ’ εἴδη παραβαλλομένων, ξηρότερον μὲν ὁ κύων, ὑγρότερον δὲ ὁ ἄνθρωπος. εἰ δὲ μύρμηκι καὶ μελίττῃ παραβάλλοις τὸν κύνα, ξηρότερα μὲν ἐκεῖνα, τὸν κύνα δ’ ὑγρότερον εὑρήσεις. ὥστε ταὐτὸ ζῶον ξηρὸν μὲν ὡς πρὸς ἄνθρωπον ὑπάρχειν, ὑγρὸν δ’ ὡς πρὸς μέλιτταν· οὕτω δὲ καὶ θερμὸν μὲν, ὡς πρὸς ἄνθρωπον, ψυχρὸν δ’, ὡς πρὸς λέοντα. καὶ θαυμαστὸν οὐδὲν, εἰ τὸ πρὸς ἕτερόν τι λεγόμενον τὰς ἐναντίας ἅμα κατηγορίας ἐπιδέχεται. οὐ γὰρ τοῦτ’ ἄτοπον, εἰ ταὐτὸ σῶμα θερμὸν ἅμα λέγεται καὶ ψυχρὸν, ἀλλ’ εἰ καὶ πρὸς ταὐτό. οὐ γὰρ, ὅτι δεξιὸς ἅμα καὶ ἀριστερὸς ὁ αὐτὸς ἄνθρωπος, ἄτοπον· εἰ δέ γε πρὸς ἄλλον μὲν δεξιὸς, πρὸς ἄλλον δὲ ἀριστερὸς, οὐδὲν ἄτοπον. οὕτως οὖν καὶ κύων ὑγρὸς ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸς, καὶ θερμὸς ἅμα καὶ ψυχρὸς ἀλλ’ οὐ πρὸς ταὐτό· πρὸς μὲν γὰρ ἄνθρωπον ξηρὸς, ὑγρὸς δ’ ὡς πρὸς μύρμηκα, καὶ πρὸς μὲν ἄνθρωπον θερμὸς, ψυχρὸς δ’ ὡς πρὸς λέοντα. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ θερμὸς μὲν, ὡς ζῶν· εἰ γάρ τι τέθνηκεν, οὐ θερμόν· οὐ θερμὸς δ’ ὡς πρὸς ἕτερον, εἰ οὕτως ἔτυχε, κύνα. ταυτὶ μὲν οὖν ἅπαντα πρὸς ἄλληλα ἐκ παραβολῆς λέγεται, τὰ δ’ ὡς ἐν ζώων γένει καθ’ ἕτερον τρόπον, ὥσπερ αὖ καὶ κατ’ εἶδος ζώου. κύων γὰρ, ὡς πρὸς μὲν μύρμηκα καὶ μέλιτταν, ὑγρὸς, ὡς δ’ ἐν ζώων γένει, ξηρός. αὐτῶν δὲ τῶν κυνῶν κατ’ εἶδος, ὁδὶ μὲν ξηρὸς, ὁδὶ δὲ ὑγρὸς, ἄλλος δέ τις, ὡς κύων, εὔκρατος.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But they also forget this: that we often, by comparing one mixture with another mixture, declare that one of them is hot. And indeed, animals are called hot and moist by the ancients not simply according to their own mixture, but when compared to plants and to dead things. For animals are hotter and moister than dead things and than plants. And moreover, when animals themselves are compared with one another according to species, the dog is drier, but the human is moister. But if you were to compare the dog to an ant and a bee, you would find those creatures drier, but the dog moister. So that the same animal happens to be dry in relation to a human, but moist in relation to a bee; and likewise also hot in relation to a human, but cold in relation to a lion. And it is not at all surprising if what is spoken of in relation to something else admits opposite predications at the same time. For this is not absurd, if the same body is called both hot and cold at the same time, but only if it is so in relation to the same thing. For it is not absurd that the same man is both right and left at the same time; but if he is right in relation to one person and left in relation to another, there is nothing absurd. Thus also a dog is both moist and dry at the same time, and both hot and cold at the same time, but not in relation to the same thing; for it is dry in relation to a human, but moist in relation to an ant, and hot in relation to a human, but cold in relation to a lion. And indeed it is also hot insofar as it is living; for if something is dead, it is not hot; but it is not hot in relation to another dog, if it happens to be so. All these things, then, are spoken of in relation to one another by comparison, but the expressions "as within the genus of animals" are used in another way, just as also "according to a species of animal." For a dog, in relation to an ant and a bee, is moist, but as within the genus of animals, it is dry. But among dogs themselves according to species, this one is dry, that one is moist, and another, as a dog, is well-tempered [i.e., has a balanced mixture].
