paragraphs.content: Λέλεκται μὲν οὖν ἐπὶ πλεῖστον ἡμῖν ὑπὲρ ἁπάσης τῆς τοιαύτης χρήσεως τῶν ὀνομάτων ἐν δευτέρῳ περὶ διαγνώσεως σφυγμῶν. ἀνάγκη δὲ, ὡς ἔοικεν, εἰπεῖν τι καὶ νῦν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν διὰ κεφαλαίων, ὅσον εἰς τὰ παρόντα χρήσιμον. τὸ μὲν ἁπλῶς ξηρὸν, ὃ πρὸς μηδὲν ἕτερον λέγεται, μόνοις τοῖς στοιχείοις ὑπάρχει, πυρί τε καὶ γῇ· καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν ὕδατι καὶ ἀέρι. κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ περὶ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ χρὴ νοεῖν. οὐδὲν γὰρ τῶν ἄλλων σωμάτων ἀκριβῶς οὔτε θερμὸν οὔτε ψυχρόν ἐστιν, ἀλλ’ ἢ τὰ στοιχεῖα μόνον.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Now then, we have spoken at greatest length about all such usage of these terms in the second book On the Diagnosis of Pulses. But it is necessary, it seems, to say something about them now as well in summary form, insofar as it is useful for present purposes. The absolutely dry, which is spoken of in relation to nothing else, belongs only to the elements, both fire and earth; and indeed the moist belongs to water and air. In the same way one must also think about the hot and the cold. For none of the other bodies is precisely either hot or cold, but only the elements.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, we have spoken at greatest length about the whole of such usage of terms in the second [book] On the Diagnosis of Pulses. Yet it is necessary, it seems, to say something about them now as well, by way of headings [i.e., in outline], so far as is useful for the present. What is simply “dry,” which is said with reference to nothing else, belongs only to the elements [stoicheia], namely fire and earth; and likewise “wet” to water and air. One must think the same also concerning “hot” and “cold.” For none of the other bodies is precisely either hot or cold, but only the elements.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: We have, then,spoken at greatest length concerning all such use of terms in the second book of *On the Diagnosis of Pulses*. But it is necessary, it seems, to say something about them now as well, in summary, insofar as it is useful for the topic at hand. The 'dry' in an absolute sense [ἁπλῶς], which is not spoken of in relation to anything else, belongs only to the elements [στοιχεῖα], namely fire and earth; and likewise, the 'moist' [belongs] to water and air. And one must think of 'hot' and 'cold' according to the same principles. For none of the other bodies is precisely either hot or cold, but only the elements.

paragraphs.content: ὅ τι δ’ ἂν τῶν ἄλλων λάβῃς, ἐκ τούτων κέκραται, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο τὸ δεύτερον σημαινόμενον οὐκ ἔθ’ ἁπλῶς θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν, ὡς ἄμικτόν τε καὶ εἰλικρινὲς, ἀλλ’ ὡς ἤτοι πλέονος μὲν τοῦ θερμοῦ, τοῦ ψυχροῦ δ’ ἐλάττονος, ἢ τοῦ μὲν ψυχροῦ πλέονος, ἐλάττονος δὲ τοῦ θερμοῦ μετέχον, ἕκαστον τῶν ἄλλων ἢ θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν λέγεται. δύο μὲν δὴ ταῦτα σημαινόμενα τοῦ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ, καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ· τὸ μὲν, ἁπλῶς λεγόντων ἡμῶν, ἄμικτόν τε καὶ εἰλικρινές· ἕτερον δὲ, μικτὸν μὲν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων, ἀλλὰ τῷ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ὀνόματι προσαγορευόμενον. οὕτως μὲν οὖν ὑγρὸν αἷμα, καὶ φλέγμα, καὶ πιμελὴ, καὶ οἶνος, ἔλαιόν τε καὶ μέλι, καὶ τῶν ἄλλων τῶν τοιούτων ἕκαστον λέγεται. ὀστᾶ δὲ καὶ χόνδροι, καὶ ὄνυχες, καὶ ὁπλαὶ, καὶ κέρατα, καὶ τρίχες, καὶ λίθοι, καὶ ξύλα, καὶ ψάμμος, καὶ κέραμος, ἐλάττονα μὲν ὑγροῦ μοῖραν ἕχει, πλείονα δὲ ξηροῦ, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο πάλιν ἅπαντα τὰ τοιαῦτα ξηρὰ προσαγορεύεται. μύρμηξ δὲ ξηρὸν, καὶ σκώληξ ὑγρὸν, ὡς ζῶα. καὶ πάλιν ἐν αὐτοῖς τοῖς σκώληξιν ὁδὶ μὲν ξηρότερος, ὁδὶ δὲ ὑγρότερος, ἢ ἁπλῶς ὡς σκώληξ, ἢ τῷδέ τινι παραβαλλόμενος ἑτέρῳ. αὐτὸ δὲ τοῦτο τί δή ποτέ ἐστιν, ὅταν οὕτως λέγωμεν, ὡς σκώληξ ξηρὸς, ὡς ἄνθρωπος θερμὸς, ὡς κύων ψυχρὸς, εἰ μή τις ἀκριβῶς ἀκούσειέ τε καὶ νοήσειε πρότερον, ἀνάγκη συγκεχύσθαι τὸν λόγον ἅπαντα. τὸ δ’ ἀκριβῶς ἐστιν, ὃ κᾀν τῷ δευτέρῳ περὶ τῆς τῶν σφυγμῶν διαγνώσεως λέγεται, τὸ κατὰ γένος ἢ εἶδος ὀνομάζεσθαι τηνικαῦθ’ ἕκαστον, οὐ θερμὸν μόνον, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν, ἢ ὑγρὸν, ἀλλὰ καὶ μέγα, καὶ μικρὸν, καὶ βραδὺ, καὶ ταχὺ, καὶ τῶν τοιούτων ἕκαστον, ὅταν ὑπὲρ τὸ σύμμετρόν τε καὶ μέσον ᾖ, ἢ ζῶον θερμὸν, ὅταν ὑπὲρ τὸ μέσον ᾖ τῇ κράσει ζῶον, ἢ ἵππος θερμὸς, ὅταν ὑπὲρ τὸν μέσον ἵππον ᾖ. τὰ δ’ ἐν ἑκάστῳ γένει τε καὶ εἴδει μέσα τὰ σύμμετρά ἐστιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Whatever else you might take, it is mixed from these [primary qualities], and for this reason the second meaning [of these terms] is no longer simply hot or cold, as unmixed and pure, but rather as participating in either more of the hot and less of the cold, or more of the cold and less of the hot—thus each of the other things is called either hot or cold. So then there are these two meanings of hot and cold, and of dry and moist: one, when we speak simply, [refers to what is] unmixed and pure; the other [refers to what is] mixed from opposites, but is named by the term of the predominant [quality]. Thus in this way blood is called moist, as are phlegm, fat, wine, oil, honey, and each of the other such things. But bones and cartilage, nails, hooves, horns, hair, stones, wood, sand, and pottery have a smaller portion of the moist and a greater [portion] of the dry, and for this reason all such things are again called dry. An ant is dry and a worm is moist, as animals. And again among the worms themselves, this one is drier and that one moister, either simply as a worm or when compared to some other particular one. But what exactly is this very thing, whenever we speak thus—"dry as a worm," "hot as a man," "cold as a dog"—unless someone hears and understands it precisely beforehand, the entire argument must necessarily be confused. The precise [understanding] is what is also stated in the second book On the Diagnosis of Pulses: that each thing is then named according to genus or species—not only hot or cold or dry or moist, but also large and small, slow and fast, and each of such things—whenever it is beyond the proportionate and the mean; or [we say] an animal is hot whenever it is beyond the mean animal in mixture [i.e., temperament]; or a horse is hot whenever it is beyond the mean horse. The mean things in each genus and species are the proportionate ones.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Whatever else among the remaining things you take is compounded out of these, and for this reason the second meaning is no longer simply “hot” or “cold,” as something unmixed and pure, but rather as sharing either more of the hot and less of the cold, or more of the cold and less of the hot; and so each of the other things is called either hot or cold. There are, then, two meanings indicated for hot and cold, and for dry and moist: the one—when we speak absolutely—is unmixed and pure; the other is mixed from the contraries, yet is designated by the name of that which predominates. Thus “moist” is said of blood and phlegm and fat, and of wine, and oil and honey, and of each of the other such things. But bones and cartilages, and nails, and hoofs, and horns, and hairs, and stones, and woods, and sand, and pottery have a smaller share of the moist and a larger of the dry, and for this reason, again, all such things are called dry. An ant is dry
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
But whatever else you take is a mixture of these qualities, and for this reason, in its second meaning, a thing is no longer called hot or cold in an absolute sense—as something unmixed and pure—but rather each of these other things is called hot or cold insofar as it partakes of more of the hot and less of the cold, or, conversely, of more of the cold and less of the hot.

There are, then, these two meanings for hot and cold, and for dry and moist. The first, when we speak in an absolute sense, is unmixed and pure; the other is mixed from the opposites, but is designated by the name of the predominant quality. Thus, then, blood, phlegm, fat, wine, oil, honey, and each of the other such things are called moist. But bones, cartilages, nails, hooves, horns, hair, stones, wood, sand, and earthenware have a lesser share of the moist and a greater share of the dry, and for this reason, in turn, all such things are designated dry. An ant is dry, and a worm is moist, considered as animals. And again, among worms themselves,

paragraphs.content: ἴσον γὰρ ἀπέχει τῶν ἄκρων ἐν ἐκείνῳ τῷ γένει τε καὶ εἴδει. γένος μὲν οὖν τὸ ζῶον, ἵππος δὲ καὶ βοῦς καὶ κύων εἴδη. καὶ δὴ καὶ μέσον μέν ἐστι τῇ κράσει καθ’ ὅλον τὸ γένος τῶν ζώων ὁ ἄνθρωπος· ἐν γὰρ τοῖς ἐφεξῆς τοῦτο δειχθήσεται. μέσος δ’ ὡς ἐν ἀνθρώποις κατ’ εἶδος ὁ καλούμενος εὔσαρκος. οὗτος δ’ ἐστὶν, ὃν οὔτε λεπτὸν, οὔτε παχὺν ἔχομεν εἰπεῖν, οὔτε θερμὸν, οὔτε ψυχρὸν, οὔτ’ ἄλλῳ τινὶ τῶν τὴν ἀμετρίαν ἐνδεικνυμένων ὀνομάτων προσαγορεῦσαι. ὅστις δ’ ἂν ὑπὲρ τοῦτον ᾖ, πάντως οὗτος ἢ θερμότερός ἐστιν, ἢ ψυχρότερος, ἢ ξηρότερος, ἢ ὑγρότερος.
paragraphs.claude_translation: For it is equally distant from the extremes in that genus and species. Now the genus is animal, while horse and ox and dog are species. And indeed, man is intermediate in mixture with respect to the entire genus of animals; for this will be demonstrated in what follows. But intermediate as among humans according to species is the one called "well-fleshed" [eusarkos]. This is the person whom we can call neither thin nor fat, neither hot nor cold, nor address by any other of the names that indicate disproportion. But whoever is beyond this person is in every case either hotter or colder or drier or moister.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For [the mean] is equally distant from the extremes within that genus and species. The genus [genos] is “animal,” while horse, ox, and dog are species [eide]. And indeed, the human being is the mean in respect of mixture/temperament [krasis] across the whole genus of animals; for this will be shown in what follows. But, as among human beings by species, the so‑called “well‑fleshed” [eusarkos] person is the mean. This is the person whom we can call neither thin nor thick, neither hot nor cold, nor designate by any of the other names that indicate lack of due measure [ametria]. And whoever goes beyond this is in any case either hotter or colder or drier or wetter.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: For it is equally distant from the extremes in that genus and species. Now, the genus is 'animal,' while horse and ox and dog are species. And indeed, man is a mean in his temperament [krasis: the mixture of the fundamental qualities or humors] throughout the whole genus of animals; for this will be shown in what follows. And the mean among men, according to species, is the one called 'well-fleshed' [eusarkos: literally 'good-fleshed,' denoting a person of ideal physical constitution]. This is the one whom we can describe as neither thin nor fat, neither hot nor cold, nor address by any other of the names that indicate a lack of due measure [ametria]. But whoever is in excess of this one is, in every case, either hotter, or colder, or drier, or wetter.

paragraphs.content: ὀνομάζεται δὲ πῇ μὲν ἁπλῶς ὁ τοιοῦτος, πῇ δ’ οὐχ ἁπλῶς. ἁπλῶς μὲν, ὅτι θερμὸς ἢ ψυχρὸς, ἢ ξηρὸς ἢ ὑγρὸς εἶναι λέγεται, μηκέτι παραβαλλόμενος ἀφωρισμένως ἑνὶ τῷδε. καθ’ ἕτερον δὲ τρόπον οὐχ ἁπλῶς, ὅτι τῷ συμμέτρῳ τε καὶ μέσῳ παντὸς τοῦ εἴδους παραβάλλεται. οὕτω δὲ καὶ κύων ζῶον ξηρὸν ἁπλῶς μὲν, ὡς ἄν τῳ δόξειε, λέγεται, μηκέτι παραβαλλόμενος, εἰ τύχῃ, μύρμηκι, καθ’ ἕτερον δὲ τρόπον οὐχ ἁπλῶς, ὅτι τῷ συμμέτρῳ τε καὶ μέσῳ τῇ κράσει παντὸς τοῦ εἴδους τῶν ζώων ἁπάντων, ὅ τί ποτ’ ἂν ᾖ τοῦτο, παραβάλλεται. πρόδηλον οὖν ἤδη γέγονεν, ὡς ἕκαστον τῶν οὕτω λεγομένων ἢ ἑνὶ παραβάλλοντες ὅτῳ δήποτε θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν ἢ ὑγρὸν πρὸς ἐκεῖνο λέγομεν, ἢ τῷ μέσῳ, καθ’ ὅπερ ἂν εἶδος ἢ γένος ᾖ τὸ λεγόμενον· οἷον εἶδος μὲν ἵππον, καὶ βοῦν, καὶ κύνα, καὶ πλάτανον, καὶ κυπάριττον, καὶ συκῆν, γένος δὲ ζῶον, ἢ φυτόν. ἐπὶ τούτοις τρίτον ἄλλο σημαινόμενον ἦν τῶν ἁπλῶς λεγομένων, ἃ δὴ καὶ τὰς ἀμίκτους τε καὶ ἄκρας ἔφαμεν ἔχειν ποιότητας, ὀνομάζεσθαί τε στοιχεῖα. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τὰς ποιότητας αὐτὰς ὀνομάζομεν ἐνίοτε τοῖς ποιοῖς σώμασιν ὁμωνύμως.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Such a thing is named in one way absolutely, and in another way not absolutely. Absolutely, because it is said to be hot or cold, or dry or moist, no longer being compared in a definite way to any particular one thing. But in another manner not absolutely, because it is compared to what is moderate and intermediate for the entire class. And in this way also a dog is said to be a dry animal absolutely, as it might seem to someone, no longer being compared, for instance, to an ant; but in another manner not absolutely, because it is compared to what is moderate and intermediate in mixture for the entire class of all animals, whatever this might be. It has now become quite clear, then, that for each of the things spoken of in this way, we say it is hot or cold, or dry or moist either by comparing it to some single thing, whatever it may be, in relation to that thing, or to the intermediate, according to whatever species or genus the thing being spoken of belongs to—for example, as a species: horse, ox, dog, plane tree, cypress, and fig tree; and as a genus: animal or plant. In addition to these there was a third different meaning of things spoken of absolutely, which we said have unmixed and extreme qualities, and are called elements. And indeed we sometimes name the qualities themselves by the same names as the qualified bodies [homonymously].
paragraphs.openai_translation:
In one respect such a thing is named simply, and in another not simply. It is named simply insofar as it is said to be hot or cold, or dry or wet, without any longer being compared in a determinate way to some one particular thing. But in another way it is not named simply, in that it is compared to what is proportionate and to the mean of each species [“proportionate” = commensurate; “mean” = the normative midpoint for a kind].

Thus, too, a dog is called a dry animal, simply—as someone might suppose—without its being any longer compared, say, to an ant; but in another way it is not called simply, in that it is compared to what is proportionate and to the mean in respect of the blend [κρᾶσις: mixture] for the whole kind of all animals, whatever that may be.

It has therefore now become clear that each of the things spoken of in this way we call hot or cold, or dry or wet, either by comparing it to some one thing or other, or to the mean, according to whatever species or genus the thing in question belongs—for example, as species: horse, ox, dog, plane tree, cypress, fig tree; and as genera: animal or plant.

In addition to these there was a third thing signified among the things called “simple,” namely those which we said possess unmixed and extreme qualities, and are called elements [στοιχεῖα]. And indeed we sometimes name the qualities themselves, homonymously, after the bodies that have them [i.e., we use the quality-terms to denote the qualified bodies].
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
Such a thing is spoken of in one way simply, and in another way not simply. Simply, because it is said to be hot or cold, or dry or wet, when it is no longer being compared in a specific way to some particular thing. In another way, however, not simply, because it is compared to the well-proportioned and mean of its entire species. Thus a dog, a dry animal, might be said to be so simply, as one might think, when it is no longer being compared, for instance, to an ant; but in another way not simply, because it is compared to the well-proportioned and mean temperament [Greek: *krasis*] of the entire species of all animals, whatever that may be.

It has therefore now become quite clear that when we call each of the things so described 'hot' or 'cold', or 'dry' or 'wet', we do so either by comparing it to some one particular thing, in relation to which it is so called, or by comparing it to the mean of whatever species or genus the thing in question belongs to. For example, a species would be horse, ox, dog, plane-tree, cypress, and fig-tree; while a genus would be animal or plant.

In addition to these, there was a third meaning for things said to be 'simply' so: namely,

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ περὶ μὲν τούτου μετ’ ὀλίγον ἐροῦμεν. εἰς δὲ τὰ παρόντα, τῶν ποιῶν σωμάτων τριχῶς λεγομένων, ἐπισκοπεῖσθαι προσήκει, πῶς ἐν ἑκάστῃ ῥήσει κέχρηταί τις τῇ προσηγορίᾳ, πότερον ὡς ἁπλοῦν τι καὶ ἄμικτον δηλῶν, ἢ ὡς πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον ὁμογενὲς ἢ ὁμοειδὲς παραβάλλων, ἢ πρὸς ὁτιοῦν τὸ ἐπιτυχόν· οἷον ὅταν ὀστοῦν εἴπῃ τις ξηρὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἁπλῶς οὑτωσὶ μόνον ὀνομάσας, ἄνευ τοῦ προσθεῖναι λέοντος, ἢ κυνὸς, ἢ ἀνθρώπου. δῆλον γὰρ, ὡς πρὸς τὴν ὅλην φύσιν ἀποβλέπων ἁπάντων τῶν ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ σωμάτων ἐπινοεῖ τι μέσον, ᾧ παραβάλλων αὐτὸ ξηρὸν εἶναί φησι. ἂν δέ γε τὸ τοῦ λέοντος, ἢ τὸ τοῦ κυνὸς, ἢ τὸ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ὀστοῦν εἴπῃ ξηρὸν εἶναι, δῆλον ὡς ἐν αὐτοῖς πάλιν τοῖς τῶν ζώων ὀστοῖς τῷ μέσῳ παραβάλλει. καὶ χρὴ κᾀνταῦθά τι νοῆσαι πάντων τῶν ζώων, τῶν μὲν μᾶλλον, τῶν δὲ ἧττον ἐχόντων ὀστᾶ ξηρὰ, μέσον εἶναι τὴν κρᾶσιν ὀστοῦν ἔν τινι γένει ζώων, οἷον ἀνθρώπου, εἰ τύχοι, καὶ τούτῳ τἄλλα παραβαλλόμενα, τὰ μὲν ὑγρὰ, τὰ δὲ ξηρὰ προσαγορεύεσθαι. καὶ μὲν δὴ κᾀν τοῖς ἀνθρώποις αὐτοῖς πάλιν ὁ μέν τις ξηρὸν, ὁ δ’ ὑγρὸν ὀστοῦν ἔχειν λεχθήσεται, τῷ μέσῳ παραβαλλόμενος ὡς ἐν ἀνθρώποις.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But concerning this matter we shall speak shortly. For present purposes, since qualified bodies are spoken of in three ways, it is appropriate to examine how someone has used the term in each statement: whether indicating something simple and unmixed, or comparing it to what is proportionate and homogeneous or of the same kind, or to just anything at random. For example, when someone says that bone is dry or cold, naming it simply in this way alone, without adding "of a lion," or "of a dog," or "of a human." For it is clear that, looking toward the whole nature of all bodies in the universe, he conceives of something intermediate, comparing it to which he says that it is dry. But if indeed he says that the bone of a lion, or of a dog, or of a human is dry, it is clear that he is comparing it again to the intermediate among the bones of animals themselves. And here too one must conceive that, among all animals—some having bones that are more dry, others less so—there is a bone intermediate in mixture [i.e., temperament] in some class of animals, for instance of humans, if it so happens, and that the others being compared to this are called some moist, others dry. And indeed even among humans themselves in turn, one person will be said to have dry bone, another moist bone, being compared to the intermediate as found among humans.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But about this we shall speak shortly. For the present, since “qualified bodies” [i.e., bodies characterized by qualities] are spoken of in three ways, it is proper to examine, in each statement, how one uses the appellation: whether declaring something as simple and unmixed, or by comparing it as homogeneous or similar-in-form with reference to a commensurate standard, or with reference to whatever happens to present itself. For example, when someone says that “bone” is dry or cold, naming it thus in simple terms, without adding “of a lion,” or “of a dog,” or “of a human,” it is clear that, looking to the whole nature of all the bodies in the world, he conceives some mean, and by comparing it to this he says it is dry. But if he says that the bone of a lion, or of a dog, or of a human is dry, it is clear that he is again comparing to the mean among the bones of animals themselves. And one must in this case too conceive something of the sort: among all animals—some having bones that are more dry, others less—there is a mean in respect of mixture [krasis], a bone in some kind of animals—say, in a human, if it should happen—and, when others are compared to this, some are designated “moist,” others “dry.” And indeed, even among humans themselves, one person will be said to have a dry bone, another a moist one, by comparison with the mean as it obtains among humans.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: But we will speak of this shortly. As for the present, since the term ‘qualitative bodies’ is used in three ways, it is proper to examine how in each utterance one uses this term: whether as indicating something simple and unmixed, or as comparing it to the well-proportioned [mean] of a homogenous or similar kind, or in relation to just anything at random. For instance, when someone calls a bone dry or cold, naming it just so, simply, without adding ‘of a lion,’ or ‘of a dog

paragraphs.content: ὅτι δ’ ἐν ἅπασι τοῖς οὖσι τὸ μέσον τῶν ἄκρων ἐστὶ τὸ σύμμετρον καὶ κατ’ ἐκεῖνο τὸ γένος ἢ εἶδος εὔκρατον, ἀεὶ χρὴ προσυπακούειν ἐν ἅπαντι τῷ λόγῳ, κᾂν παρελθόντες ποτὲ τῇ λέξει τύχωμεν αὐτῇ. καὶ μὲν δὴ τούτων οὕτως ἐχόντων, ὅταν ὑγρὰν εἶναί τις εἴπῃ τήνδε τὴν κρᾶσιν, ἢ θερμὴν, ἐρωτᾷν, ὅπως εἴρηκεν, ἆρά γε τῷδέ τινι παραβάλλων ἀφωρισμένως ἑνὶ, καθάπερ, εἰ τύχοι, τῷ Πλάτωνι τὸν Θεόφραστον, ἢ κατὰ γένος ὁτιοῦν, ἢ εἶδος. ἢ γὰρ ὡς ἄνθρωπον, ἢ ὡς ζῶον, ἢ ὡς οὐσίαν ἁπλῶς. τὸ γὰρ δὴ τρίτον σημαινόμενον ἑκάστῳ τῶν τοιούτων ὀνομάτων, ὅπερ ἁπλοῦν ἐλέγομεν εἶναι καὶ ἄμικτον, οὐκ ἔστιν ἐν τοῖς κεκραμένοις, ἀλλ’ ἐν αὐτοῖς τοῖς πρώτοις, ἃ δὴ καὶ στοιχεῖα προσαγορεύομεν. ὥστε, τριχῶς ἑκάστου τῶν ποιῶν σωμάτων λεγομένου, τῶν δύο μόνων ἡμᾶς χρήζειν εἰς τὴν περὶ κράσεων πραγματείαν, ἢ πρὸς τὸ τυχὸν ὁτιοῦν παραβάλλοντας, ἢ πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον ὁμογενές. ἐπεὶ δὲ πολλὰ τὰ γένη, καθάπερ οὖν καὶ τὰ ἄτομα, δυνήσεται ταὐτὸ σῶμα καὶ θερμὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν, καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν εἶναι κατὰ πολλοὺς τοὺς τρόπους.
paragraphs.claude_translation: That in all existing things the mean between the extremes is what is proportionate and well-tempered according to that genus or species, one must always understand implicitly throughout the entire argument, even if we happen at some point to omit it in our actual wording. And indeed, since these matters stand thus, whenever someone says that this particular mixture is moist or hot, one must ask in what way he has spoken—whether he is making a comparison with some one definite thing, as for instance, if it so happens, comparing Theophrastus with Plato, or according to some genus or species. For either as a human being, or as an animal, or as a substance simply. For indeed the third signification of each of such terms, which we said was simple and unmixed, does not exist in mixed things, but in the primary things themselves, which we also call elements. Consequently, since each of the qualified bodies is spoken of in three ways, we need only two of them for the treatise on mixtures: either making comparison with any random thing whatever, or with the proportionate thing of the same genus. But since the genera are many, just as indeed the individuals are also, the same body will be able to be both hot and cold, and both dry and moist in many different ways.
paragraphs.openai_translation: That in all existing things the mean between the extremes is what is proportionate and, relative to that genus or species, well-mixed [eukraton], must always be tacitly understood throughout the whole discussion, even if we should at times happen to pass it over in our wording. And since this is so, whenever someone says that such-and-such a mixture [krasis] is moist or hot, one should ask how he has said it—whether by comparing it to some one determinate thing, as, say, Theophrastus to Plato, or according to some genus or species; that is, as a human being, or as an animal, or as substance simply. For the third thing signified by each of such names—what we said is simple and unmixed—is not present in mixed things, but in the primary things themselves, which we also call elements. Accordingly, since each of the qualified bodies [i.e., bodies characterized by qualities] is spoken of in three ways, we need only two of them for the inquiry concerning mixtures: either by comparison to some chance particular, or to the commensurate homogeneous [of the same kind]. Since the genera are many, as indeed are the individuals, the same body will be able to be, in many ways, both hot and cold, and dry and moist.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: That in all existing things the mean between the extremes is what is well-proportioned, and that in respect to this [mean] a genus or species is well-tempered, one must always understand implicitly throughout the entire discussion, even if we should happen to omit it in our actual phrasing. And indeed, this being the case, whenever someone says that this particular temperament [krasis] is wet, or hot, one must ask in what sense he has said it: whether by comparing it to some one specific thing—just

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅταν μὲν ἑνὶ τῷ τυχόντι παραβάλληται, πάνυ σαφές ἐστιν, ὡς ἐγχωρεῖ τἀναντία λέγεσθαι ταὐτὸν, οἷον Δίωνα Θέωνος μὲν καὶ Μέμνονος ξηρότερον, Ἀρίστωνος δὲ καὶ Γλαύκωνος ὑγρότερον. ὅταν δὲ πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον, ὁμογενὲς ἢ ὁμοειδὲς, ἐνταῦθ’ ἤδη συγχεῖσθαί τε καὶ ταράττεσθαι συμβαίνει τοὺς ἀγυμνάστους.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But whenever something is compared to any random individual, it is quite clear that opposite things can be said about the same thing—for example, that Dion is drier than Theon and Memnon, but moister than Ariston and Glaucon. However, whenever the comparison is made to what is proportionate [or well-balanced], homogeneous, or of the same kind, then it turns out that those who are untrained become confused and disturbed.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But whenever it is compared with any random individual, it is quite clear how it is permissible for contraries to be predicated of the same thing—for example, that Dion is drier than Theon and Memnon, but wetter than Ariston and Glaucon. But when [the comparison is] with what is commensurate [σύμμετρον], homogeneous [ὁμογενές], or of the same kind [ὁμοειδές], it is at that point that the untrained become confused and disturbed.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: But when it is compared with any given individual, it is perfectly clear that the same thing can be described by opposite terms—for instance, that Dion is drier than Theon and Memnon, but wetter than Ariston and Glaucon. When, however, the comparison is with what is commensurate [the well-proportioned standard], of the same genus or species, it is then that the untrained happen to become confused and disturbed.

paragraphs.content: ὁ γὰρ αὐτὸς ἄνθρωπός ὑγρὸς ἅμα καὶ θερμὸς εἷναι δύναται, καὶ ξηρὸς καὶ ψυχρός· ξηρὸς μὲν καὶ ψυχρὸς, ὡς πρὸς τὸν σύμμετρον ἄνθρωπον παραβαλλόμενος, ὑγρὸς δὲ καὶ θερμὸς, ὡς πρὸς ἄλλο τι ζῶον, ἢ φυτὸν, ἢ οὐσίαν ἡντιναοῦν· οἷον ὡς πρὸς μὲν ζῶον, εἰ τύχοι, μέλιττάν τε καὶ μύρμηκα, πρὸς δὲ φυτὸν, ἐλαίαν, ἢ συκῆν, ἢ δάφνην, πρὸς οὐσίαν δὲ τινα ἑτέραν, ἣ μήτε ζῶόν ἐστι, μήτε φυτὸν, οἷον λίθον, ἢ σίδηρον, ἢ χαλκόν ἐν τούτοις δὲ τὸ μὲν πρὸς ἄνθρωπον παραβάλλειν, πρὸς ὁμοειδές ἐστιν ἡ παραβολὴ, τὸ δὲ πρὸς μέλιτταν ἢ μύρμηκα πρὸς ὁμογενὲς, ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ πρὸς φυτὸν ὁτιοῦν. ἔστι γὰρ ἀνωτέρω τοῦ ζώου τοῦτο τὸ γένος, ὥσπερ οὖν καὶ αὐτοῦ τούτου λίθος καὶ σίδηρος καὶ χαλκὸς ἐκ τῶν ἄνωθεν γενῶν. καλείσθω γοῦν ὁμογενὲς ἕνεκα συντόμου διδασκαλίας ἡ τοιαύτη σύμπασα παραβολή· τοσόνδε μόνον ἐν αὐτῇ διελομένων ἡμῶν, ὡς, ἐπειδὴ μὲν ἁπλῶς οὐσία τις εὔκρατος λέλεκται, καὶ ταύτης δέ τις ἑτέρα ξηροτέρα καὶ θερμοτέρα, καὶ ψυχροτέρα καὶ ὑγροτέρα, τὴν μὲν εὔκρατον ἐνταῦθα τὴν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων ἀκριβῶς ἴσων συνελθόντων ὀνομάζομεν, ὅσον δ’ ἀπολείπεται τῆσδε καὶ πλεονεκτεῖ κατά τι, τῷ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ὀνόματι προσαγορεύομεν· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἤτοι φυτὸν ἢ ζῶον εὔκρατον ὁτιοῦν εἴπωμεν, οὐκ ἔθ’ ἁπλῶς ἐν τῇ τοιαύτῃ τάξει τἀναντία παραβάλλομεν ἀλλήλοις, ἀλλὰ πρὸς τὴν τοῦ φυτοῦ φύσιν ἢ τὴν τοῦ ζώου τὴν ἀναφορὰν ποιούμεθα, συκῆν μὲν εὔκρατον, εἰ τύχοι, λέγοντες, ὅταν, οἵαν μάλιστα πρέπει τὴν φύσιν ὑπάρχειν συκῇ, τοιαύτη τις ᾖ, κύνα δ’ αὖ, καὶ σῦν, καὶ ἵππον, καὶ ἄνθρωπον, ἐπειδὰν καὶ τούτων ἕκαστον ἄριστα τῆς οἰκείας ἔχῃ φύσεως. αὐτὸ δὴ τοῦτο, τὸ τῆς οἰκείας φύσεως ἔχειν ἄριστα, ταῖς ἐνεργείαις κρίνεται, καὶ γὰρ καὶ φυτὸν καὶ ζῶον ὁτιοῦν ἄριστα διακεῖσθαι τηνικαῦτά φαμεν, ὅταν ἐνεργῇ κάλλιστα. συκῆς μὲν γὰρ ἀρετὴ βέλτιστά τε καὶ πλεῖστα τελεσφορεῖν σῦκα· κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ τῆς ἀμπέλου, τὸ πλείστας τε καὶ καλλίστας εὐφορεῖν σταφυλὰς, ἵππου δὲ, τὸ θεῖν ὠκύτατα, καὶ κυνὸς, πρὸς μὲν θήρας καὶ φυλακὰς ἄκρως εἶναι θυμοειδῆ, πρὸς δὲ τοὺς οἰκείους πραότατον. ἅπαντα οὖν ταῦτα, τά τε ζῶα λέγω καὶ τὰ φυτὰ, τὴν ἀρίστην τε καὶ μέσην ἐν τῷ σφετέρῳ γένει κρᾶσιν ἔχειν ἐροῦμεν οὐχ ἁπλῶς, ὅταν ἰσότης ἀκριβῶς ᾖ τῶν ἐναντίων, ἀλλ’ ὅταν ἡ κατὰ δύναμιν αὐτῆς ὑπάρχῃ συμμετρία. τοιοῦτο δέ τι καὶ τὴν δικαιοσύνην εἶναί φαμεν, οὐ σταθμῷ καὶ μέτρῳ τὸ ἴσον, ἀλλὰ τῷ προσήκοντί γε καὶ κατὰ τὴν ἀξίαν ἐξετάζοντες.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For the same human being can at once be moist and warm, and dry and cold: dry and cold when compared with the proportionate [i.e., well-balanced] human, but moist and warm when compared with some other animal, or a plant, or any sort of substance—say, in relation to an animal, if you like, a bee or an ant; in relation to a plant, an olive, or a fig tree, or a laurel; and in relation to some other substance that is neither animal nor plant, a stone, or iron, or bronze. In these cases, the comparison to a human is a comparison to what is of the same species, whereas the comparison to a bee or an ant is to what is of the same genus; likewise, so too with any plant. For that is a genus superior to the animal, and likewise even stone, iron, and bronze belong to genera higher than this. Let, then, for the sake of concise exposition, the whole of such comparison be called “homogeneous” [homogenes], with only this distinction allowed in it: since we speak, in general, of some substance as well-tempered [eukratos, having a balanced mixture] and of another as drier and hotter, or colder and moister, we call “well-tempered” here that in which the opposed qualities have come together in exactly equal measure; and whatever falls short of this and has an excess in some respect, we designate by the name of the quality that has the excess. But whenever we say that some plant or animal is well-tempered, we no longer set the contraries against one another simply in such a class; rather, we take our reference from the nature of the plant or of the animal. Thus we call a fig tree well-tempered, if you will, whenever it is such as most befits the nature that ought to belong to a fig tree; and likewise a dog, a pig, a horse, and a human being, whenever each of these has its own nature in the best condition. Now this very thing—having one’s own nature in the best condition—is judged by the activities; for we say that any plant or animal whatsoever is in the best state when it is functioning at its best. For the excellence [aretē] of a fig tree is to bring to perfection figs that are both the best and the most; and similarly with the vine, to bear the most and finest clusters; for a horse, to run fastest; and for a dog, to be supremely spirited for hunting and guarding, and yet most gentle toward its own people. Accordingly, we shall say that all these things—both animals and plants—possess the best and the mean [i.e., the appropriate middle] mixture [krasis] within their own kind not simply when there is an exact equality of the contraries, but when there exists the proportion appropriate to its capacity. And we say something of this sort also about justice, assessing equality not by scale and measure, but by what is fitting and in accordance with worth.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further
paragraphs.claude_translation: For the same person can be both moist and hot at the same time, and dry and cold: dry and cold when compared to the well-balanced person, but moist and hot when compared to some other animal, or plant, or any substance whatsoever; for example, when compared to an animal, it might be a bee or an ant, or when compared to a plant, an olive tree, or a fig tree, or a laurel, or when compared to some other substance that is neither an animal nor a plant, such as a stone, or iron, or bronze. In these cases, the comparison to a human being is a comparison to something of the same species [homoeidēs], while the comparison to a bee or an ant is to something of the same genus [homogenēs], and likewise also to any plant whatsoever. For this genus is higher than that of the animal, just as stone and iron and bronze are from the genera above even this. Let such a comparison in its entirety be called "of the same genus" [homogenēs] for the sake of concise instruction; we make only this one distinction in it: that when a substance is said to be well-balanced in an absolute sense, and another substance is drier and hotter than this, or colder and moister, we call "well-balanced" here that which has come together from exactly equal opposites, while whatever falls short of this or exceeds it in some respect, we designate by the name of the quality that predominates. But when we say that any plant or animal whatsoever is well-balanced, we no longer compare the opposites to each other in an absolute sense in such a classification, but rather we make our reference to the nature of the plant or the nature of the animal, saying, for instance, that a fig tree is well-balanced whenever it is of such a nature as it is most fitting for a fig tree to have, and likewise a dog, and a pig, and a horse, and a human being, whenever each of these too is in the best condition of its own nature. This very thing—being in the best condition of one's own nature—is judged by the activities [energeiai], for indeed we say that any plant or animal whatsoever is in the best condition precisely when it performs its functions most excellently. For the excellence of a fig tree is to bear the best and most numerous figs; and similarly for the vine, to produce the most numerous and finest grapes; for a horse, to run most swiftly; and for a dog, to be extremely spirited toward hunting and guarding, but most gentle toward its household members. Therefore, all these things—I mean both the animals and the plants—we shall say have the best and middle mixture [krasis] in their own genus not in an absolute sense, when there is exact equality of the opposites, but when the proper proportion for it exists. We say that justice too is something of this sort, examining what is equal not by weight and measure, but by what is fitting and according to worth.

paragraphs.content: ἰσότης οὖν κράσεως ἐν ἅπασι τοῖς εὐκράτοις ζώοις τε καὶ φυτοῖς ἐστιν, οὐχ ἡ κατὰ τῶν κερασθέντων στοιχείων ὄγκον, ἀλλ’ ἡ τῇ φύσει τοῦ τε ζώου καὶ τοῦ φυτοῦ πρέπουσα. πρέπει δ’ ἔσθ’ ὅτε, τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ, τὸ δὲ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλέον ὑπάρχειν. οὐ γὰρ ὁμοίαν χρὴ κρᾶσιν ἔχειν ἄνθρωπον, καὶ λέοντα, καὶ μέλιτταν, καὶ κύνα. πρὸς δὲ τὸν ἐρόμενον, ἧστινός ἐστι κράσεως ἄνθρωπος, ἢ ἵππος, ἢ βοῦς, ἢ κύων, ἢ ὁτιοῦν ἄλλο τῶν πάντων, οὐχ ἁπλῶς ἀποκριτέον. οὐ γὰρ ἐγχωρεῖ τὰ πολλαχῶς λεγόμενά τε καὶ κρινόμενα, καθ’ ἕνα τρόπον ἀποκρινάμενον, ἀνέγκλητον εἶναι. χρὴ τοίνυν δυοῖν θάτερον, ἢ πάσας ἐπεξέρχεσθαι τὰς διαφορὰς, ἢ, περὶ τίνος ἤρετο, πυθόμενον, ἐκείνην μόνην εἰπεῖν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ὡς ἐν ζώοις ἐπυνθάνετο, τίνος εἴη κράσεως, ἐπὶ τὸ μέσον ἁπάντων ζώων τῇ κράσει βλέποντα, τὴν ἀπόκρισιν αὐτὴν ποιητέον· εἰ δ’ ἁπλῶς τε καὶ ὡς πρὸς ἅπασαν οὐσίαν, οὕτως ἤδη παραβάλλειν τὰ ἐναντία τῶν ἐν αὐτῷ πρὸς ἄλληλα, καὶ σκοπεῖσθαι, μηκέτι πρὸς τὰς ἐνεργείας ἀναφέροντα τὴν κρᾶσιν, ἀλλὰ πρὸς τοὺς ὄγκους τῶν στοιχείων. εἰ δ’ ἀφωρισμένως τῷδέ τινι παραβάλλων ἤρετο, πρὸς ἐκεῖνο μόνον παραβλητέον. ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον, εἴ τινος τῶν ἀτόμων οὐσιῶν, οἷον, εἰ τύχοι, Δίωνος, ἢ τοῦδέ τινος τοῦ κυνὸς, ἐρωτηθείημεν ὁποία τις ἡ κρᾶσίς ἐστιν, οὐχ ἁπλῶς ἀποκριτέον. ἀφορμὴ γὰρ οὐ σμικρὰ τοῖς σοφισταῖς ἐντεῦθεν εἰς τὸ συκοφαντεῖν. εἰ γὰρ εἴποις, θερμῆς καὶ ξηρᾶς κράσεως εἶναι τὸν Δίων, ῥᾷστον αὐτῷ, προχειρισαμένῳ τῶν ξηροτέρων καὶ θερμοτέρων ἐκείνου τὴν κρᾶσιν ἄνθρωπον ὁντιναοῦν, ὑγρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ὡς πρὸς ἐκεῖνον ἀποφῇναι τὸν Δίωνα· τοῦτο δ’ ἄλλο τι ζῶον ἢ φυτὸν, οἷον, εἰ τύχοι, λέοντά τε καὶ κύνα, καὶ τούτων ὑγρότερόν τινα καὶ ξηρότερον ἀποδεῖξαι τὸν Δίωνα. χρὴ τοίνυν, ὃς μήθ’ ἑαυτὸν ἐξαπατῆσαι βούλεται, μήθ’ ὑπ’ ἄλλου σοφισθῆναι, τοῦτον ἀπὸ τῶν ἁπλῶς λεγομένων θερμῶν, καὶ ψυχρῶν, καὶ ξηρῶν, καὶ ὑγρῶν οὐσιῶν ἀρξάμενον, οὕτως ἐπὶ τὰς ἄλλας μετιέναι, καὶ πρῶτον μὲν αὐτὸ δὴ τοῦτο ἐπ’ αὐτῶν διορίσασθαι, τὸ μηδὲ ταύτας, εἰ καὶ ὅτι μάλιστα δοκοῦσιν ἁπλῶς λέγεσθαι, πεφευγέναι τὴν πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον ὁμογενὲς παραβολήν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Equality of mixture, therefore, exists in all well-tempered animals and plants, not equality according to the mass of the elements that have been mixed, but equality that is appropriate to the nature of both the animal and the plant. And it is appropriate at times for the moist to be greater than the dry, and the hot than the cold. For a human being should not have the same mixture as a lion, a bee, and a dog. Moreover, to one who asks what mixture a human being is, or a horse, or an ox, or a dog, or any other thing at all, one must not answer simply. For it is not possible for things that are spoken of and judged in many ways to be beyond reproach when one has answered in a single manner. One must therefore do one of two things: either go through all the differences, or, having learned about what he was asking, state that one alone. For if he was inquiring, as among animals, what mixture it might be, one must make the answer looking toward the middle of all animals in mixture; but if simply and in relation to all substance, then one must now compare the opposites within it to one another, and examine them, no longer referring the mixture to the functions but to the masses of the elements. But if he asked by comparing it specifically to some particular thing, one must compare it to that alone. And even more, if we should be asked about any of the individual substances, for example, as it may be, Dion, or some particular dog, what sort the mixture is, one must not answer simply. For this provides no small opportunity for sophists to engage in trickery. For if you should say that Dion is of a hot and dry mixture, it is very easy for him, having selected any human being whatsoever who is drier and hotter in mixture than that man, to declare Dion to be moist and cold in relation to him; and to prove Dion to be moister and drier than some other animal or plant, for example, as it may be, a lion and a dog, and someone moister and drier than these. Therefore, whoever wishes neither to deceive himself nor to be tricked by another through sophistry, must begin from substances that are called simply hot, and cold, and dry, and moist, and thus proceed to the others, and first indeed distinguish this very thing concerning them: that not even these, even if they seem most especially to be spoken of simply, have escaped comparison with the commensurate homogeneous [standard].
paragraphs.openai_translation:
Equality of mixture [krasis: the blend or temperament of hot/cold/dry/moist] in all well-tempered animals and plants is not equality according to the bulk of the elements that have been mixed, but that which is fitting to the nature of the animal or the plant. And at times it is fitting that the moist be more than the dry, and the hot more than the cold. For a human being, a lion, a bee, and a dog ought not to have the same mixture. As for the person who asks of what mixture a human, or a horse, or an ox, or a dog, or anything else at all is, one must not answer without qualification. For things that are spoken of and judged in many ways cannot, if one gives a single kind of answer, be beyond reproach. One must therefore do one of two things: either run through all the distinctions, or, after learning in reference to what the question was asked, state only that.

For if he was inquiring as among animals, of what mixture it is, one should make the answer by looking to the mean, in respect of mixture, of all animals. But if he was asking simply and with reference to all substance, then one must compare the contraries within the thing to one another, and consider the matter no longer by referring the mixture to activities [i.e., functions or operations], but to the bulks of the elements. And if he asked in a determinate way, comparing it to this particular thing, one should compare it only to that.

Moreover, still more so, if we were asked of one of the individual substances—say, if it should happen, of Dion, or of this particular dog—what sort of mixture it has, we must not answer simply. For from this point the sophists get no small opportunity for captious attack. For if you were to say that Dion is of a hot and dry mixture, it is easiest for him, after taking any human being whose mixture is drier and hotter than Dion’s, to declare Dion moist and cold in comparison with that man; and to show that, compared with other living beings or plants—for example, if it should happen, a lion and a dog—Dion is in some respects wetter and in others drier than they. Therefore, whoever does not wish either to deceive himself or to be tricked by another must begin from the substances that are called simply hot, cold, dry, and moist [i.e., the “simple” bodies/elements], and thus proceed to the others; and first of all determine this very point with respect to those themselves: that not even these, although they seem most of all to be spoken of without qualification, have escaped evaluation by comparison to a like and commensurate standard.
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
Therefore, an equality of mixture [krasis] exists in all well-tempered animals and plants, not one according to the bulk of the elements mixed, but one that is fitting to the nature of the animal and the plant. And it is sometimes fitting for the wet to be more abundant than the dry, and the hot than the cold. For a human, a lion, a bee, and a dog ought not to have the same mixture.

And to one who asks what sort of mixture a human, or a horse, or an ox, or a dog, or any other thing at all possesses, one must not answer simply [i.e., without qualification]. For it is not possible, concerning things that are spoken of and judged in many ways, to be beyond reproach by answering in a single way. One must, therefore, do one of two things: either go through all the different senses [of the term], or, having first inquired what he is asking about, state that one alone. For if he were asking in the context of animals what sort of mixture it has, one must formulate the answer by looking to the mean mixture of all animals. But if [he were asking] simply and in relation to all substance, then one must in this case compare the opposites within it to one another, and examine them by no longer referring the mixture to its functions [energeiai], but to the bulks of the elements. But if he asked in a specific way, comparing it to some particular thing, it must be compared to that alone.

And even more so, if we should be asked about some individual substance—for instance, about Dion, or this particular dog—what its mixture is like, one must not answer simply. For from this, no small opportunity arises for the sophists to practice their chicanery. For if you should say that Dion is of a hot and dry mixture, it is very easy for the sophist, by producing any man whatsoever whose mixture is drier and hotter than his, to show that Dion, in comparison to that man, is wet and cold. And he can do the same with some other animal or plant—for instance, a lion or a dog—and demonstrate Dion to be wetter than one of these and drier than another.

Therefore, whoever wishes neither to deceive himself nor to be tricked by another's sophistry must begin from the substances that are called absolutely hot, cold, dry, and wet, and proceed from there to the others. And first of all, he must establish this very point concerning them: that not even these substances, though they may seem to be spoken of in the most absolute sense, have escaped comparison to what is commensurate and of the same kind [homogenes].

paragraphs.content: ὥσπερ γὰρ κύνα μέσον ἁπάντων κυνῶν τῇ κράσει λέγομεν, ὅταν ἴσον ἀπέχῃ τῶν ἄκρων, οὕτω καὶ οὐσίαν ἐροῦμεν εἶναι μέσην τῇ κράσει τὴν ἴσον ἀπέχουσαν τῶν ἄκρων, ἅ δὴ καὶ πρῶτά τέ εἰσι πάντων καὶ στοιχεῖα. ἴσον δ’ ἀφέξει δηλονότι τῶν ἄκρων, ἐξ ἴσου κερασθέντων ἁπάντων. τὴν οὖν ὑπερβάλλουσαν, ἢ ἐλλείπουσαν τῆσδε, θερμὴν, ἢ ψυχρὰν, ἢ ξηρὰν, ἢ ὑγρὰν εἶναι φήσομεν, ἅμα μὲν τῇ μέσῃ παραβάλλοντες, ἅμα δὲ καὶ τῶν ἐναντίων στοιχείων ἐξέτασιν ἐπ’ αὐτῆς ποιούμενοι. καὶ δὴ καὶ κατὰ τοῦτο μὲν ἁπλῶς ἐροῦμεν αὐτὴν ἢ θερμὴν, ἢ ξηρὰν, ἢ ψυχρὰν, ἢ ὑγράν ὑπάρχειν. ἐπειδὰν δὲ τῇ μέσῃ κράσει παραβάλλωμεν, οὐχ ἁπλῶς, ἀλλ’ ὅτι πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον ὁμογενὲς οὕτως ἔχει. γένος δ’ ἦν αὐτῶν ἡ οὐσία. πάντα γὰρ ὑπ’ αὐτὴν πέπτωκεν, ὡς ἀνώτατον τὸ γένος, ἔμψυχά τε καὶ ἄψυχα, καὶ κοινόν ἐστιν ἥδε, καὶ ἀνθρώπου, καὶ κυνὸς, καὶ πλατάνου, καὶ συκῆς, καὶ χαλκοῦ, καὶ σιδήρου, καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων γένος.
paragraphs.claude_translation: For just as we say a dog is intermediate among all dogs in its mixture when it is equally distant from the extremes, so too we shall say that a substance is intermediate in mixture when it is equally distant from the extremes, which are indeed both first of all things and elements. And it will be equally distant from the extremes, clearly, when all things have been mixed in equal proportions. Therefore we shall say that the substance which exceeds or falls short of this one is hot, or cold, or dry, or wet, comparing it at one and the same time with the intermediate, and also making an examination of the opposing elements in it. And indeed in this respect we shall say simply that it is hot, or dry, or cold, or wet. But whenever we compare it with the intermediate mixture, we shall say this not simply, but that it stands thus in relation to the well-proportioned [mixture] of the same kind. Now their kind was substance. For all things have fallen under it, as the highest kind—both ensouled and non-ensouled things—and this is the common kind of both man and dog and plane-tree and fig-tree and bronze and iron and all other things.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Just as we call a dog “middle” among all dogs in respect of its mixture [krāsis: proportion of qualities] when it is equally distant from the extremes, so too we shall say that a substance is “middle” in respect of mixture when it is equally distant from the extremes, which, in fact, are both primary of all things and are the elements. And it will be equally distant from the extremes, plainly, when all have been blended in equal measure. Therefore, whatever exceeds or falls short of this we shall say is hot, or cold, or dry, or moist—both by comparing it with the mean and by conducting an examination of the opposed elements upon it. And indeed, in this respect we shall say simply that it is hot, or dry, or cold, or moist. But whenever we compare it with the mean mixture, we shall not speak simply, but say how it stands thus in relation to the proportionate, homogeneous standard [to symmetron homoghenes: a commensurate, uniform benchmark of mixture]. And substance was their genus. For everything falls under it, as the highest genus—both ensouled and soulless—and this is common as the genus of man, and dog, and the plane-tree, and the fig-tree, and bronze, and iron, and the genus of all other things.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: For just as we speak of a dog as intermediate in its mixture [krasis] when it is equally distant from the extremes, so too will we say that a substance [ousia] is intermediate in its mixture when it is equally distant from the extremes, which are indeed the first of all things and the elements [stoicheia]. And it will clearly be equally distant from the extremes when all of them have been mixed in equal measure. Therefore, we will say that a substance which exceeds or falls short of this is hot, or cold, or dry, or wet, at once by comparing it to the intermediate one, and also by undertaking an examination of the contrary elements within it. And indeed, in this respect we will say it is simply hot, or dry, or cold, or wet. But when we compare it to the intermediate mixture, we do not speak simply, but state that it is so in relation to the balanced state of its own kind. And their genus [genos] was substance. For all things fall under it, as the highest genus—both animate and inanimate things. And this is a common genus of man, and dog, and plane-tree, and fig-tree, and bronze, and iron, and of all other things.

paragraphs.content: ὑπ’ αὐτῇ δ’ ἐστὶν ἕτερα γένη πολλά· τὸ μὲν ζῶον ὄρνιθός τε καὶ ἰχθύος, τὸ δὲ φυτὸν δένδρου τε καὶ βοτάνης· ἀετοῦ δὲ καὶ κόρακος ὄρνις, καὶ λάβρακος καὶ φωκίδος ἰχθύς. ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ τὸ μὲν δένδρον ἐλαίας τε καὶ συκῆς γένος· ἡ βοτάνη δὲ ἀναγαλλίδος τε καὶ παιονίας. ἔσχατα δ’ ἤδη γένη ταῦτα· καὶ διὰ τοῦτο καὶ εἴδη προσαγορεύεται, κόραξ, καὶ φωκὶς, καὶ συκῆ, καὶ ἀναγαλλίς· οὕτω δὲ καὶ ἄνθρωπος, καὶ βοῦς, καὶ κύων.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Under it [substance] there are many other genera: on the one hand, animal is a genus of bird and fish; on the other hand, plant is a genus of tree and herb. Bird, in turn, is a genus of eagle and crow, and fish is a genus of sea bass and seal. Similarly, tree is a genus of olive and fig; and herb is a genus of pimpernel and peony. These are now the lowest genera; and for this reason they are also called species [forms]: crow, seal, fig, and pimpernel. In the same way, human, ox, and dog are also [species].
paragraphs.openai_translation: Under it there are many other genera: the genus animal [genus], of bird and fish; and the genus plant, of tree and herb. And of birds, the eagle and the raven; and of fishes, the labrax [sea-bass] and the seal. Likewise, the tree is the genus of the olive and the fig; and the herb, of the anagallis [pimpernel] and the peony. These are already ultimate genera; and for this reason they are also called species—raven, and seal, and fig-tree, and anagallis; and so too man, ox, and dog.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: And under this are many other genera [γένη]: animal is the genus of bird and fish, and plant, of tree and herb. Bird, in turn, is the genus of eagle and raven, and fish, of sea-bass and seal. Likewise, tree is the genus of olive and fig, and herb, of pimpernel and peony. These, then, are the lowest genera; and for this reason they are also called species [εἴδη]: raven, and seal, and fig, and pimpernel. So too are man, and ox, and dog.

paragraphs.content: ἄνωθεν μὲν οὖν κατιόντων, ἔσχατα γένη ταῦτα, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο καὶ εἴδη προσαγορεύεται· κάτωθεν δ’ ἀνιόντων ἀπὸ τῶν ἀτόμων οὐσιῶν, πρῶτα. καὶ δέδεικται πρὸς ἑτέρου γράμματος, ὡς εὐλόγως οἱ παλαιοὶ ταῦτα ξύμπαντα τὰ μεταξὺ τῶν ἀτόμων τε καὶ τῶν πρώτων γενῶν εἴδη τε ἅμα καὶ γένη προσαγορεύουσιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Therefore, when descending from above, these are the lowest genera, and for this reason they are also called species; but when ascending from below from the individual substances, they are the first. And it has been demonstrated in another work that the ancients reasonably call all these things that are between the individuals and the primary genera both species and genera at the same time.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So then, when one proceeds downward from above, these are the lowest genera, and for this reason they are also called species; but when one ascends from below, starting from the individual substances [individuals/particulars], they are first. And it has been shown in another writing that it is reasonable that the ancients call all the things that lie between the individuals and the primary genera [highest genera] both species and genera at once.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: When descending from above, then, these are the last genera, and for this reason they are also called species [Greek: *eidē*]; but when ascending from below, from the individual substances [Greek: *atomōn ousiōn*], they are the first. And it has been demonstrated in another work that the ancients, with good reason, call all these intermediaries—between the individuals and the primary genera—both species and genera at once.

paragraphs.content: Ὁπότ’ οὖν διῄρηται τὰ σημαινόμενα, καὶ ὡς οὐχ ἁπλῶς ἀποφαίνεσθαι χρὴ θερμόν τε καὶ ψυχρὸν, καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν σῶμα, σαφῶς ἀποδέδεικται, ζητητέον ἐφεξῆς αὐτῶν τὰ γνωρίσματα. καίτοι κᾷνταῦθα χρὴ πρότερον ὑπὲρ τῶν ὀνομάτων διελέσθαι τῶν ἐμπίπτειν ἐξ ἀνάγκης μελλόντων εἰς τὸν ἐφεξῆς λόγον, ἐξαπλῶσαί τέ τι πρᾶγμα, δυνάμει μὲν ἤδη προαποδεδειγμένον, οὐ μὴν ἐναργῶς γε πᾶσι τοῖς ἐντυγχάνουσι τῷδε τῷ γράμματι νοηθῆναι δυνάμενον. ὑπὲρ τῶν ὀνομάτων οὖν πρῶτον εἰπὼν, οὕτως ἐπάνειμι ἐπὶ τὸ πρᾶγμα. τὸ θερμὸν, καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν, καὶ τὸ ξηρὸν, καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν, ὅτι μὲν οὐχ ἕν τι σημαίνει, ἐπειδὰν ἐπὶ σωμάτων λέγηται, δέδεικται πρόσθεν· ὅτι δὲ καὶ τὰς ἐν τοῖς σώμασι ποιότητας αὐτὰς μόνας, ἄνευ τῶν δεδεγμένων αὐτὰς οὐσιῶν, οὕτως ὀνομάζουσιν ἐνίοτε, τοῦτο μὲν οὔπω εἴρηται πρόσθεν, ἤδη δὲ αὐτὸ λέγεσθαι καιρός.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Since, therefore, the meanings have been distinguished, and it has been clearly demonstrated that one must not make simple declarations about hot and cold, and dry and moist body, we must investigate next their distinguishing characteristics. And yet here too it is necessary first to discuss the terms that will inevitably occur in the subsequent discourse, and to explain in detail a certain matter which has already been demonstrated in principle, but which nevertheless cannot be clearly understood by all who encounter this treatise. Having spoken first, then, about the terms, I shall thus return to the matter at hand. That "the hot," and "the cold," and "the dry," and "the moist," when spoken of in reference to bodies, do not signify one single thing, has been demonstrated previously; but that they also sometimes name the qualities themselves in bodies alone, without the substances that receive them—this has not yet been stated previously, but now is the proper time for it to be said.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Since, then, the things signified have been distinguished, and it has been clearly shown that one ought not simply to predicate of a body that it is hot or cold, and dry or moist, we must next investigate their distinguishing marks. And yet here too it is necessary first to discuss the terms that will of necessity occur in the argument to follow, and to set out more plainly a certain point that has already been demonstrated in potential, though it cannot be clearly understood by everyone who encounters this writing. So, after speaking first about the names, I shall then return to the matter itself. That “the hot,” “the cold,” “the dry,” and “the moist” do not signify a single thing when they are said of bodies has been shown previously; but that they sometimes also name the very qualities in bodies by themselves [qualities: poiotêtes], without the substances that receive them [substances: ousiai], this has not yet been stated before, and it is now time to say it.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: Since, therefore, the meanings have been distinguished, and it has been clearly demonstrated that one must not declare a body hot and cold, and dry and wet, in a simple sense, we must next investigate their characteristics. And yet, here too, it is necessary first to make distinctions regarding the names that will necessarily enter into the subsequent discussion, and to explain in full a certain matter which, though already demonstrated in potentiality [δυνάμει], cannot be understood clearly by all who encounter this writing. Therefore, having first spoken about the names, I will thus return to the matter itself. That ‘the hot,’ ‘the cold,’ ‘the dry,’ and ‘the wet’ do not signify any one thing when spoken of in connection with bodies has been demonstrated previously; but that people sometimes use these names for the qualities themselves in bodies, alone and apart from the substances [οὐσιῶν] that have received them—this has not yet been said before, but now is the time for it to be said.

paragraphs.content: ὥσπερ οὖν τὸ, λευκὸν, ὄνομα, κατά τε τοῦ χρώματος ἐπιφέρουσιν, ἐπειδὰν οὕτω λέγωσιν, ἐναντίον ἐστὶ τὸ λευκὸν χρῶμα τῷ μέλανι, κατά τε τοῦ δεδεγμένου τὸ χρῶμα σώματος, ἐπειδὰν τὸ τοῦ κύκνου σῶμα λευκὸν εἶναι φάσκωσιν, οὕτω καὶ τὸ, θερμὸν, ὄνομα, κατά τε τῆς ποιότητος ἐπιφέρουσιν, ὡς εἰ καὶ θερμότητα προσηγόρευον, ἀλλὰ καὶ κατὰ τοῦ σώματος, ὅ τὴν θερμότητα δέδεκται. τὴν γὰρ δὴ ποιότητα παρὰ τὸ δεδεγμένον αὐτὴν σῶμα ἑτέραν χρὴ νομίζειν εἶναί τινα φύσιν ἔχουσαν ἰδίαν, ὡς ἐν τοῖς περὶ τῶν στοιχείων λόγοις δείκνυται. θερμότης μὲν οὖν ποιότης· ἡ δ’ αὐτὴ καὶ θερμὸν ὀνομάζεται, καθάπερ λευκότης καὶ λευκόν. αὐτὸ δὲ σῶμα τὸ θερμὸν ἓν τοῦτο μόνον ὄνομα κέκτηται, τὸ θερμὸν, ὥσπερ τὸ λευκόν· οὐ μὴν οὔτε θερμότης, οὔτε λευκότης αὐτὸ τὸ σῶμά ποτε προσαγορεύεται. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ ξηρὸν, καὶ ψυχρὸν, καὶ ὑγρὸν ὀνομάζεται αὐτό τε τὸ σῶμα καὶ ἡ ποιότης. οὐ μὴν ἡ ψυχρότης, ἢ ξηρότης, ἢ ὑγρότης ἔτι τὸ σῶμα καλεῖται, καθάπερ ἡ ἐν αὐτῷ ποιότης. τούτων δ’ οὕτως ἐχόντων, εὔλογον, ἐπειδὰν μὲν ἤτοι θερμότητά τις ἢ ψυχρότητα διαλεγόμενος εἴπῃ, μηδὲν γίνεσθαι σόφισμα· μόναι γὰρ ἐκ τῶν τοιούτων ὀνομάτων αἱ ποιότητες δηλοῦνται· θερμὸν δ’ εἰπόντος, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἐπειδὴ καὶ ἡ ποιότης οὕτω καὶ τὸ σῶμα τὸ δεδεγμένον αὐτὴν ὀνομάζεται, πρόχειρον γίνεσθαι τῷ κακουργεῖν ἐθέλοντι, τὸ μὴ δηλούμενον ὑπὸ τοῦ λέγοντος ἀκούειν, ἵν’ ἔχῃ σοφίζεσθαι. τοιοῦτο γάρ τοι δρῶσι καὶ πρὸς τὸν ἀφορισμὸν ἀντιλέγοντες, ἐν ᾧ φησιν Ἱπποκράτης· τὰ αὐξανόμενα πλεῖστον ἔχει τὸ ἔμφυτον θερμόν. οὐ γὰρ σῶμά τι θερμὸν τὸ ἔμφυτον τῷ ζώῳ λέγεσθαι πρὸς Ἱπποκράτους ἀκούσαντες, οὐδὲ ζητήσαντες, ὅ τί ποτέ ἐστι τοῦτο, κατὰ τῆς ποιότητος μόνης, ἣν δὴ καὶ θερμότητα καλοῦμεν, εἰρῆσθαι τοὔνομα δεξάμενοι, τὴν ἀντιλογίαν οὕτω ποιοῦνται. καίτοι φαίνεται σμικρὸν ὂν τὸ διαστέλλεσθαι τὰς ὁμωνυμίας, ἐν τῇ χρείᾳ τῶν πραγμάτων ἱκανῶς ἀξιόλογον ὑπάρχον.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Just as, therefore, they apply the term "white" both to the color, when they say in this way that the white color is opposite to the black, and to the body that has received the color, when they assert that the body of the swan is white, so too they apply the term "hot" both to the quality, as if they were also calling it "heat," and also to the body which has received the heat. For indeed one must consider the quality to be a certain different nature having its own particular character apart from the body that has received it, as is demonstrated in the discussions concerning the elements. Heat, then, is a quality; and the same thing is also called "hot," just as whiteness is also called "white." But the hot body itself has acquired only this one name, "hot," just as "white"; however, neither "heat" nor "whiteness" is ever used to designate the body itself. And in the same manner both the body itself and the quality are called "dry," "cold," and "moist." Nevertheless, the body is not still called "coldness" or "dryness" or "moistness," as is the quality in it. These things being so, it is reasonable that whenever someone in discussion says either "heat" or "coldness," no sophism arises; for from such terms only the qualities are indicated. But when someone says "hot" or "cold," since both the quality and the body that has received it are named in this way, it becomes easy for one who wishes to act dishonestly to understand what is not meant by the speaker, so that he may have the opportunity to make sophistical arguments. For indeed they do such a thing when they argue against the aphorism in which Hippocrates says: "Growing things have the most innate heat." For not having understood that Hippocrates means some hot body as innate to the living creature, nor having investigated what this might be, but having accepted that the term was used only for the quality, which we also call "heat," they make their objection in this way. And yet, although distinguishing homonymies [terms with multiple meanings] appears to be a small matter, in the practical application of things it proves to be quite significant.
