paragraphs.gemini_translation:
Just as, then, they apply the name 'white' both to the color, when they say, "the white color is opposite to the black," and to the body that has received the color, when they assert that the swan's body is white, so also they apply the name 'hot' both to the quality—as if they were naming it 'hotness'—and also to the body which has received the hotness. For one must consider the quality to be a nature distinct from the body that has received it, possessing an identity of its own, as is shown in the treatises concerning the elements. Hotness, then, is a quality; and this same [quality] is also named 'hot,' just as 'whiteness' and 'white.' But the hot body itself possesses this one name only, 'hot,' just like 'white'; however, the body itself is never called 'hotness' or 'whiteness.'

And in the same way, both the body itself and the quality are named 'dry,' 'cold,' and 'wet.' However, the body is not also called 'coldness,' or 'dryness,' or 'wetness,' in the way that the quality within it is. This being the case, it is reasonable that when someone in a discussion says either 'hotness' or 'coldness,' no sophism arises, for by such names only the qualities are indicated. But when one says 'hot' or 'cold'—since both the quality and the body that has received it are so named—it becomes easy for one wishing to act maliciously to interpret what is not meant by the speaker, in order to practice sophistry.

For this is precisely what they do when they argue against the aphorism in which Hippocrates says:

paragraphs.content: Ἀλλ’ ἐπειδὴ καὶ τοῦτο σαφῶς ἤδη διώρισται, ἐπὶ τὸ ὑπόλοιπον αὖθις ἐπανιτέον. οὔσης γάρ τινος ἀκράτου καὶ ἀμίκτου ποιότητος, ὑγρότητός τε καὶ ξηρότητος, καὶ θερμότητος καὶ ψυχρότητος, ὅσα ταύτας διεδέξαντο σώματα, θερμὰ δηλονότι καὶ ψυχρὰ καὶ ξηρὰ καὶ ὑγρὰ τελέως τε καὶ ἀκριβῶς ἔσται. ταυτὶ μὲν οὖν μοι νόει τὰ τῶν γινομένων τε καὶ φθειρομένων στοιχεῖα· τὰ δ’ ἄλλα σώματα, τά τε τῶν ζώων, καὶ τὰ τῶν φυτῶν, καὶ τὰ τῶν ἀψύχων ἁπάντων, οἷον χαλκοῦ, καὶ σιδήρου, καὶ λίθων, καὶ ξύλων, ἐν τῷ μεταξὺ τῶν πρώτων ἐκείνων τετάχθαι. οὐδὲν γὰρ αὐτῶν οὔτ’ ἄκρως θερμὸν, οὔτ’ ἄκρως ψυχρὸν, οὔτ’ ἄκρως ὑγρὸν, οὔτ’ ἄκρως ξηρόν ἐστιν. ἀλλ’ ἤτοι μέσον ἀκριβῶς ὑπάρχει τῶν ἐναντίων, ὡς μηδὲν μᾶλλον εἶναι θερμὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν, ἢ ὑγρὸν, ἢ θατέρῳ τῶν ἄκρων προσκεχώρηκεν, ὡς μᾶλλον εἶναι θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ μᾶλλον ὑγρὸν ἢ ξηρόν. εἰ μὲν δὴ μέσον ἀκριβῶς εἴη καθ’ ἑκατέραν τῶν ἐναντιώσεων, ὡς μηδὲν μᾶλλον εἶναι θερμὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν, ἢ ὑγρὸν, εὔκρατον ἁπλῶς τοῦτο λεχθήσεται. θατέρου δὲ πλεονεκτήσαντος, ἤτοι κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν, ἢ κατ’ ἀμφοτέραν, οὐκ ἔτ’ εὔκρατον. εἰ μὲν δὴ θερμὸν εἴη μᾶλλον, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ὃ μᾶλλόν ἐστι, τοῦτο λεχθήσεται· ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ ὑγρόν· κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ εἰ ψυχρὸν εἴη μᾶλλον, ὀνομασθήσεται ψυχρόν. εἰ δ’ ἐξ ἑκατέρας τῆς ἀντιθέσεως ἐπικρατοίη θάτερον, ἤτοι θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὸν, ἢ θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν, ὀνομασθήσεται τὸ σῶμα κατὰ τὸ ἐπικρατοῦν. ταύτας μὲν οὖν τὰς τέτταρας δυσκρασίας, ὡς καὶ πρόσθεν εἴπομεν, οἱ πλεῖστοι γινώσκουσιν ἰατροί τε καὶ φιλόσοφοι. τὰς δ’ ἄλλας τέτταρας ἐξ ἡμίσεως τούτων γιγνομένας οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅπως παραλείπουσιν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὴν πρώτην ἁπασῶν κρᾶσιν, τὴν ἀρίστην.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But since this too has now been clearly distinguished, we must return again to what remains. For since there exists some unmixed and pure quality—wetness and dryness, and hotness and coldness—whatever bodies have received these qualities will obviously be hot and cold and dry and wet completely and precisely. These, then, you should understand to be the elements of things that come to be and perish. But the other bodies—those of animals, and those of plants, and those of all inanimate things, such as bronze, and iron, and stones, and woods—are arranged in the middle between those primary elements. For none of them is either extremely hot, or extremely cold, or extremely wet, or extremely dry. Rather, either it exists precisely in the middle of the opposites, so as to be no more hot than cold, or dry than wet, or it has inclined toward one of the extremes, so as to be more hot than cold, or more wet than dry. Now if it should be precisely in the middle with respect to each of the oppositions, so as to be no more hot than cold, or dry than wet, this will be called simply well-tempered [eukraton]. But when one side predominates, either in one opposition or in both, it is no longer well-tempered. If then it should be more hot than cold, it will be called by what it is more of; and likewise also dry and wet. In the same way also if it should be more cold, it will be named cold. But if one side from each opposition should predominate—either hot together with wet, or hot together with dry, or cold together with wet, or cold together with dry—the body will be named according to what predominates. These four dyskrasias [bad temperaments], then, as we also said before, most physicians and philosophers recognize. But the other four that arise from half of these, I do not know how they overlook, just as they also overlook the first of all temperaments [kraseis], the best one.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But since this too has now been clearly determined, we must return again to what remains. For if there exists some pure and unmixed quality—of moistness and dryness, and of heat and cold—then whatever bodies have received these will be hot and cold and dry and moist absolutely and precisely. Understand these, then, as the elements [stoicheia] of things that come to be and pass away; whereas the other bodies—those of animals, plants, and all inanimate things, such as bronze, iron, stones, and woods—are set in the interval between those first ones. For none of them is extreme in heat, nor extreme in cold, nor extreme in moisture, nor extreme in dryness. Rather, either it stands exactly at the mean of the opposites, so as to be no more hot than cold or dry than moist, or else it has inclined toward one of the extremes, so as to be more hot than cold, or more moist than dry. If indeed it were exactly at the mean with respect to each pair of opposites, so as to be no more hot than cold or dry than moist, this will be called simply “well-tempered” [eukraton, a balanced mixture]. But if one or the other prevails, either with respect to one opposition or with respect to both, it is no longer well-tempered. If, then, it is more hot than cold, it will be named by whichever quality is greater; and likewise for dry and moist; and similarly, if it is more cold, it will be called “cold.” If, however, in each opposition one of the pair is dominant—either hot together with moist, or hot together with dry, or cold together with moist, or cold together with dry—the body will be named according to what predominates. These four dyscrasias [imbalanced mixtures] most people—both physicians and philosophers—recognize, as we said before. But the other four, arising from the half-measures of these, I do not know how they overlook, just as they also overlook the first and best mixture of all.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅτι γε δυνατὸν, ἐπικρατοῦντος τοῦ θερμοῦ, μηδὲν μᾶλλον ὑγρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν εἶναι τὴν κρᾶσιν, ὅσον ἐπὶ ταύτῃ τῇ συζυγίᾳ, πρόδηλον μὲν οἶμαι κᾀκ τῶν ἤδη προειρημένων εἶναι. ῥᾷστον δὲ, κᾂν εἰ μηδὲν προείρητο, συλλογίσασθαι, συγχωρησάντων γε ἅπαξ αὐτῶν, ἑτέραν μὲν εἶναι κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ἑτέραν δὲ ξηρὰν καὶ θερμήν. εἰ γὰρ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστι πάντως εἶναι ξηρὰν τὴν θερμὴν, ἀλλ’ ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ ὑγρὰν ὑπάρχειν αὐτὴν, ἐγχωρήσει δηλονότι καὶ μέσην· ἐγγυτέρω γάρ ἐστιν ἡ μέση τῆς ξηρᾶς κράσεως, ἤπερ ἡ ὑγρά. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον ἐστί τις ἑτέρα ψυχρὰ κρᾶσις, ἐφ’ ἧς ἐστιν ἰσχυρότερον τὸ ψυχρόν· οὐ μὴν οὔθ’ ὑγρὰν, οὔτε ξηρὰν ὑπάρχειν αὐτὴν ἀνάγκη, ἀλλ’ ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ μέσην γενέσθαι· πάλιν γὰρ κᾀνταῦθα τὸν αὐτὸν ἐπάξεις λόγον. ὥστ’, εἴπερ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν ὑγρὰν εἶναι τὴν ψυχρὰν, ἀλλ’ , χωρεῖ καὶ ξηρὰν γενέσθαι, πρόδηλον, ὡς καὶ τὴν μέσην ἐγχωρήσει, ἐγγυτέρω γάρ ἐστιν αὕτη τῆς ὑγρᾶς, ἤπερ ἡ ξηρά.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation of Paragraph 8.2:

But that it is possible, when the hot predominates, for the mixture to be neither more moist nor more dry, at least with respect to this pairing, I think is evident even from what has already been said. Yet it is very easy to deduce this, even if nothing had been said before, provided that they once agree that one mixture is moist and hot, while another is dry and hot. For if it is not necessary that what is hot must in every case be dry, but it is possible for it to be moist as well, then clearly it will also be possible for it to be intermediate; for the intermediate is closer to the dry mixture than the moist is. In the same manner there is also another cold mixture, in which the cold is stronger; however, it is not necessary for it to be either moist or dry, but it is possible for it to become intermediate as well; for again in this case you will apply the same argument. Consequently, if it is not necessary for what is cold to be moist, but it is possible for it to become dry, it is evident that the intermediate will also be possible, for this is closer to the moist than the dry is.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But that it is at any rate possible, when the hot [quality] prevails, for the mixture [krasis: the balanced “temperament” of qualities] to be no more wet than dry, so far as concerns this pairing [syzygia] of attributes, is, I think, evident already from what has been said. And even if nothing had been said beforehand, it would be easiest to infer—once they have granted in the first place that there is one mixture that is wet and hot and another that is dry and hot. For if it is not necessary that what is hot be in every case dry, but it is also possible for it to be wet, then it will plainly also admit of an intermediate [state]; for the intermediate is nearer to the dry mixture than the wet is. In the same way there is another cold mixture, in which the cold is stronger; yet it is not necessary that it be either wet or dry, but it can also be intermediate; for here again you will apply the same argument. Therefore, if it is not necessary for what is cold to be wet, but it can also be dry, it is evident that it will also admit the intermediate [state], for this is nearer to the wet than the dry is.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: But that it is possible, when the hot prevails, for the temperament [krasis] to be neither more wet nor more dry, insofar as it depends

paragraphs.content: ὡς οὖν αὗται αἱ δύο δυσκρασίαι κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν ἐδείχθησαν, ἡ μὲν θερμὴ μόνον, ἡ δὲ ψυχρά· κατὰ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον ἕτεραι δύο γενήσονται κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν, ἡ μὲν ξηρὰ μόνον, ἡ δ’ ὑγρὰ, συμμέτρως ἐχόντων πρὸς ἄλληλα τοῦ θερμοῦ καὶ τοῦ ψυχροῦ. πάλιν γὰρ κᾀνταῦθα φήσομεν, ὥσπερ οὐκ ἔστιν ἀναγκαῖον, ἥ τίς ἐστι ξηρὰ κρᾶσις, εὐθὺς ταύτην εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν, ἀλλ’ ἐνδέχεται καὶ ψυχρὰν ὑπάρχειν, οὐκ ἀδύνατον ἔσται καὶ τὸ μήτε ψυχρὰν εἶναί τινα, μήτε θερμὴν, ἀλλ’ εὔκρατον μὲν κατὰ τοῦτο, ξηρὰν δὲ κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν. ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ τὴν ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον οὔτε θερμὴν, οὔτε ψυχρὰν ὑπάρχειν, ἀλλ’ ἐνδέχεται μέσην ἀμφοῖν εἶναι κατά γε ταύτην τὴν ἀντίθεσιν. εἰ τοίνυν οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον, οὔτε τῇ κατὰ τὸ ψυχρὸν καὶ θερμὸν δυσκρασίᾳ τὴν ἐκ τῆς ἑτέρας ἀντιθέσεως ἕπεσθαι, οὔτ’ ἐκείνῃ τὴν ἐκ ταύτης, ἐνδέχεταί ποτε καὶ τὴν εὔκρατον ὅσον ἐπὶ θερμότητι καὶ ψυχρότητι φύσιν ἤτοι ξηρὰν ἢ ὑγρὰν γενέσθαι, καὶ τὴν ἐν τούτοις πάλιν εὔκρατον ἤτοι θερμὴν ἢ ψυχράν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Just as, therefore, these two dyskrasias [imbalances] were shown to exist according to one opposition—the one being hot only, the other cold—in the same manner two others will arise according to the other opposition, the one being dry only, the other moist, when the hot and the cold are in proper proportion to one another. For again here too we shall say, just as it is not necessary that whatever mixture is dry should immediately be hot as well, but it is possible for it to be cold, so it will not be impossible for something to be neither cold nor hot, but rather well-balanced [eukratos] in this respect, yet dry according to the other opposition. Similarly, it is not necessary for a moist mixture to be either hot or cold, but it is possible for it to be intermediate between both, at least with respect to this opposition. If, therefore, it is not necessary either for the dyskrasia according to cold and hot to be accompanied by the one from the other opposition, or for that one to be accompanied by the one from this, it is possible at some time for a nature that is well-balanced with respect to heat and coldness to become either dry or moist, and for one that is well-balanced in these [dry and moist] in turn to become either hot or cold.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
Accordingly, just as those two imbalances [dyscrasiai: imbalances of temperament] were shown with respect to the one opposition—one being only hot, the other cold—so in the same way two others will arise with respect to the other opposition: one only dry, the other moist, while the hot and the cold stand in due proportion to one another.

For again here too we shall say: just as it is not necessary that whatever mixture [krâsis: temperament/mixture] is dry should immediately also be hot, but it may also be cold, so it will not be impossible for something to be neither cold nor hot, but well-balanced in this respect, yet dry with respect to the other opposition. Likewise, a moist mixture is not necessarily either hot or cold; rather, it may be intermediate between both in regard to this opposition.

If then it is not necessary that the imbalance according to cold and hot be accompanied by that from the other opposition, nor that from the latter by the one from the former, it is possible at times that a nature well-balanced as regards heat and cold should be either dry or moist, and that a nature well-balanced in these [i.e., in dryness and moistness] should in turn be either hot or cold.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ὥστ’ εἶναι καὶ ταύτας τέτταρας ἑτέρας ἐκείνων δυσκρασίας, ὡς οἱ πρόσθεν ἰατροί τε καὶ φιλόσοφοι παρέδοσαν ἡμῖν, καὶ μέσας γε ταύτας τετάχθαι τῶν εὐκράτων ἕξεων καὶ τῶν κατ’ ἀμφοτέρας τὰς ἀντιθέσεις δυσκράτων. ἡ μὲν γὰρ ἄκρως εὔκρατος οὐδετέραν ἀντίθεσιν ἔχει πλεονεκτοῦσαν, ἡ δ’ ἐξ ὑπεναντίου τῆσδε δύσκρατος ἀμφοτέρας μοχθηράς. ἐν μέσῳ δ’ ἐστὶν ἡ κατὰ μὲν τὴν ἑτέραν εὔκρατος, κατὰ δὲ τὴν ἑτέραν δύσκρατος ὑπάρχουσα, ἥτις ἐξ ἡμίσεως μὲν εὔκρατος, ἐξ ἡμίσεως δὲ δύσκρατος οὖσα, μέση δεόντως ἂν εἶναι λέγοιτο τῆς ὅλης εὐκράτου τε καὶ δυσκράτου. καὶ εἴπερ ταῦθ’ οὕτως ἔχει, ὥσπερ οὖν καὶ ἔχει, θαῤῥούντως ἤδη λέγομεν, ἐννέα τὰς πάσας εἶναι τῶν κράσεων διαφορὰς, εὔκρατον μὲν μίαν, οὐκ εὐκράτους δὲ τὰς ὀκτὼ, τέτταρας μὲν ἁπλᾶς, ὑγρὰν, καὶ ξηρὰν, καὶ θερμὴν, καὶ ψυχρὰν, ἄλλας δὲ τέτταρας συνθέτους, ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν, καὶ ξηρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν, καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν, καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηράν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

So that these too are four other dyskrasias [imbalances] distinct from those, as the earlier physicians and philosophers handed down to us, and indeed these are positioned midway between the eukratic [well-balanced] conditions and those that are dyskratic [imbalanced] in both oppositions. For the perfectly eukratic has neither opposition predominating, while the dyskratic that is the opposite of this has both in a bad state. In the middle is that which is eukratic in one respect but dyskratic in the other, which, being half eukratic and half dyskratic, would properly be said to be intermediate between the wholly eukratic and dyskratic. And if these things are so, as indeed they are, we may now confidently say that there are nine differences of mixtures in all: one eukratic, and eight not eukratic—four simple ones: moist, and dry, and hot, and cold; and four others that are compound: moist and hot together, and dry and hot together, and cold and moist together, and cold and dry together.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So that there are also these four other imbalances [dyskrasiai] besides those, as the earlier physicians and philosophers have handed down to us, and these are placed as intermediate between the well-balanced states [eukratai hexeis] and the ill-balanced ones with respect to both oppositions [i.e., the pairs hot–cold and dry–moist]. For the perfectly well-balanced has neither opposition prevailing; but the imbalance opposite to this has both [oppositions] in a bad condition. In between is that which, in respect of the one opposition, is well-balanced, but in respect of the other is ill-balanced—being half well-balanced and half ill-balanced, it would rightly be called the mean between what is wholly well-balanced and what is ill-balanced. And if these things are so—as indeed they are—we may now speak with confidence that there are nine differences of mixtures [kraiseis] in all: one well-balanced [eukraton], and eight not well-balanced, four simple—moist, dry, hot, and cold—and four composite: moist together with hot, dry together with hot, cold together with moist, and cold together with dry.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: Ἐν ἑκάστῃ δὲ τῶν εἰρημένων κράσεων τὸ μᾶλλόν τε καὶ τὸ ἦττον πάμπολυ, κατά τε τὰς ἁπλᾶς λεγομένας κράσεις, ἐπί τε τῆς ὅλης οὐσίας, ἤδη δὲ καὶ καθ’ ἕν ὁτιοῦν γένος. εἰ δή τις βούλεται διαγνωστικὸς εἶναι κράσεων, ἄρχεσθαι τούτῳ προσήκει τῆς γυμνασίας ἀπὸ τῶν καθ’ ἕκαστον γένος εὐκράτων τε καὶ μέσων φύσεων. ἐκείναις γὰρ τὰς ἄλλας παραβάλλων, ῥᾳδίως ἐξευρήσει τὸ πλεονάζον ἢ τὸ λεῖπον ἐν ἑκάστῃ. περὶ πρώτων οὖν ῥητέον τῶν ἁπλῶς λεγομένων εὐκράτων τε καὶ δυσκράτων, ἅς ἐπὶ πάσης οὐσίας γεννητῆς, οὐκ ἐπὶ ζώων μόνον, ἢ φυτῶν, ἔφαμεν ἐξετάζεσθαι. πάλιν δὲ κᾀνταῦθα τό γε τοσοῦτο χρὴ διαστείλασθαι περὶ ὀνομάτων, ὡς θερμὴ κρᾶσις ἄλλη μέν ἐστιν ἐνεργείᾳ, δυνάμει δ’ ἄλλη, καὶ ὡς δυνάμει ταῦτ’ εἶναι λέγομεν, ὅσα μήπω μέν ἐστιν ὃ λέγεται, ῥᾷστον δ’ αὐτοῖς γενέσθαι, φυσικήν τινα ἐπιτηδειότητα κεκτημένοις εἰς τὸ γενέσθαι. περὶ πρώτων οὖν διέλθωμεν τῶν ἐνεργείᾳ θερμῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν, καὶ ξηρῶν καὶ ὑγρῶν, ἀπὸ τῆς συμπάσης οὐσίας ἀρξάμενοι, κᾄπειτα μεταβῶμεν ἐπί τε τὰ ζῶα καὶ τὰ φυτά. τελέως γὰρ ἂν οὕτως ἡμῖν ἀπειργασμένον εἴη τὸ προτεθέν. ἐπειδὴ τοίνυν τὸ μέσον ἐν ἅπαντι γένει, καὶ μάλιστα κατὰ τὰς συμπάσας οὐσίας, ἐκ τῆς τῶν ἄκρων μίξεως γίνεται, χρὴ καὶ τὴν νόησιν αὐτοῦ καὶ τὴν διάγνωσιν ἐξ ἐκείνων συνίστασθαι. τὸ μὲν δὴ τῆς νοήσεως ῥᾶστον. ἀπὸ γὰρ τοῦ θερμοτάτου πάντων τῶν εἰς αἴσθησιν ἡκόντων, οἷον ἤτοι πυρὸς, ἤ τινος ὕδατος ἄκρως ζέοντος, ἐπὶ τὸ ψυχρότατον κατελθόντες ἁπάντων ὧν ἴσμεν, οἶον κρύσταλλον, ἢ χιόνα, νοήσαντές τι διάστημα, μέσον ἀκριβῶς τοῦτο τέμνομεν. οὕτω γὰρ ἐξευρήσομεν τῇ νοήσει τὸ σύμμετρον, ὅπερ ἑκατέρου τῶν ἄκρων ἴσον ἀπέχει.
paragraphs.claude_translation: In each of the aforementioned mixtures [kraseis], there is a very great degree of more and less, both in the so-called simple mixtures and in the whole substance, and indeed also in any single class. If, therefore, someone wishes to be skilled in diagnosing mixtures, it is appropriate for him to begin his training from the well-mixed and middle natures in each class. For by comparing the others to these, he will easily discover what is in excess or what is deficient in each. First, then, we must speak about those that are called simply well-mixed and ill-mixed, which we said are examined in all generated substance, not only in animals or plants. But again, even here, this much must be distinguished concerning terminology: that a hot mixture is one thing in actuality and another in potentiality, and that we say those things exist in potentiality which are not yet what they are called, but for which it is very easy to become so, possessing a certain natural aptitude for becoming. First, then, let us discuss those things that are actually hot and cold, and dry and moist, beginning from the whole of substance, and then let us proceed to animals and plants. For in this way what we have proposed will be completely accomplished by us. Since, therefore, the middle in every class, and especially in all substances, comes to be from the mixture of the extremes, it is necessary that both the conception and the diagnosis of it be established from those extremes. Now the matter of conception is very easy. For starting from the hottest of all things that come to perception—such as either fire or some water that is extremely boiling—and descending to the coldest of all things we know—such as ice or snow—and conceiving of a certain interval, we divide this precisely in the middle. For in this way we shall discover by conception the balanced [symmetron], which is equally distant from each of the extremes.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
In each of the mixtures just mentioned, there is a great range of “more” and “less,” both with respect to the so‑called simple mixtures and in regard to the whole substance, and indeed also in each particular kind. If someone wishes to be skilled at diagnosing mixtures, it is fitting that he begin his training from the well‑tempered and mean natures in each several kind. For by comparing the others with these, he will easily discover in each case what is in excess and what is deficient.

We must therefore speak first about the so‑called simply [i.e., absolutely] well‑tempered and ill‑tempered [mixtures; krasis], which we said are to be examined in every generated substance, not only in animals or in plants. And again here one must at least make this distinction concerning terms: a hot mixture is one thing in actuality [energeia] and another in potentiality [dynamis]; and we say that things are hot in potentiality when they are not yet what is asserted of them, but can most readily become so, having a certain natural aptitude for becoming so.

Let us then first discuss those that are hot and cold in actuality, and dry and moist, beginning from the whole compass of substance, and then pass on to animals and plants. For in this way the task we set before us would be fully worked out.

Since, then, the mean in every kind—and especially with respect to wholes of substance—arises from the mixture of extremes, our conception of it and our discernment of it must be constituted from those extremes. Conception, at any rate, is the easiest. Starting from the hottest of all things that come within sensation—for example, fire, or some water at a maximal boil—and descending to the coldest of all the

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ κατασκευάσαι πως αὐτὸ δυνάμεθα, τὸν ἴσον ὄγκον κρυστάλλου μίξαντες ὕδατι ζέοντι. τὸ γὰρ ἐξ ἀμφοῖν κραθὲν ἴσον ἑκατέρου τῶν ἄκρων ἀφέξει, τοῦ τε καίοντος καὶ τοῦ ναρκοῦντος διὰ ψύξιν. οὔκουν οὐδὲν ἔτι χαλεπόν ἐστι, τοῦ κραθέντος οὕτως ἁψαμένους, ἔχειν τὸ μέσον ἁπάσης οὐσίας ἐν τῇ κατὰ τὸ θερμόν τε καὶ ψυχρὸν ἀντιθέσει, καὶ μεμνῆσθαι τούτου, καὶ κρίνειν ἅπαντα τἄλλα καθάπερ τινὶ κανόνι παραβάλλοντας. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ξηρὰν γῆν, ἢ τέφραν, ἤ τι τοιοῦτο ἕτερον ἀκριβῶς αὐχμηρὸν ἀναδεύσας ὕδατι κατὰ τὸν ὄγκον ἴσῳ, τὸ μέσον ἐργάσῃ σῶμα τῆς κατὰ τὸν ξηρόν τε καὶ ὑγρὸν ἀντιθέσεως. οὔκουν οὐδὲ ἐνταῦθα χαλεπὸν οὐδὲν, ὄψει τε ἅμα καὶ ἁφῇ τὸ τοιοῦτο σῶμα διαγνόντας, παραθέσθαι τῇ μνήμῃ, καὶ τούτῳ κανόνι τε καὶ κριτηρίῳ χρῆσθαι πρὸς τὴν τῶν ἐλλειπόντων ἢ πλεοναζόντων ὑγρῶν καὶ ξηρῶν διάγνωσιν. ἔστω δὲ δηλονότι τὸ κρινόμενον σῶμα συμμέτρως θερμόν. εἰ γὰρ εἰς ἄκρον ἤτοι θερμότητος ἢ ψύξεως ἄγοιτο, τουτὶ τὸ μέσον ὑγροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ σῶμα φαντασίαν ἐνίοτε παρέξει ψευδῆ, καὶ δόξει ποτὲ μὲν ὑγρότερον εἶναι τοῦ συμμέτρου, ποτὲ δὲ ξηρότερον. εἰ μὲν γὰρ θερμανθείη πλέον, ἢ δεῖ, τηκόμενόν τε καὶ ῥέον, ὑγροτέρου φαντασίαν ἑαυτοῦ παρέξει. ψυχόμενον δὲ περαιτέρω τοῦ προσήκοντος, ἵσταταί τε καὶ πήγνυται, καὶ ἀκίνητον γίνεται, καὶ σκληρὸν ἁπτομένοις φαίνεται, κᾀκ τούτου φαντασίαν προβάλλει ψευδῆ ξηρότητος. εἰ δ’, ὥσπερ ὑγροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ μετέσχεν ἴσον, οὕτω καὶ θερμότητός τε καὶ ψύξεως εἴη μέσον, οὔτε σκληρὸν, οὔτε μαλακὸν ἁπτομένῳ φαίνεται τὸ τοιοῦτο σῶμα. τὸ μὲν οὖν ὅλα δι’ ὅλων αὐτὰ κεράσαι, τὸ θερμὸν λέγω καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν, καὶ τὸ ξηρὸν καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν, ἀδύνατον ἀνθρώπῳ. γῆ γὰρ ὑγρῷ φυραθεῖσα μέμικται μὲν, ὡς ἄν τῳ δόξειε, καὶ οὕτω κέκραται πᾶσα παντὶ, παράθεσις μήν ἐστι τὸ τοιοῦτο κατὰ σμικρὰ, καὶ οὐ δι’ ὅλων κρᾶσις, ἀλλὰ τὸ δι’ ὅλων ἄμφω κεράσαι θεοῦ καὶ φύσεως ἔργον. ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον, εἰ τὸ θερμὸν καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν ὅλα δι’ ὅλων ἀλλήλοις κεραννύοιτο. τὸ μέντοι παράθεσιν ἐργάσασθαι τοιαύτην, ὡς ἐκφεύγειν τὴν αἴσθησιν ἕκαστον τῶν ἁπλῶν σωμάτων, οὐ φύσεως τοῦτό γε μόνης ἢ θεοῦ τὸ ἔργον, ἀλλὰ καὶ ἡμέτερόν ἐστιν. οὐδὲ γὰρ χαλεπὸν ὑγροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ μέσον ἐργάσασθαι πηλὸν ἐκ τῆς τοιαύτης μίξεως· ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ. καί σοι φανεῖται τὸ τοιοῦτο σῶμα καὶ τῇ θερμότητι μὲν καὶ τῇ ψυχρότητι εὔκρατον, ἀλλὰ καὶ σκληρότητός τε καὶ μαλακότητος ἐν τῷ μέσῳ. τοιοῦτο δ’ ἐστὶ καὶ τὸ τῶν ἀνθρώπων δέρμα, μέσον ἀκριβῶς ἁπάντων τῶν ἐσχάτων, θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ, καὶ σκληροῦ καὶ μαλακοῦ, καὶ τούτου μάλιστα τὸ κατὰ τὴν χεῖρα. γνώμων γὰρ αὕτη πάντων ἔμελλεν ἔσεσθαι τῶν αἰσθητῶν, ὄργανον ἁπτικὸν ὑπὸ τῆς φύσεως ἀπεργασθεῖσα τῷ φρονιμωτάτῳ τῶν ζώων οἰκεῖον. ἴσον οὖν ἀπέχειν αὐτὴν ἐχρῆν ἁπάντων τῶν ἄκρων, θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ, καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ. καὶ δὴ καὶ γέγονεν ἐκ τῆς τούτων ἁπάντων ἰσομοιρίας, οὐ μιχθέντων μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ δι’ ὅλων ἀλλήλοις κερασθέντων, ὅπερ οὐκ ἔτ’ οὐδεὶς ἡμῶν ἐργάσασθαι δυνατός ἐστιν, ἀλλὰ φύσεως τὸ ἔργον.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
But we can also in a way contrive it, by mixing an equal bulk of crystal [ice] with boiling water. For what is blended from the two will keep an equal distance from each of the extremes, both from the burning and from the numbing by cold. Accordingly, there is no longer anything difficult about this: by touching what has been mixed in this way, we can have the mean [meson] of the whole substance in the opposition of hot and cold, keep this in mind, and judge all other things by comparing them, as with a kind of rule. And indeed, by taking dry earth, or ash, or some other such precisely parched thing, and stirring it with water in an equal bulk, you will produce a body that is the mean in the opposition of dry and moist. Here too there is nothing difficult: by discerning such a body at once by sight and by touch, store it up in memory, and use this as a rule and criterion for diagnosing the presence of liquids and dries [i.e., moisture and dryness] in defect or in excess.

Let the body being judged, then, plainly be moderately warm. For if it should be brought to the extreme of either heat or cold, this mean body of moist and dry will at times offer a false appearance, and will seem now to be moister than the due measure, now drier. For if it is heated more than it should be, as it melts and flows it will present an appearance of being moister than it is. But when it is cooled beyond what is fitting, it sets and congeals, becomes unmoving, and feels hard to the touch, and from this it projects a false appearance of dryness. If, however, just as it has shared equally in moist and dry, it were also at the mean of heat and cold, such a body would appear to the toucher neither hard nor soft.

Now to commingle them wholly through-and-through—the hot and the cold, and the dry and the moist—is impossible for a human being. For earth kneaded with water is, one might suppose, mixed and thus all blended with all; yet such a thing is juxtaposition [paráthesis] in small particles, not mixture through-and-through [krâsis di’ holôn]. To blend both through-and-through is the work of god and of nature—still more so if hot and cold themselves were to be mixed wholes through wholes. However, to produce such a juxtaposition that each of the simple bodies escapes perception—this is not the work of nature or god alone, but also ours. For it is not difficult to produce a clay that is the mean of moist and dry from such a mixture; and likewise of hot and cold. And such a body will appear to you well-tempered [eúkraton] in respect of heat and cold, and also midway in hardness and softness.

Such too is the skin of human beings, precisely the mean of all the extremes—of hot and cold, and hard and soft—and most of all that of the hand. For this was destined to be the gauge [gnṓmōn] of all sensible things, fashioned by nature as a tactile instrument fitting for the most intelligent of animals. Therefore it had to be equally distant from all the extremes—hot and cold, and dry and moist. And in fact it has come to be from an equal-sharing of all these, not merely by being mixed, but by being blended through-and-through with one another—which none of us is able to accomplish, but is the work of nature.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But we can also somehow construct this ourselves, by mixing an equal volume of crystal [ice] with boiling water. For what is blended from both will stand at an equal distance from each of the extremes, both from what burns and from what numbs through coldness. Therefore it is no longer at all difficult, having touched what has been blended in this way, to possess the middle point of all substance in the opposition between hot and cold, and to remember this, and to judge all other things by comparing them as if to some standard. And indeed, if you mix thoroughly dry earth, or ash, or some other such completely parched substance with water equal in volume, you will produce the middle body of the opposition between dry and wet. Therefore here too there is no difficulty, having distinguished such a body by both sight and touch simultaneously, to commit it to memory, and to use this as both a standard and criterion for the diagnosis of things deficient or excessive in wetness and dryness. But let the body being judged be moderately warm, obviously. For if it should be brought to an extreme of either heat or coldness, this middle body of wet and dry will sometimes present a false impression, and will seem at one time to be wetter than the moderate state, at another time drier. For if it should be heated more than necessary, melting and flowing, it will present an impression of being wetter than itself. But when cooled beyond what is appropriate, it both stands still and solidifies, and becomes immobile, and appears hard to those touching it, and from this projects a false impression of dryness. But if, just as it partook equally of wet and dry, so too it should be midway between heat and coldness, such a body appears to one touching it neither hard nor soft. Now to blend them completely through and through—I mean the hot and the cold, and the dry and the wet—is impossible for a human being. For earth kneaded with moisture is mixed, as it might seem to someone, and thus the whole is blended with the whole, yet such a thing is juxtaposition in small parts, and not a blending through and through, but to blend both completely through and through is the work of god and nature. Even more so, if the hot and the cold should be blended with each other completely through and through. However, to produce such a juxtaposition that each of the simple bodies escapes perception—this is not the work of nature or god alone, but is also ours. For it is not difficult to produce clay as a middle between wet and dry from such a mixture; and likewise also between hot and cold. And such a body will appear to you well-tempered both in heat and coldness, but also in the middle between hardness and softness. Such too is human skin, precisely midway between all the extremes—hot and cold, and hard and soft—and especially that on the hand. For this was destined to be the indicator of all perceptible things, having been fashioned by nature as a tactile organ appropriate to the most intelligent of living beings. Therefore it had to stand at an equal distance from all the extremes—hot and cold, and dry and wet. And indeed it has come to be from the equal share of all these, not only mixed but also blended with each other through and through, which none of us is any longer capable of producing, but is the work of nature.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ὅσα μὲν οὖν σκληρότερα τοῦ δέρματός ἐστι μόρια, καθάπερ ὀστᾶ, καὶ χόνδροι, καὶ κέρατα, καὶ τρίχες, ὄνυχές τε καὶ σύνδεσμοι, καὶ ὁπλαὶ, καὶ πλῆκτρα, πλέον ἐν τούτοις ἐστὶ τὸ ξηρόν· ὅσα δὲ μαλακώτερα, καθάπερ αἷμα, καὶ φλέγμα, καὶ πιμελὴ, καὶ στέαρ, καὶ μυελὸς, ἐγκέφαλός τε καὶ νωτιαῖος, ὑγροῦ πλέον ἐν τούτοις ἐστὶν, ἢ ξηροῦ. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ὅσῳ τὸ πάντων ξηρότατον ἐν ἀνθρώπῳ μόριον ὑπερβάλλει ξηρότητι τοῦ δέρματος, τοσούτῳ πάλιν ἀπολείπεται τὸ ὑγρότατον. ἔοικε δέ πως ὁ λόγος ἤδη τῶν χρησιμωτάτων αὐτῶν ἐφάπτεσθαι, καὶ διδάσκειν, ἅμα μὲν ὡς οὐχὶ ζώων μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων σωμάτων εὐκρατότατός ἐστιν ὁ ἄνθρωπος, ἅμα δ’ ὡς τῶν ἐν αὐτῷ μορίων τὸ τῆς χειρὸς δέρμα τὸ ἔσωθεν ἁπάσας ἐκπέφευγεν ἀκριβῶς τὰς ὑπερβολάς. ἐπιστήσαντες οὖν πάλιν ἐνταῦθα τὸν λόγον ἐπισκεψώμεθα, τίς ἄριστα πάντων κέκραται ἄνθρωπος, ὃν καὶ τῆς ὅλης μὲν οὐσίας, ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον ἀνθρώπων καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ζώων ἐν τῷ μέσῳ χρὴ τάξαντας, καθάπερ τινὰ κανόνα καὶ γνώμονα, τοὺς ἄλλους ἅπαντας τούτῳ παραβάλλοντας, θερμοὺς καὶ ψυχροὺς, καὶ ξηροὺς καὶ ὑγροὺς ὀνομάζειν. δεῖ δὲ συνδραμεῖν ἐς ταὐτὸν ἐπὶ τοῦδε πολλὰ γνωρίσματα. καὶ γὰρ ὡς πρὸς τὴν ὅλην οὐσίαν ἐξετάζοντι μέσον φαίνεσθαι χρὴ τὸν τοιοῦτον, ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον ὡς πρὸς ἀνθρώπους τε καὶ ζῶα. τὰ μὲν οὖν ἁπάσης τῆς οὐσίας γνωρίσματα κοινὰ προείρηται· τὰ δ’ ὡς ἐν ζώων εἴδεσιν ἐνεργείας τελειότητι κρίνεται τῆς ἑκάστῳ πρεπούσης. πρέπει δ’ ἀνθρώπῳ μὲν εἶναι σοφωτάτῳ, κυνὶ δὲ πρᾳοτάτῳ τε ἅμα καὶ ἀλκιμωτάτῳ, λέοντι δὲ ἀλκιμωτάτῳ μόνον, ὥσπερ γε καὶ προβάτῳ πρᾳοτάτω. καὶ μέν με καὶ ὡς τὰς τοῦ σώματος ἐνεργείας οἰκείας εἶναι χρὴ τῷ τῆς ψυχῆς ἤθει, δέδεικται μὲν καὶ πρὸς Ἀριστοτέλους ἐν τοῖς περὶ ζώων μορίων· λέλεκται δὲ καὶ πρὸς ἡμῶν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν οὐδὲν ἦττον. ἡ μὲν δὴ μέθοδος ἥδε. τὸ δ’ ἀσκῆσαι γνωρίζειν ἑτοίμως ἐν ἑκάστῳ γένει ζώου καὶ κατὰ τὰ σύμπαντα τὸ μέσον, οὐ τοῦ τυχόντος ἀνδρὸς, ἀλλ’ ἐσχάτως ἐστὶ φιλοπόνου, καὶ διὰ μακρᾶς ἐμπειρίας καὶ πολλῆς γνώσεως ἁπάντων τῶν κατὰ μέρος ἐξευρίσκειν δυναμένου τὸ μέσον. οὕτω γοῦν καὶ πλάσται, καὶ γραφεῖς, ἀνδριαντοποιοί τε καὶ ὅλως ἀγαλματοποιοὶ τὰ κάλλιστα γράφουσί τε καὶ πλάττουσι καθ’ ἕκαστον εἶδος, οἶον ἄνθρωπον εὐμορφότατον, ἢ ἵππον, ἢ βοῦν, ἢ λέοντα, τὸ μέσον ἐν ἐκείνῳ τῷ γένει σκοποῦντες. καί πού τις ἀνδριὰς ἐπαινεῖται, Πολυκλείτου κανὼν ὀνομαζόμενος, ἐκ τοῦ πάντων τῶν μορίων ἀκριβῆ τὴν πρὸς ἄλληλα συμμετρίαν ἔχειν ὀνόματος τοιούτου τυχών. ἔστι μὲν οὖν ἐπιπλέον, ὃν νῦν ἡμεῖς ἐζητοῦμεν, ἢ ὁ κανὼν οὗτος. οὐ μόνον γὰρ ὑγρότητός τε καὶ ξηρότητος ἐν τῷ μέσῳ καθέστηκεν ὁ οὕτως εὔσαρκος ἄνθρωπος, ἀλλὰ καὶ διαπλάσεως ἀρίστης τετύχηκεν, ἴσως μὲν ἑπομένης τῇ τῶν τεσσάρων στοιχείων εὐκρασίᾳ, τάχα δέ τινα θειοτέραν ἀρχὴν ἑτέραν ἐχούσης ἄνωθεν. ἀλλὰ τό γε πάντως εὔκρατον εἶναι τὸν τοιοῦτον ἐξ ἀνάγκης ὑπάρχει· τὸ γὰρ ἐν εὐσαρκίᾳ σύμμετρον εὐκρασίας ἐστὶν ἔγγονον. εὐθὺς δ’ ὑπάρχει τῷ τοιούτῳ σώματι, καὶ ταῖς ἐνεργείαις ἄριστα διακεῖσθαι, καὶ σκληρότητός τε καὶ μαλακότητος ἔχειν μετρίως, θερμότητός τε καὶ ψυχρότητος· καὶ ταῦθ’ ὑπάρχειν ἅπαντα τῷ δέρματι, καὶ τούτῳ μάλιστα τῷ τῆς χειρὸς ἐντὸς, ὅταν μηδένα τύλον ἔχῃ τοιοῦτον, οἷον τοῖς ἐρέττουσί τε καὶ σκάπτουσι γίνεται. διττῆς γὰρ ἕνεκα χρείας τῶν χειρῶν γεγενημένων, ἁφῆς καὶ ἀντιλήψεως, αἱ μαλακαὶ μὲν εἰς τὴν τῆς ἁφῆς ἀκρίβειαν, αἱ σκληραὶ δὲ εἰς τὴν τῆς ἀντιλήψεως ἰσχὺν ἐπιτηδειότεραι. καὶ δὴ καὶ τὸ δέρμα τὸ μέσον οὐ μόνον ἁπάντων ἀνθρωπίνων μορίων, ἀλλὰ καὶ τῆς ὅλης οὐσίας, καὶ πάντων τῶν ἐν γενέσει καὶ φθορᾷ σωμάτων, οὐ τὸ τετυλωμένον ἐστὶ καὶ σκληρὸν καὶ λιθῶδες, ἀλλὰ τὸ κατὰ φύσιν ἔχον, ᾧ δὴ καὶ μάλιστά φαμεν ἀκριβοῦσθαι τὴν ἁφήν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Now then, those parts that are harder than the skin, such as bones, cartilages, horns, hairs, nails, ligaments, hooves, and spurs—in these the dry element predominates; but those that are softer, such as blood, phlegm, fat, suet, marrow, brain, and spinal cord—in these the moist element predominates more than the dry. And indeed, by as much as the driest part in a human being exceeds the skin in dryness, by so much in turn does the moistest part fall short of it. The argument now seems somehow to be touching upon the most useful matters themselves, and to be teaching, on the one hand, that man is the most well-tempered not only of animals but of all other bodies, and on the other hand, that among the parts in him, the inner skin of the hand has precisely escaped all extremes. Therefore, pausing again at this point in our argument, let us examine what sort of human being is best tempered of all—one whom we must place in the middle both of all substance and, even more so, of humans and other animals, and using him as a kind of standard and rule, comparing all others to him, we should call them hot and cold, and dry and moist. Many characteristics must converge together in such a person. For when examined in relation to all substance, such a person must appear to be in the middle, and even more so in relation to humans and animals. Now the characteristics of all substance have been stated previously in common; but those characteristics as they exist among species of animals are judged by the perfection of the activity appropriate to each. It is appropriate for a human being to be most wise, for a dog to be both most gentle and most courageous, for a lion to be most courageous only, just as for a sheep to be most gentle. And indeed that the activities of the body must be suited to the character of the soul has been demonstrated both by Aristotle in his works on the parts of animals, and has been discussed by us concerning these matters no less. This, then, is the method. But to train oneself to recognize readily in each genus of animal, and in all things generally, what is the mean—this is not the work of just any man, but of one who is extremely industrious and capable of discovering the mean through long experience and extensive knowledge of all particulars. Thus indeed sculptors, painters, statue-makers, and image-makers in general paint and sculpt the most beautiful examples in each species—for instance, the most well-formed human, or horse, or ox, or lion—by aiming at the mean in that genus. And a certain statue is praised, called Polyclitus's Canon, having received such a name from the fact that all its parts have precise symmetry with one another. Now the person we are now seeking is something more than this canon. For a human being who is well-fleshed in this way stands not only in the middle of moisture and dryness, but has also obtained the best formation—perhaps following from the good temperament of the four elements, but perhaps having some other more divine principle from above. But in any case, it necessarily follows that such a person is well-tempered; for the proper proportion in good flesh is the offspring of good temperament. Immediately such a body is also best disposed in its activities, and possesses moderately both hardness and softness, and heat and cold; and all these qualities belong to the skin, and especially to the inner skin of the hand, whenever it has no such callus as develops in those who row and dig. For since the hands have been made for a double purpose—touch and grasping—soft hands are more suitable for the precision of touch, while hard ones are more suitable for the strength of grasping. And indeed the skin that is the mean, not only of all human parts but also of all substance and all bodies subject to generation and corruption, is not the calloused, hard, and stone-like skin, but that which is in its natural state, by which we say that touch is especially perfected.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, in all the parts that are harder than the skin—such as bones, and cartilages, and horns, and hairs, and nails, and ligaments, and armors [protective structures], and striking-parts [offensive structures]—the dry element is predominant; whereas in the softer parts—such as blood, and phlegm, and fat [pimelē], and suet [stear], and marrow, and the brain and spinal cord—the moist element is more abundant than the dry. And indeed, by just as much as the very driest part in a human being exceeds the skin in dryness, by so much again does the very moistest fall short of it. The argument now seems in a way to be touching upon their most useful features, and to be teaching at once that the human being is the most well-tempered [best balanced in qualities] not only among animals but among all other bodies as well, and also that, among the parts within him, the inner skin of the hand has precisely escaped every excess to the utmost degree. Let us therefore halt our discourse here again and inquire which human being is the best mixed of all—one whom we ought, after setting him in the middle both of the whole of substance and, even more, of human beings and the other animals, to use as a kind of rule and measuring-rod, comparing all the rest to him and naming them hot and cold, and dry and moist. Many marks must converge upon the same point for this: for the sort of person we examine must appear to be in the middle not only with reference to the whole of substance, but even more with reference to human beings and animals. Now the common marks concerning the whole of substance have been stated beforehand; but as regards animals, the criterion is the perfection of the activities appropriate to each. It befits a human being to be the most wise, a dog to be at once the gentlest and the most courageous, a lion to be the most courageous only, and a sheep the gentlest. Moreover, that the bodily activities ought to be fitting to the character of the soul has been shown by Aristotle in the Parts of Animals, and we too have spoken about these matters no less. Such, then, is the method. But to be trained to recognize readily, both in each animal kind and taken universally, the mean—not for just any man, but for one of extreme diligence, who through long experience and much knowledge of particulars is able to discover the mean—this is the task. Thus sculptors and painters, makers of statues and, in general, makers of images, represent and model the most beautiful example in each species—say, the most well-formed human being, or horse, or ox, or lion—by looking to the mean within that genus. And there is, I suppose, a certain statue that is praised, called the Canon of Polycleitus, which received such a name from possessing the exact commensurability of all the parts with one another. What we are now seeking goes beyond even that canon. For the well-fleshed man is set in the mean not only in respect of moistness and dryness, but he has also attained the best formation—perhaps as a consequence of the well-balanced mixture of the four elements, though perhaps it has some other, more divine principle from above. In any case, it necessarily belongs to such a person to be well-tempered; for symmetry within good flesh is born from good mixture. And immediately it belongs to such a body to be excellently disposed also for activities, and to possess a measured degree of both hardness and softness, and of heat and cold; and all these qualities belong to the skin, most of all to the inner skin of the hand [the palm], whenever it has no callus such as arises in those who dig and hoe. For since the hands have come to be for a twofold use—touch and grasping—the soft are more suitable for accuracy of touch, while the hard are more suitable for strength in grasping. Accordingly, the skin that is in the mean—not only among all human parts, but also within the whole of substance and among all bodies subject to coming-to-be and passing-away—is not the calloused and hard and stony skin, but that which is naturally constituted, in which, indeed, we say touch is most precise.

paragraphs.content: ὅτι μὲν οὖν σκληρότητός τε καὶ μαλακότητος ἐν τῷ μέσῳ καθέστηκεν ἁπάντων μορίων, ἱκανῶς ἐναργές· ὅτι δὲ καὶ θερμότητος καὶ ψυχρότητος, ἐκ τῆς οὐσίας ἂν αὐτοῦ μάλιστα καταμάθοις. ἔστι γὰρ οἷον ἔναιμόν τι νεῦρον, ἀκριβῶς μέσον ὑπάρχον νεύρου τε καὶ σαρκὸς, ὡς εἰ καὶ κραθέντων ἀμφοῖν ἐγένετο. ἀλλὰ νεῦρον μὲν ἅπαν ἄναιμόν τε καὶ ψυχρόν· σὰρξ δὲ πολύαιμός τε καὶ θερμή· μέσον δ’ ἀμφοῖν τὸ δέρμα, μήτ’ ἄναιμον τὸ πάμπαν, ὡς νεῦρον, ἀλλὰ μηδὲ πολύαιμον, ὡς ἡ σὰρξ, γενόμενον. εἰ δὴ τοῦτο κανόνα τε καὶ οἷον κριτήριον ἁπάντων τῶν τοῦ ζώου μορίων προστησάμενος ἐξετάζεις τε καὶ παραβάλλεις αὐτῷ τἄλλα, τὰς ὀκτὼ διαφορὰς εὑρήσεις τῆς δυσκρασίας ἐν αὐτοῖς. καὶ δὴ καὶ κατὰ μέρος δίειμί σοι περὶ πάντων ἑξῆς. φλέγμα μὲν οὖν ὑγρότατόν ἐστι καὶ ψυχρότατον, αἷμα δὲ θερμότατον, ἀλλ’ οὐχ οὕτως ὑγρὸν, ὡς τὸ φλέγμα. θρὶξ δὲ ξηροτάτη τε καὶ ψυχροτάτη· ἧττον δὲ αὐτῆς ὀστοῦν ψυχρόν ἐστι καὶ ξηρὸν, καὶ τοῦδε χόνδρος ἧττον ξηρός. ἐφεξῆς δὲ χόνδρῳ σύνδεσμος, καὶ ὃν χονδροσύνδεσμον ὀνομάζουσιν, ἔπειτα τένων, εἶθ’ ὑμὴν, καὶ ἀρτηρία, καὶ φλὲψ, αὐτὰ δηλονότι τὰ σώματα τῶν ἀγγείων, εἶθ’ ὅσα νεῦρα σκληρά. τὰ δὲ μαλακὰ νεῦρα κατὰ τὴν τοῦ δέρματος ὑπάρχει φύσιν ἐν τῇ καθ’ ὑγρότητά τε καὶ ξηρότητα μεσότητι. κατὰ γὰρ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν οὐκ ἔτι μέσον θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ τὸ νεῦρον μαλακὸν, ἀλλὰ τοσοῦτον ἀπολείπεται θερμότητος, ὅσον καὶ αἵματος. οὕτω δὲ καὶ τἄλλα σύμπαντα τὰ πρόσθεν εἰρημένα τοσούτῳ ψυχρότερα δέρματος, ὅσῳ καὶ ἀναιμότερα. καὶ οἵ γε χιτῶνες αὐτοὶ τῶν ἐναιμοτάτων ἀγγείων, ἀρτηρίας λέγω καὶ φλεβὸς, ἄναιμοί τέ εἰσι καὶ ψυχροὶ τῇ φύσει· τῇ γειτνιάσει δὲ τοῦ αἵματος θερμαίνονται, καὶ εἰς μέσην ἀφικνοῦνται κατάστασιν κράσεως. τὸ δὲ αἷμα πάλιν αὐτὸ παρὰ τῆς καρδίας ἔχει τὴν θερμασίαν. φύσει γὰρ ἐκεῖνο τὸ σπλάγχνον ἁπάντων ἐστὶ τῶν τοῦ ζώου μορίων ἐναιμότατόν τε ἅμα καὶ θερμότατον· ἐφεξῆς δ’ αὐτῷ τὸ ἧπαρ.
paragraphs.claude_translation: That skin stands in the middle of all parts with respect to hardness and softness is sufficiently evident; but that it also stands midway between heat and cold, you would learn best from its substance. For it is like a certain blood-containing sinew, being precisely intermediate between sinew and flesh, as if it came to be from a mixture of both. But every sinew is bloodless and cold; flesh, however, is full of blood and hot; and skin is intermediate between both, having become neither completely bloodless like sinew, nor full of blood like flesh. If therefore you establish this as a standard and as it were a criterion of all the parts of the animal, and examine and compare the other parts to it, you will find the eight differences of dyskrasia [imbalance of qualities] in them. And indeed I shall go through all of them in detail for you in order. Phlegm, then, is most moist and most cold, while blood is most hot, but not as moist as phlegm. Hair is most dry and most cold; bone is less cold and dry than it, and cartilage is less dry than bone. Next after cartilage comes ligament, and what they call chondro-ligament [cartilaginous ligament], then tendon, then membrane, and artery, and vein—obviously the bodies of the vessels themselves—then all the hard nerves. The soft nerves exist according to the nature of skin in the intermediate state with respect to moisture and dryness. For according to the other opposition, the soft nerve is no longer intermediate between hot and cold, but falls short of heat by as much as it also falls short of blood. Similarly also all the other parts mentioned previously are colder than skin by as much as they are more bloodless. And indeed the coats themselves of the most blood-filled vessels—I mean the artery and vein—are bloodless and cold by nature; but they are heated by their proximity to the blood, and arrive at an intermediate state of mixture. The blood itself in turn has its heat from the heart. For that organ by nature is of all the parts of the animal both most full of blood and most hot at the same time; and next after it comes the liver.
paragraphs.openai_translation: That the skin stands, with respect to hardness and softness, in the middle among all the parts is sufficiently evident; and that it is also in the middle between heat and cold you would best perceive from its substance. For it is, as it were, a blood-containing nerve, precisely a mean between nerve and flesh, as if it had come to be from a mixture of both. But

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἡ μὲν καρδία βραχὺ δέρματος ἀποδεῖ σκληρότητι, τὸ δ’ ἧπαρ πολύ. καὶ τοίνυν ὑγροτέρα τοσούτῳ δέρματός ἐστιν, ὅσῳ μαλακωτέρα. καὶ μὴν δὴ καὶ σὰρξ ὑγροτέρα δέρματος· ἀλλ’ αὕτη μὲν καὶ θερμοτέρα. νωτιαῖος δὲ ὑγρότερος μὲν, ἀλλὰ καὶ ψυχρότερος· καὶ τοῦδε μᾶλλον ἐγκέφαλος υγρότερος, ἔτι δὲ τούτου μᾶλλον πιμελή, καὶ ἡ πῆξις αὐτῆς, διὰ τὴν τῶν ὑμένων γειτνίασιν· ἐλαίῳ γὰρ ἔοικε παχεῖ, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο πήγνυται, ψυχροῖς καὶ ἀναίμοις ὁμιλοῦσα μορίοις. οὔτε δ’ ἥπατι περιπήγνυσθαι πιμελὴν, οὔτ’ ἀρτηρίαις καὶ φλεψὶν, οὔτε καρδίᾳ δυνατὸν, ἀλλ’ οὐδ’ ἄλλῳ τινὶ θερμῷ πάνυ μορίῳ. διότι δὲ πέπηγε πάνυ ψυχρῷ, διὰ τοῦτο χεῖται θερμαινομένη τοῖς ἄλλοις ὁμοίως πεπηγόσιν. οὐ μὴν ἐγκέφαλός γε θερμαινόμενος χεῖται, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο ἦττον ὑγρός ἐστι πιμελῆς. ἧττον δ’ ὑγρὰ πιμελῆς ἐστι καὶ ἡ τοῦ πνεύμονος σὰρξ, οὐδὲ γὰρ αὕτη χεῖται θερμαινομένη. πολὺ δ’ ἔτι μᾶλλον ἡ τοῦ σπληνός τε καὶ τῶν νεφρῶν ἧττόν ἐστιν ὑγρὰ πιμελῆς. ἅπαντα μέντοι ταῦτα δέρματός ἐστιν ὑγρότερα. τὰς δὲ τούτων ἀποδείξεις ἐν τῷ μεταξὺ λόγῳ διέξειμι· καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ὅσα λείπει τῇ συμπάσῃ περὶ κράσεων πραγματείᾳ διὰ τῶν ἐφεξῆς δυοῖν ὑπομνημάτων εἰρήσεται.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But the heart falls short of skin in hardness by only a little, while the liver falls short by much. And indeed, it is moister than skin by as much as it is softer. And furthermore, flesh is moister than skin; but this is also warmer. The spinal marrow is moister, but also colder; and the brain is moister than this, and fat is still moister than the brain, and its solidification occurs because of the proximity of the membranes; for it resembles thick oil, and for this reason it solidifies, being in contact with cold and bloodless parts. But it is not possible for fat to solidify around the liver, nor around the arteries and veins, nor around the heart, nor indeed around any other very warm part. And because it has solidified in a very cold place, for this reason when heated it melts just like other solidified substances. The brain, however, does not melt when heated, and for this reason it is less moist than fat. The flesh of the lung is also less moist than fat, for this too does not melt when heated. And still much more so, the flesh of the spleen and the kidneys is less moist than fat. All of these, however, are moister than skin. I shall go through the demonstrations of these matters in the intermediate treatise; and indeed whatever remains for the complete work on mixtures [temperaments] will be discussed in the next two books.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But the heart falls short of the skin by a little in hardness, whereas the liver by much. Accordingly, each is so much the moister than the skin as it is the softer. And indeed flesh is moister than skin; and this [flesh] is also warmer. The spinal marrow, however, is moister, but also colder; and the brain is still moister than this, and more so than it is the fat [pimelē], as well as its coagulation, because of its proximity to the membranes [hymenes]. For it is like thick oil, and for this reason it congeals when it associates with parts that are cold and bloodless. It is not possible for fat to congeal around the liver, or around the arteries and veins, or around the heart, nor indeed around any other part that is very warm. But because it has congealed around something very cold, for this reason, when warmed, it melts,
