paragraphs.content: ὀπὸν γοῦν, ἤτοι τὸν Κυρηναικὸν, ἢ τὸν Μηδικὸν, ἢ τὸν Παρθικὸν, αὐτὸν καθ’ αὑτὸν οὐκ ἔστιν ἀλύπως λαβεῖν· ἀλλ’ εἰ παντελῶς ὀλίγος, ἢ σὺν ἄλλοις ἐν καιρῷ τῷ προσήκοντι ληφθείη, μεγάλως ὠφελεῖ. ταύτῃ μὲν οὖν, ὅσα θερμαίνει τὸ σῶμα, μεταβολῆς ἀρχὴν ἐν αὐτῷ λαβόντα, καθότι πρόσθεν ἐῤῥέθη, πάλιν ἀντιθερμαίνειν αὐτὸ πέφυκεν· ὅσα δὲ ψύχει, καθάπερ ὀπὸς μήκωνος, οὐ μεταβάλλεται πρὸς τοῦ σώματος οὐδ’ ἐπ’ ὀλίγον, ἀλλ’ εὐθὺς αὐτὸ νικᾷ καὶ μεταβάλλει, κᾂν εἰ θερμῄνας αὐτὰ δοίης. ἔστι γὰρ ἡ σφῶν αὐτῶν φύσις ψυχρὰ, καθότι καὶ τὸ ὕδωρ. ὀρθῶς οὖν καὶ τοῦτο σὺν πολλοῖς ἄλλοις ὑπ’ Ἀριστοτέλους εἴρηται, τὸ τῶν θερμῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν καὶ ξηρῶν καὶ ὑγρῶν σωμάτων τὰ μὲν εἶναι καθ’ αὑτὰ τοιαῦτα, τὰ δὲ κατὰ συμβεβηκός. οἷον καὶ τὸ ὕδωρ καθ’ αὑτὸ μὲν ψυχρὸν, κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς δέ ποτε θερμόν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: At any rate, juice—whether the Cyrenaic, the Median, or the Parthian—cannot be taken by itself without distress; but if taken in very small quantity, or with other things at the appropriate time, it is greatly beneficial. In this way, then, those things that heat the body, having received the beginning of change within it, as was stated earlier, are naturally disposed to heat it in turn; but those things that cool, like poppy juice, are not changed by the body even slightly, but immediately overcome and change it, even if you should give them after heating them. For their own nature is cold, just as water is. Correctly, therefore, this too has been stated by Aristotle along with many other things: that of hot and cold and dry and moist bodies, some are such in themselves, while others are so accidentally. For example, water is cold in itself, but sometimes hot accidentally.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Opium, at any rate—whether the Cyrenaic, the Median, or the Parthian—cannot be taken safely by itself; but if it is taken in a very small quantity, or together with other substances at the appropriate time, it is very beneficial. Thus, whatever warms the body, once it has received a beginning of alteration within it, as was said before, is naturally disposed to heat it back again; whereas whatever cools, like the juice of the poppy [opium], is not altered by the body even in the least, but at once overpowers it and alters it, even if you administer them after warming. For their own nature is cold, just as water is. Accordingly, and rightly, Aristotle has said this among many other things: that of bodies which are hot and cold and dry and moist, some are such in themselves [kath’ hauta], others only incidentally [kata symbebekos]. For example, water is cold in itself, but at times incidentally warm.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἡ μὲν ἐπίκτητος αὐτοῦ θερμασία ταχέως ἀπόλλυται, μένει δ’ ἡ σύμφυτος ψυχρότης. ὡς οὖν ὕδωρ θερμὸν ἐπιβληθὲν φλογὶ, κατασβέννυσιν αὐτὴν, οὕτω καὶ τὸ μηκώνειον εἰ καὶ ὅτι μάλιστα θερμῄνας δοίης, ἀποψύξεις τε τὴν ἐν τοῖς ζώοις θερμασίαν, καὶ κίνδυνον ἐπάξεις θανάτου. πάντα οὖν τὰ τοιαῦτα φάρμακα, βραχέα τε διδόμενα καὶ σὺν τοῖς κολάζειν αὐτῶν τὸ σφοδρὸν τῆς ψύξεως δυναμένοις, ἔστιν ὅτε χρείαν τινὰ παρέχει τοῖς σώμασιν ἡμῶν, ὡς ἐν τοῖς περὶ φαρμάκων εἰρήσεται. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ τὸ διὰ τῶν κανθαρίδων φάρμακον ἱκανῶς ὀνίνησι τοὺς ὑδερικοὺς, καίτοι τοὐπίπαν ἑλκοῖ τὴν κύστιν ἡ κανθαρίς· ἀλλ’ ἐπειδὰν ὑπό τε τῶν μιχθέντων αὐτῇ κολασθῇ, καὶ σώματι προσάγηται παμπόλλην ὑγρότητα περιέχοντι, κενοῖ διὰ τῶν οὔρων αὐτήν. μάλιστα οὖν χρὴ προσέχειν τὸν νοῦν ἐν ἅπασι τοῖς δυνάμει θερμοῖς ἢ ψυχροῖς εἶναι λεγομένοις, εἴτε τῆς φύσεώς ἐστι τῶν τρέφειν δυναμένων, εἴτε μόνην ἀφορμὴν ἀλλοιώσεως λαμβάνοντα, κᾄπειτα κατὰ τὴν οἰκείαν φύσιν ἀλλοιούμενα, διατίθησί πως τὸ σῶμα, καὶ τρίτον ἐπὶ τούτοις, εἰ μηδ’ ὅλως ἀλλοιοῦται πρὸς αὐτοῦ κατὰ μηδέν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ἐκ τοῦ γένους εἴη τῶν τρεφόντων, εἰ μὲν κρατηθείη, θερμαίνει, μὴ κρατηθέντα δὲ, ψύχει· εἰ δὲ τῶν ἐπ’ ὀλίγον ποσὸν ἀλλοιουμένων, θερμαίνει πάντως· εἰ δὲ τῶν μηδ’ ὅλως, ψύχει μάλιστα.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But its acquired heat is quickly lost, while its innate coldness remains. Therefore, just as hot water thrown upon a flame extinguishes it, so too with poppy juice: even if you give it after heating it as much as possible, you will cool the heat in living creatures and bring upon them the danger of death. All such drugs, therefore, when given in small amounts and together with things capable of tempering their excessive coldness, sometimes provide a certain benefit to our bodies, as will be discussed in the works on drugs. For indeed the drug made from Spanish flies [cantharides] sufficiently benefits those suffering from dropsy [edema], although generally the Spanish fly ulcerates the bladder; but when it has been tempered by the things mixed with it, and is applied to a body containing a very great amount of fluid, it evacuates this through the urine. Therefore, one must pay attention most of all in all things said to be hot or cold in potency, whether they are of the nature of things capable of nourishing, or whether, taking only an initial impulse of alteration and then being altered according to their own nature, they affect the body in some way, and thirdly in addition to these, whether they are not altered by it at all in any respect. For if it should be from the class of nourishing things, if it is mastered [by the body], it heats, but if not mastered, it cools; but if it is from those things altered to a small degree, it heats in every case; but if from those things not altered at all, it cools most of all.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But its acquired heat is quickly lost, while its innate coldness remains. Thus, just as hot water, when thrown on a flame, puts it out, so too opium [mekonion], even if you administer it after heating it as much as possible, will chill the heat in living beings and bring on the danger of death. Therefore all such drugs, when given in small doses and together with agents able to check the vehemence of their coldness, sometimes provide some benefit to our bodies, as will be stated in the works On Drugs. For indeed the remedy made with cantharides [blister beetles] benefits hydropic patients [those with dropsy] well enough, although as a rule cantharis ulcerates the bladder; but when it is checked by the ingredients mixed with it, and is applied to a body containing a very great amount of moisture, it evacuates this through the urine. One must therefore pay the closest attention, in all things said to be potentially hot or cold, to whether they belong by nature to the class capable of nourishing [i.e., foods], or whether, merely taking the occasion for an alteration, they then, being altered in accordance with their own nature, dispose the body in some way, and, thirdly, in addition to these, whether they are not altered by the body at all in any respect. For if it belongs to the genus of nutritive things, then, if it is mastered [assimilated], it warms, but if not mastered, it cools; if it is of those altered only to a small degree, it warms in any case; but if it is of those not altered at all, it cools most of all.
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
But its acquired heat is quickly destroyed, while its innate coldness remains. Therefore, just as hot water thrown upon a flame extinguishes it, so too with poppy juice [opium]: even if you were to heat it as much as possible before administering it, you will cool the heat in living creatures and bring on the risk of death. All such drugs, therefore, when given in small amounts and along with substances capable of checking [or tempering] their excessive coldness, are sometimes of some use to our bodies, as will be discussed in my work *On Drugs*. For indeed, the drug made from cantharides [Spanish fly] is of considerable help to those with dropsy, even though cantharides generally ulcerates the bladder. But when its power is checked by the substances mixed with it, and it is applied to a body containing a great deal of moisture, it evacuates that moisture through the urine.

Therefore, one must pay the closest attention to all substances said to be potentially [δυνάμει] hot or cold, considering whether it belongs to the nature of things that can provide nourishment; or whether, by providing only a starting point for alteration and then being altered according to its own nature, it affects the body in a certain way; and thirdly, whether it is not altered by the body at all. For if it is of the class of nourishing substances, it heats if it is mastered [by the body's innate heat], but cools if it is not. If it is one of those substances that are altered only to a small degree, it always heats. And if it is one of those that are not altered at all, it cools most powerfully.

paragraphs.content: Προσέχειν δὲ, ὡς εἴρηται, μάλιστα καὶ διορίζεσθαι τὰ καθ’ ἑαυτὰ τῶν κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς, οὐκ ἐπὶ θερμῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν μόνον, ἀλλ’ οὐδὲν ἧττον αὐτῶν ἐφ’ ὑγρῶν τε καὶ ξηρῶν. ἔνια γὰρ τῶν τοιούτων, ξηρὰ ταῖς οὐσίαις ὑπάρχοντα, πολλῷ θερμῷ τακέντα, φαντασίαν ὑγρότητος ἔλαβεν, ὡς χαλκὸς καὶ σίδηρος· ἢ καθ’ ἑαυτὰ μέν ἐστιν ὑγρὰ, καθάπερ ὁ κρύσταλλος, ἀκράτῳ δὲ ψύξει πλησιάζοντα, ξηρὰ φαίνεται. χρὴ τοίνυν τούτων ἁπάντων τὴν κρίσιν οὐχ ἁπλῶς ποιεῖσθαι, καθότι κᾀν τοῖς ἔμπροσθεν ἐλέγομεν, ἀλλὰ μετὰ τοῦ συνεπισκέπτεσθαι, πῶς ἔχει θερμότητος ἢ ψυχρότητος. εἰ μὲν γὰρ, ὀλίγης μετέχοντα θερμότητος, ὅμως καὶ ὑγρὰ φαίνοιτο, διὰ τὴν οἰκείαν φύσιν ἐστὶ τοιαῦτα, κᾂν εἰ μετὰ δαψιλοῦς θερμασίας, ξηρά. τὰ δ’ ἤτοι ῥέοντα μετὰ θερμότητος ζεούσης, ἢ πεπηγότα διὰ ψύξιν ἄκρατον, οὐ καθ’ ἑαυτὰ νομίζειν εἶναι τὰ μὲν ὑγρὰ, τὰ δὲ ξηρά. ταύτῃ τε οὖν διαιρεῖσθαι τὰ καθ’ ἑαυτὰ τῶν κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς, ἀναφέροντά τε πρὸς. αὐτὰ ταῦτα τὴν κρίσιν οὕτω ποιεῖσθαι τῶν δυνάμει θερμῶν, ἢ ψυχρῶν, ἢ ξηρῶν, ἢ ὑγρῶν. οὐ γὰρ πρὸς τὸ κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς, ἀλλὰ πρὸς τὸ καθ’ ἑαυτὸ χρὴ κρίνεσθαι τὸ δυνάμει. κοινὴ δ’ ἐπὶ πάντων ἡ κρίσις καὶ μία τὸ τάχος τῆς ἀλλοιώσεως. ὁμωνύμως δὲ λεγομένου τοῦ θερμοῦ, καὶ ψυχροῦ, καὶ ξηροῦ, καὶ ὑγροῦ· τὰ μὲν γὰρ κατ’ ἐπικράτησιν οὕτως ὀνομάζεται, τὰ δ’ ὡς ἄκραν ἔχοντα ἧς παρονομάζεται ποιότητος· εἰς ὁπότερον αὐτῶν ἑτοίμως μεθίσταται τὸ κρινόμενον, ἔσται δυνάμει τοιοῦτο. ἔλαιον μὲν γάρ ἐστι δυνάμει θερμὸν, ὅτι ῥᾳδίως φλὸξ γίνεται. κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ ῥητίνη, καὶ ἄσφαλτος, καὶ πίττα. οἶνος δὲ, διότι ῥᾳδίως αἷμα γίνεται. κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ μέλι, καὶ κρέας, καὶ γάλα. ταυτὶ μὲν οὖν, ὅλαις ἀλλοιούμενα ταῖς οὐσίαις, τροφαὶ τῶν ἀλλοιούντων εἰσί. τὰ δὲ κατὰ μίαν ἡντιναοῦν ποιότητα τὴν ἀλλοίωσιν ἴσχοντά τε καὶ τρεπόμενα, φάρμακα μόνον, ὥσπερ γε καὶ ὅσα ταῖς ὅλαις ἑαυτῶν οὐσίαις ἄτρεπτα μένοντα διατίθησι τὸ σῶμα, φάρμακα μέν ἐστι καὶ ταῦτα· χαλεπὰ δὲ καὶ φθαρτικὰ τῆς τοῦ ζώου φύσεως· ὅθεν περ, οἶμαι, καὶ τὸ γένος αὐτῶν ἅπαν ὀνομάζεται δηλητήριον. οὐ γὰρ δὴ διὰ τοῦτό γε λεκτέον οὐκ εἶναι τῷ γένει δηλητήρια τὰ τοιαῦτα, διότι παντελῶς ἐλάχιστα προσαχθέντα βλάβην οὐδὲ μίαν αἰσθητὴν ἐπιφέρει. οὕτω γὰρ ἂν οὐδὲ τὸ πῦρ εἴη θερμὸν, οὐδ’ ἡ χιὼν ψυχρά· ὡς καὶ τούτων γε παντάπασι τὰ σμικρὰ σαφὲς οὐδὲν ἀποτελεῖ περὶ τοῖς σώμασιν ἡμῶν πάθος. σπινθῆρος γὰρ ἑνὸς ἑκατοστὸν μέρος ἔστι μὲν πάντως τῷ γένει πῦρ, ἀλλ’ οὐ μόνον οὐκ ἂν ἡμᾶς καύσειεν ἢ θερμῄνειεν, ἀλλ’ οὐδ’ ἄν αἴσθησίν τινα παράσχοι προσπεσόν. οὕτω δὲ καὶ τὸ τῆς ψυχρᾶς ῥανίδος ἑκατοστὸν μέρος οὐ μόνον οὐδὲν ἂν βλάψειεν ἢ ψύξειεν, ἀλλ’ οὐδ’ ἂν αἴσθησίν τινα παράσχοι. μὴ τοίνυν οὕτως μηδὲ τὰ δηλητήρια κρίνειν, ἀλλὰ τῇ τῆς ὅλης φύσεως ἐναντιώσει, τὴν δ’ ἐναντίωσιν ἐκ τῆς ἐμμέσου κρίνειν μεταβολῆς. οἷον εὐθέως ἀπὸ τῶν στοιχείων οὔθ’ ὕδωρ εἰς πῦρ, οὔτε πῦρ εἰς ὕδωρ μεταβάλλειν πέφυκεν, ἀλλ’ εἰς ἀέρα μὲν ἄμφω, ἐκεῖνος δ’ εἰς ἑκάτερα, εἰς ἄλληλα δὲ ταῦτ’ οὐδαμῶς.
paragraphs.claude_translation: One must pay attention, as has been said, especially to distinguish things that are per se from things that are accidental, not only in the case of hot and cold things, but no less in the case of moist and dry things. For some of such things, being dry in their substances, when melted by much heat, have taken on the appearance of moisture, like copper and iron; or they are moist per se, just as crystal is, but when approaching unmixed coldness, they appear dry. Therefore, one must make the judgment of all these things not simply, as we were also saying in what came before, but with the additional consideration of how they stand in relation to heat or cold. For if, while partaking of little heat, they nevertheless appear moist, they are such through their own nature, and likewise if with abundant heat they are dry. But those things that either flow with boiling heat or have solidified through unmixed cold should not be considered to be moist or dry per se. Therefore, one must distinguish things per se from things accidental in this way, and referring to these very things, make the judgment thus of things potentially hot, or cold, or dry, or moist. For the potential must be judged not in relation to the accidental, but in relation to the per se. And the judgment is common and one for all things: the speed of alteration. Since hot, cold, dry, and moist are spoken of homonymously—for some things are named thus according to predominance, while others are named as having an extreme degree of the quality from which they are denominatively named—whatever of these the thing being judged readily changes into, it will be such potentially. For oil is potentially hot, because it readily becomes flame. And in the same way resin, asphalt, and pitch. Wine, because it readily becomes blood. And in the same way honey, meat, and milk. These things, then, being altered in their whole substances, are foods for the things altering them. But those things that undergo and are changed in alteration according to any single quality whatsoever are only drugs, just as indeed those things that, remaining unchanged in their whole substances, affect the body—these too are drugs, but difficult ones and destructive of the nature of the living being; whence, I think, their whole class is called poison. For one should certainly not say that such things are not poisons by class because, when applied in completely minimal amounts, they bring no perceptible harm whatsoever. For in this way fire would not be hot, nor snow cold; since even very small amounts of these produce no clear effect upon our bodies. For the hundredth part of a single spark is certainly fire by class, but it would not only not burn or warm us, but would not even provide any sensation when it falls upon us. And likewise the hundredth part of a cold drop would not only not harm or cool us, but would not even provide any sensation. Therefore, one must not judge poisons in this way either, but by the opposition to the whole nature, and judge the opposition from the intermediate change. For example, immediately from the elements, neither does water naturally change into fire, nor fire into water, but both change into air, and that into each of them, but these never into one another.

paragraphs.content: ἄμεσος μὲν οὖν ἡ εἰς ἀέρα μεταβολὴ τοῦ ὕδατος· ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ τοῦ πυρός. οὐκ ἄμεσον δὲ ἡ πυρὸς καὶ ὕδατος εἰς ἄλληλα ταῦτ’ οὖν ἀλλήλοις ἐναντία ἐστὶ καὶ πολέμια. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ ὀπὸς μήκωνος ἀνθρωπείῳ σώματι τελέως ἐστὶν ἐναντίος, οὐδὲν εἰς αὐτὸ οὔτε κατὰ μίαν ποιότητα δρᾶσαι δυνάμενον, οὔτε πολὺ δὴ μᾶλλον ἔτι καθ’ ὅλην τὴν οὐσίαν. ἓν μὲν δὴ τοῦτο γένος τῶν δηλητηρίων. ἕτερον δὲ τῶν ἀφορμὴν μέν τινα μεταβολῆς λαμβανόντων ἐκ τῆς ἐν ἡμῖν θερμασίας, εἰς πολυειδεῖς δ’ ἐντεῦθεν ἐκτρεπομένων ἀλλοιώσεις, ὑφ’ ὧν διαφθείρεσθαι τὴν φύσιν ἡμῶν συμβαίνει. πάντα γὰρ τὰ τοιαῦτα τῷ γένει δηλητήρια, κᾂν διὰ σμικρότητά ποτε μηδὲν αἰσθητὸν ἀπεργάζηται. τὰ μὲν δὴ διαβιβρώσκοντα καὶ σήποντα καὶ τήκοντα τὴν τοῦ σώματος ἡμῶν φύσιν εἰκότως ὀνομάζεται δυνάμει θερμά· τὰ δ’ αὖ ψύχοντα καὶ ναρκοῦντα ψυχρά. τὰ μὲν οὖν πρότερα παράλογον οὐδὲν οὔτε αὐτὰ πάσχειν, οὔτε τοῖς σώμασιν ἡμῶν ἐναπεργάζεσθαι δοκεῖ. θερμῷ γὰρ σώματι πλησιάσαντα, καί τινα ῥοπὴν ἀλλοιώσεως ἐντεῦθεν λαβόντα, τὰ μὲν εἰς ἐσχάτην ἀφικνεῖται θερμότητα, τὰ δ’ εἰς σηπεδόνα. διατίθησιν οὖν εἰκότως καὶ τὰ τῶν ζώων σώματα κατὰ τὴν ἑαυτῶν διάθεσιν. ὅσα δὲ ψύχει τὸ σῶμα, κᾂν θερμῄνας αὐτὰ προσενέγκῃς, ἀπορίαν οὐ σμικρὰν ἐπιφέρει, τίνος ποτὲ φύσεώς ἐστιν. εἰ γὰρ ἅπαξ ἐνεργείᾳ θερμὰ γέγονε, τί οὐ θερμαίνει τὸ ζῶον; ἢ εἰ μήπω τεθέρμανται, πῶς φαίνεται θερμά; λύσις δὲ τῆς ἀπορίας, εἰ διορισθείη τὸ καθ’ αὑτὸ ψυχρὸν τοῦ κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς, ὡς Ἀριστοτέλης ἐδίδαξεν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: The transformation of water into air is immediate; and likewise also that of fire. But the transformation of fire and water into each other is not immediate. These, therefore, are contrary and hostile to each other. In the same manner, poppy juice is completely contrary to the human body, being able to act upon it neither according to a single quality, nor much more still according to its entire substance. This, then, is one kind of poison. Another kind consists of those things that receive a certain starting point of transformation from the heat within us, but from this point turn aside into manifold alterations, by which our nature happens to be destroyed. For all such things are poisons by their kind, even if on account of their small quantity they sometimes produce no perceptible effect. Now those things that corrode and putrefy and dissolve the nature of our body are reasonably called hot in potency; while those that cool and numb are called cold. Concerning the former, then, it seems nothing irrational either that they themselves should be affected or that they should produce effects in our bodies. For having approached a hot body and having received from this some impulse toward alteration, some reach an extreme heat, while others reach putrefaction. They therefore reasonably affect the bodies of living creatures according to their own condition. But those things that cool the body, even if you heat them and then apply them, introduce no small difficulty as to what their nature might be. For if they have once become actually hot, why do they not heat the living creature? Or if they have not yet been heated, how do they appear hot? The solution to this difficulty lies in distinguishing what is cold in itself from what is cold accidentally, as Aristotle taught.

paragraphs.content: ἀπόλλυται γὰρ ἐν τάχει τῶν κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς θερμῶν ἡ ἐπίκτητος διάθεσις, ὥστ’ εἰς τὴν ἀρχαίαν αὐτὰ φύσιν ἐπανέρχεσθαι ῥᾳδίως. ἐν δὲ τῷ πλησιάζειν ἡμῖν τὰ φύσει μὲν ψυχρὰ, κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς δὲ θερμὰ, δύο ταῦτ’ ἐξ ἀνάγκης γίνεται· τὸ μὲν ἐπίκτητον αὐτῶν ἀπόλλυται θερμὸν, ἡ δ’ οἰκεία κρᾶσις, οὐδὲν ὑπὸ τῆς ἡμετέρας πάσχουσα, μένει ψυχρά, καὶ τί θαυμαστὸν, εἰ μήκωνος ὀπὸς, ἢ μανδραγόρας, ἢ κώνειον, ἤ τι τῶν τοιούτων, εἶ καὶ θερμανθέντα προσενεχθείης, μικρὸν ὕστερον γίνεται ψυχρά; πτισσάνης, καὶ γάλακτος, καὶ χόνδρου, καὶ ἄρτου, τὸ αὐτὸ τοῦτο πασχόντων, ἐπειδὰν εἰς ἄῤῥωστον ἐμπεσόντα γαστέρα μὴ κρατηθῇ πρὸς αὐτῆς· ἐμεῖται γοῦν πολλάκις ἱκανῶς ψυχρά. καὶ τό γε τούτων μεῖζον, ὃ δὴ καὶ Ἱπποκράτης ἐπεσημῄνατο· καίτοι χυμὸς ὂν ἤδη τὸ φλέγμα, κᾀκ τῶν σιτίων τῶν μὴ πεφθέντων πολλάκις ἐν τῇ γαστρὶ γεννώμενος, ὅμως ψυχρὸν ἁπτομένοις φαίνεται, οὐ μόνον ἐν τῇ γαστρὶ συστὰν, ἀλλὰ κᾀκ τῶν φλεβῶν αὐτῶν ὑπό τινος τῶν καθαιρόντων φαρμάκων ἑλχθέν. καί τοί γε γλισχρότατόν ἐστι σφόδρα, καὶ βιαίως ἄγεται, ἀλλ’ ὅμως οὐδ’ ἡ βία τῆς ὁλκῆς ἐκθερμαίνειν αὐτὸ δύναται. τί οὖν θαυμαστὸν, εἰ καὶ τὸ μηκώνειον, οὕτως ἐναντίον ἡμῶν τῇ φύσει φάρμακον, ἀποψύχεται μὲν αὐτίκα μάλα, κᾂν θερμὸν ποθῇ, συγκαταψύχει δ’ ἑαυτῷ τὸ σῶμα. τὴν γὰρ ἐπίκτητον οὐ φυλάττει θερμασίαν, ὅτι φύσει ψυχρὸν ἦν· τῷ δὲ μηδ’ ἀλλοιοῦσθαι τὴν οὐσίαν αὐτοῦ πρὸς ἡμῶν, ἀλλὰ μᾶλλον ἀλλοιοῦν τε καὶ μεταβάλλειν ἡμᾶς, οὔτε θερμαίνεταί τι πρὸς ἡμῶν, αὐτό τε διατίθησιν ἡμᾶς καθ’ αὑτό· ψυχρὸν οὖν ὑπάρχον φύσει, ψύχει δήπου καὶ ἡμᾶς. οὐκοῦν οὐκέτ’ ἄπορον οὐδὲν ὑπόλοιπον ἐν τῷ λόγῳ. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ ὅτι τούτων ἁπάντων τῶν φύσει ψυχρῶν ὅ τι ἂν ἐπὶ πλέον ἐκθερμῄνης, ἐξίσταται τῆς ἰδίας φύσεως, πρὸς τῷ μηδὲν ἄπορον ἔχειν, ἔτι καὶ μαρτυρεῖ τοῖς εἰρημένοις. ὡς γὰρ καὶ ἡ σαλαμάνδρα μέχρι μέν τινος ὑπὸ πυρὸς οὐδὲν πάσχει, κατακαίεται δ’, εἰ πλείονι χρόνῳ τῷ πυρὶ πλησιάσειεν, οὕτω καὶ ὁ μανδραγόρας, καὶ κώνειον, καὶ ψύλλιον, ἐπὶ βραχὺ μὲν ὁμιλήσαντα τῷ πυρὶ, τὴν οἰκείαν ἔτι διαφυλάττει κρᾶσιν, ἐπὶ πλέον δὲ θερμανθέντα, διαφθείρεται παραχρῆμα, καὶ δρᾷν οὐκέτι οὐδὲν ὧν πρότερον ἐπεφύκει δύναται. τῶν μὲν δὴ τοιούτων ἁπάντων ἡ φύσις ἐναντιωτάτη τοῖς ἀνθρώποις ἐστί· φύσιν δ’ ὅταν εἴπω, τὴν ὅλην οὐσίαν τε καὶ κρᾶσιν λέγω, τὴν ἐκ τῶν πρώτων στοιχείων, θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ, καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ· τῶν δὲ τάχιστα τρεφόντων οἰκειοτάτη. τὰ δ’ ἄλλα πάντα μεταξὺ τούτων ἐστί· τὰ μὲν μᾶλλον, τὰ δ’ ἧττον δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ὑπὸ τοῦ σώματος ἡμῶν δυνάμενα. καστόριον μὲν γὰρ καὶ πέπερι δρᾷν μᾶλλον ἢ πάσχειν ὑπὸ τοῦ σώματος ἡμῶν δυνάμενα· οἶνος δὲ καὶ μέλι καὶ πτισσάνη πάσχειν μᾶλλον ἢ δρᾷν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For the acquired condition of heat that belongs to things only incidentally is quickly lost, so that they readily return to their original nature. And when things that are by nature cold but incidentally hot come near us, two consequences necessarily follow: their acquired heat is lost, while their proper constitution [krâsis: intrinsic “mixture” or tempering] remains cold, suffering nothing from our body. And what is surprising if the juice of the poppy [opium], or mandrake, or hemlock, or anything of that sort, even if brought to us warmed, a little later becomes cold? Barley gruel [ptisane], milk, groats [chondros], and bread undergo the same experience when they fall into a sick stomach and are not retained by it; indeed, they are often vomited up quite cold. And here is an even stronger point, one noted by Hippocrates: although phlegm is already a humor, and is often generated in the stomach from undigested foods, nevertheless it feels cold to the touch—not only when it has congealed in the stomach, but even when it has been drawn from the very veins by some purgative drug. And yet it is exceedingly viscous and is expelled with force; nevertheless, not even the violence of that traction is able to heat it. What, then, is surprising if the poppy drug—so contrary to our nature—cools down at once, even if it was drunk warm, and cools the body along with itself? For it does not preserve its acquired warmth, since it was by nature cold; and because its substance is not altered by us, but rather it alters and transforms us, it is not warmed by us in any degree, and instead disposes us according to its own character. Being by nature cold, it naturally cools us as well. Accordingly, nothing puzzling remains in the argument. Indeed, the fact that any of these naturally cold things, if overheated for a longer time, departs from its own nature not only leaves no puzzle, but also corroborates what has been said. For just as the salamander, up to a point, suffers nothing from fire, yet is burned if it remains near the fire too long, so too mandrake, hemlock, and psyllium [fleawort/plantain]: after brief contact with fire they still preserve their proper constitution, but if heated further they are immediately destroyed and can no longer perform any of the actions for which they were originally suited. The nature of all such substances is most opposed to human beings; and by “nature” I mean the whole substance and constitution, derived from the primary elements—hot and cold, and dry and wet—whereas those that nourish most quickly are most akin to us. All other substances fall between these: some are more, some less capable of acting on and being acted upon by our body. Thus castoreum and pepper are able to act on our body more than to be acted upon by it, whereas wine, honey, and ptisane are more acted upon than they act.
paragraphs.claude_translation: For the acquired disposition of things that are hot accidentally is destroyed quickly, so that they easily return to their original nature. But when things that are cold by nature but hot accidentally come near us, these two things necessarily occur: their acquired heat is destroyed, while their proper mixture, suffering nothing from our own, remains cold. And what is surprising if poppy juice, or mandrake, or hemlock, or any such thing, even if you take it after it has been heated, becomes cold a short time later? Barley gruel, milk, groats, and bread suffer this same thing, whenever they fall into a weak stomach and are not mastered by it; at any rate, they are often vomited up quite cold. And what is even more significant than these things, which Hippocrates also noted: although phlegm is already a humor and is often generated in the stomach from undigested foods, nevertheless it appears cold to the touch, not only when it has collected in the stomach, but also when it has been drawn from the veins themselves by some purgative drug. And yet it is extremely viscous and is drawn out forcibly, but nevertheless even the force of the extraction cannot heat it. What then is surprising if poppy drug too, being a drug so contrary to our nature, is cooled immediately, even if drunk hot, and cools the body along with itself? For it does not retain its acquired heat, because it was cold by nature; and because its substance is not altered by us, but rather it alters and changes us, it is not heated at all by us, but it itself affects us according to its own nature; therefore, being cold by nature, it naturally also cools us. Therefore nothing problematic remains in the argument. And indeed the fact that whatever of all these things that are cold by nature you heat excessively departs from its proper nature, in addition to containing nothing problematic, also bears witness to what has been said. For just as the salamander up to a certain point suffers nothing from fire, but is burned up if it approaches the fire for a longer time, so too mandrake, hemlock, and fleawort, when they have contact with fire briefly, still preserve their proper mixture, but when heated excessively, they are immediately destroyed and can no longer do any of the things they were naturally able to do before. Now the nature of all such things is most contrary to human beings; and when I say nature, I mean the whole substance and mixture derived from the primary elements—hot and cold, dry and moist; but the nature of things that nourish most quickly is most akin to us. All other things are between these: some being more, others less able to act upon and be acted upon by our body. For castoreum and pepper are more able to act upon than be acted upon by our body; but wine, honey, and barley gruel are more able to be acted upon than to act.

paragraphs.content: ἅπαντα οὖν ταῦτα καὶ πάσχει τι καὶ δρᾷ περὶ τὸ σῶμα. καθ’ ὅλου γὰρ ἐπειδὰν εἰς ταὐτὸ ἀλλήλοις ἥκοντα διαμάχηταί τε καὶ στασιάζῃ πρὸς ἄλληλα περὶ τῆς ἀλλοιώσεως ἐν χρόνῳ πλείονι, δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ἑκάτερον αὐτῶν ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν. ἴσως δὲ, κᾂν μὴ πολλῷ πάνυ χρόνῳ γίγνηται τοῦτο, δρᾷ μὲν ἔτι καὶ τότε τὸ νικώμενον εἰς τὸ κρατοῦν, ἀλλ’ οὕτω σμικρὸν, ὡς λανθάνειν τὴν αἴσθησιν. οὐδὲ γὰρ ὁ τμητικώτατος σίδηρος εἰ τὸν μαλακώτατον τέμνει κηρὸν δι’ ὅλης ἡμέρας καὶ νυκτὸς, ἀδύνατον αὐτῷ μὴ οὐκ ἀμβλὺν γενέσθαι σαφῶς. οὕτω δή που κᾀκεῖνο καλῶς εἰρῆσθαι δοκεῖ, Πέτρην κοιλαίνει ῥανὶς ὕδατος ἐνδελεχείῃ. καὶ γὰρ καὶ φαίνεται γινόμενον οὕτως.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Therefore all these things both undergo something and act upon the body. For in general, whenever they come into contact with one another and struggle and are in conflict with each other concerning alteration over a longer period of time, it is necessary that each of them both acts and is acted upon. Perhaps, even if this does not happen over a very long time, the thing being overcome still acts even then upon the thing prevailing, but so slightly that it escapes perception. For not even if the sharpest iron cuts the softest wax throughout an entire day and night is it impossible for it not to become manifestly blunt. Thus indeed that saying too seems to be well stated: "A drop of water hollows out a stone by constant falling." For indeed this is seen to happen in this way.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Therefore all these things both are affected by something and act with respect to the body. For in general, whenever things that have come together to the same [subject] contend and are at variance with one another about alteration [alloiōsis: qualitative change] over a longer time, it is necessary that each of them both act and be acted upon [agent and patient]. Perhaps even if this does not occur over a very long time, the weaker still then acts upon the stronger, but so slightly as to escape perception. For not even the sharpest iron, if it cuts the softest wax for a whole day and night, can fail clearly to become blunted. Thus, too, that saying seems well put: “A drop of water hollows a stone by persistence.” And in fact it is seen to occur in this way.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: Therefore, all these things both are acted upon and act in some way with respect to the body. For as a universal rule, whenever things have come into contact with one another and struggle and are at odds with each other concerning alteration [qualitative change] over a considerable time, it is necessary for each of them both to act and to be acted upon. But perhaps, even if this happens in not a very long time, the thing being overcome still acts upon the prevailing one, but so slightly as to escape our perception. For indeed, if the sharpest iron cuts the softest wax for a whole day and night, it is impossible for it not to become perceptibly blunted. Thus, no doubt, that saying also seems to be well put: "A drop of water hollows a stone by persistence." And in fact, this is observed to happen.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐπὶ μὲν μιᾶς ἢ καὶ δευτέρας προσβολῆς οὐδὲν οὔπω σαφὲς ἐν τοῖς τοιούτοις ἰδεῖν ἐστιν. ὅθεν, οἶμαι, καὶ τὸ μηδ’ ὅλως πάσχειν ἔνια πρὸς τῶν ὁμιλούντων ἐδοξάσθη τισί· καὶ συγχωρητέον γε τοῖς οὕτω λέγουσι. πολλάκις δὲ καὶ αὐτοὺς ἡμᾶς ὁμοίως ἐκείνοις λεκτέον ἐστὶ τὰ πολλά· πλὴν εἴ ποτε μέχρι τῆς ἐσχάτης ἀκριβείας ἀνάγοιμεν τὸν λόγον, ὥσπερ ἐν τῷ παρόντι ποιοῦμεν. οὕτως οὖν καὶ τὸ τῆς ἀειπαθείας δόγμα, τῷ λόγῳ μὲν αὐτῷ μόνῳ σκοποῦσιν, ἰσχυρὰν ἔχει τὴν ἀπόδειξιν. οὐ μὴν χρεία γέ τίς ἐστιν αὐτοῦ πρὸς τὰς κατὰ μέρος πράξεις.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But in the case of one or even a second encounter, it is not yet possible to see anything clear in such matters. For this reason, I think, some people have also come to believe that certain things are not affected at all by things that come into contact with them; and one must grant this to those who speak in this way. And often we ourselves must speak in the same way as they do for the most part; except if at some point we should carry the argument to the utmost precision, just as we are doing in the present case. Thus, then, the doctrine of continuous affection [ἀειπάθεια], when examined by reason alone, has a strong demonstration. Nevertheless, there is no need for it in particular practical matters.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But on the first, or even the second, encounter, nothing yet clear can be seen in matters of this sort. Hence, I suppose, some have even thought that certain things are not affected at all by those that are in contact with them [hoi homilountes: things that “associate” or come into contact]. And one must concede something to those who speak in this way. Often, too, we ourselves must, for the most part, speak as they do—except whenever we carry the argument to the utmost precision, as we are doing now. Thus, the doctrine of aeipatheia [perpetual being-affected] has, for those who consider it by reason alone, a powerful demonstration. Yet there is, to be sure, no particular need of it for individual practical applications.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: But on the basis of a single or even a second encounter, nothing clear can yet be seen in such cases. For this reason, I believe, the opinion has been held by some that certain things are not affected at all by the things they are in contact with; and one must certainly concede to those who say so. Indeed, we ourselves must often speak for the most part just as they do, unless, of course, we are to trace the argument back to the utmost degree of precision, as we are doing in the present instance. In this way, then, the doctrine of constant affection [aeipatheia, perpetual affection or passivity], for those who examine it by reason alone, possesses a strong proof. However, there is no need of it for particular actions.

paragraphs.content: ἂν γὰρ οὕτω μικρά τινα περὶ ἡμᾶς ᾖ πάθη διὰ παντὸς, ὡς μηδεμίαν αἰσθητὴν καὶ σαφῆ βλάβην ἐνεργείας ἐργάζεσθαι μηδεμιᾶς, εὐκαταφρόνητα δήπουθέν ἐστι, καὶ τῷ μηδὲν εἶναι φάσκοντι τὰ τοιαῦτα συγχωρητέον. οὕτως οὖν ἔχει κᾀπὶ τῶν τρεφόντων, ὀλίγου δεῖν, ἁπάντων. ἐργάζεται μὲν γάρ τι καὶ ταῦτα περὶ τὸ σῶμα τῶν ἀνθρώπων, ἀλλ’ οὐκ αἰσθητὸν, οὐδὲ σαφές τι καθάπαξ. ἡ μέντοι πολυχρόνιος αὐτῶν προσφορὰ μεγάλως ἀλλοιοῖ καὶ μεταβάλλει σαφῶς ἤδη τὰ σώματα. ἔνια μέν γε καὶ κατὰ τὴν πρώτην χρῆσιν εὐθὺς ἐναργῶς ἐνδείκνυται τὴν ἀλλοίῳσιν, οἶον καὶ ἡ θριδακίνη, τοὺς μὲν ἐγκαιομένους τὴν γαστέρα σαφῶς ἐμψύχουσά τε καὶ ἀδίψους ἐργαζομένη, τοὺς δὲ κατεψυγμένους ἐναργῶς βλάπτουσα. συντελεῖ δ’ οὐ σμικρὰ καὶ τοῖς ὕπνοις, οὐ κατ’ ἄλλον τινὰ λόγον, ἀλλ’ ὅτι ψυχρά τέ ἐστι καὶ ὑγρὰ τὴν κρᾶσιν· ἀλλ’ οὕτως ὑγρὰ καὶ ψυχρὰ πρὸς ἄνθρωπόν τε καὶ τἄλλ’, ὅσα τρέφειν πέφυκεν, ὡς καὶ τὰ ξύλα τὰ χλωρὰ πρὸς τὸ πῦρ. ὥστ’ εὐλόγως ἄμφω τοῖς τοιούτοις ἐδέσμασιν ὑπάρχει, τό θ’ ὡς φαρμάκοις διατιθέναι τὰ σώμαθ’ ἡμῶν, καὶ τὸ τρέφειν, παρ’ ὅλον μὲν τὸν χρόνον τῆς πέψεως, ὡς φαρμάκοις· ἡνίκα δ’ ἤδη τρέφει τε καὶ τελέως ὁμοιοῦται, τότ’ οὐκέτ’ οὐδὲν ἡμᾶς ἀντιδρῶντα, τὴν ἔμφυτον αὔξει θερμασίαν, ὡς καὶ πρόσθεν εἴρηται. κοινὸν γὰρ ἤδη τῶν τρεφόντων ἁπάντων ἐστὶ, καὶ οὐ χρὴ θαυμάζειν, εἴ τι, πρὶν μὲν ἐξομοιοῦσθαι καὶ τρέφειν, ἔτι πεττόμενον ἔψυχεν, ἐξομοιωθὲν δὲ καὶ θρέψαν, ἐθέρμῃνε, μεμνημένους ἀεὶ τοῦ τῶν χλωρῶν ξύλων παραδείγματος.
paragraphs.claude_translation: For if certain affections around us are so small throughout that they produce no perceptible and clear harm to any function, they are surely to be despised, and one must concede to the person who claims that such things are nothing. Thus it is also with nearly all nourishing things. For these too produce some effect upon the human body, but not a perceptible one, nor anything clear at all. However, their prolonged consumption greatly alters and clearly changes the bodies. Some indeed even at their first use immediately show the alteration clearly, as for example lettuce, which clearly cools and makes free from thirst those who are burning in the stomach, but clearly harms those who are chilled. It contributes not a little also to sleep, not for any other reason, but because it is cold and moist in its mixture [temperament]. But it is moist and cold in relation to man and the other things which it is naturally suited to nourish, as green wood is in relation to fire. So that reasonably both properties belong to such foods: both to affect our bodies as drugs do, and to nourish—throughout the whole time of digestion, as drugs; but when it already nourishes and is completely assimilated, then it no longer acts against us at all, but increases the innate heat, as was said before. For this is now common to all nourishing things, and one should not wonder if something, before being assimilated and nourishing, while still being digested, cooled, but once assimilated and having nourished, warmed—always remembering the example of green wood.

paragraphs.content: ὥστε καὶ ἡ χρεία τῶν τοιούτων ἁπάντων διττὴ τοῖς ἰατροῖς ἐστι, καὶ ὡς σιτίων, καὶ ὡς φαρμάκων. φέρε γὰρ ὑπηλλάχθαι τινὶ τὴν ἀρίστην ἐν τῇ γαστρὶ κρᾶσιν ἐπὶ τὸ θερμότερον. οὗτος, ἄχρι μὲν οὗ πέττει τὴν θριδακίνην, ἐμψυχθήσεται καὶ συμμετρίαν κτήσεται κράσεως· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἐξ αὐτῆς ἤδη τρέφηται, τὴν οὐσίαν αὐξήσει τῆς ἐμφύτου θερμασίας. ἐν τούτῳ δὴ καὶ μάλιστα δοκοῦσί μοι παραλογίζεσθαι σφᾶς αὐτοὺς οἱ πολλοὶ τῶν νεωτέρων ἰατρῶν, ἀγνοοῦντες, ὡς ἐνίοτε μὲν ἡ ποιότης ἐπιτείνεται τῆς ἐν ἡμῖν θερμασίας, ἐνίοτε δ’ ἡ οὐσία παραύξεται, καὶ ὡς ἑκατέρως οἱ παλαιοὶ θερμότερον γεγονέναι τὸ ζῶόν φασι. καὶ γὰρ καὶ γίνεται θερμότερον, ἄντ’ ἐπιτείνῃς αὐτοῦ τὴν θερμασίαν, ἄντ’ αὐξήσῃς τὴν οὐσίαν, ἐν ᾗ πρώτῃ περιέχεται. φέρε γὰρ εἶναι τὸ αἷμα τὸ ἐν τῷ σώματι τοῦ ζώου καθ’ αὑτὸ θερμὸν, ἢ, νὴ Δία, εἰ βούλει τὴν ξανθὴν χολὴν, ἅπαντα δὲ τἄλλα κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς ὑπάρχειν θερμὰ τῷ τούτων μετέχειν. ἆρ’ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον ἔσται, διττῶς γίνεσθαι θερμότερον τὸ ζῶον, ἤτοι τῷ πλείονας ἐπικτήσασθαι χυμοὺς θερμοὺς, ἢ τῷ θερμοτέρους ἔχειν, ἢ πρότερον; ἐμοὶ μὲν καὶ πάνυ φαίνεται. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν, οἶμαι, τρόπον καὶ ψυχρότερον ἔσται διττῶς, ἢ τῷ πλείους ὑποτραφῆναι τοὺς ψυχροὺς χυμοὺς, οἶον τὸ φλέγμα καὶ τὴν μέλαιναν χολὴν, ἢ τῷ, τῆς αὐτῶν ἁπάντων μενούσης συμμετρίας, ὑπαλλαχθῆναι μόνην τὴν ποιότητα. τί δὴ οὖν θαυμαστὸν, ἄχρι μὲν ἂν πέπτηται τὸ ψυχρὸν τῇ φύσει σιτίον, οἶον ἀνδράχνη τε καὶ θριδακίνη, ψυχρᾶς ποιότητος ἀναπίμπλασθαι τὸ σῶμα, πεφθέντων δ’ ἀκριβῶς καὶ γενομένων αἷμα χρηστὸν, θερμότερον αὖθις ἑαυτοῦ γίνεσθαι τὸ σῶμα τῇ τοῦ θερμοῦ χυμοῦ γενέσει; καὶ μὴν εἰ μηδὲν τούτων μήτ’ ἀδύνατόν ἐστι, μήτε θαυμαστὸν ἔτι, παυσάσθωσαν οἱ μὴ συγχωροῦντες, ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ ἔδεσμα καὶ τὴν ὡς τροφῆς καὶ τὴν ὡς φαρμάκου χρείαν τῷ ζώῳ παρέχειν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: So the use of all such things is twofold for physicians, both as foods and as drugs. For suppose that someone's best mixture [temperament] in the stomach has been altered toward the hotter. This person, as long as he is digesting lettuce, will be cooled and will acquire a balanced mixture; but when he is already being nourished from it, he will increase the substance of the innate heat. In this matter especially, it seems to me, most of the younger physicians deceive themselves, not knowing that sometimes the quality of the heat in us is intensified, and sometimes the substance is increased, and that in both ways the ancients say that the living creature has become hotter. For indeed it does become hotter, whether you intensify its heat or increase the substance in which it is primarily contained. For suppose that the blood in the body of the living creature is hot in itself, or, by Zeus, if you prefer, the yellow bile, and that all other things are hot accidentally by partaking of these. Will it not be necessary that the living creature becomes hotter in two ways, either by acquiring more hot humors, or by having hotter ones than before? To me at least it certainly appears so. And in the same way, I think, it will also be colder in two ways, either because the cold humors have been nourished underneath [accumulated], such as phlegm and black bile, or because, while the balance of all these remains the same, only the quality has been altered. What then is surprising if, as long as food that is cold by nature is being digested, such as purslane and lettuce, the body is filled with cold quality, but when they have been thoroughly digested and have become good blood, the body again becomes hotter than itself by the generation of hot humor? And indeed, if none of these things is either impossible or any longer surprising, let those who do not agree cease [their objections], [and admit] that one and the same food provides to the living creature both the use as nourishment and the use as a drug.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So the use of all such things is twofold for physicians: both as foods and as drugs. For suppose that the best mixture [krasis: proportional “temperament” of qualities] in the stomach has been altered toward the hotter. This person, so long as he is digesting [pepsis: concoction/digestion] lettuce, will be enlivened and will obtain a balanced proportion of mixture; but when he is already being nourished from it, he will increase the substance of his inborn heat [thermasia: innate heat]. At this point, then, most of the younger physicians especially seem to me to mislead themselves, being ignorant that sometimes it is the quality of the heat within us that is intensified, and sometimes its substance is augmented—and that in both ways the ancients say the living creature becomes hotter. For indeed it does become hotter, either if you intensify its heat, or if you increase the substance in which that heat is primarily contained. Suppose the blood in the body of the animal is hot in itself—or, by Zeus, if you prefer, the yellow bile—and that all the other things are hot only incidentally by partaking of these. Is it not necessary that the animal become hotter in two ways, either by acquiring more hot humors [chymoi: bodily “juices,” i.e., humors], or by having them hotter than before? It seems to me entirely so. And in the same way, I think, it will also become colder in two ways: either by being overnourished with the cold humors, such as phlegm and black bile, or—while the symmetrical proportion of all of them remains—the quality alone being altered. What, then, is surprising if, so long as a food cold by nature—for example purslane and lettuce—is being digested, the body is filled with a cold quality, but when they have been thoroughly concocted and have become good blood, the body becomes once again hotter than before through the generation of the hot humor? And if none of these things is either impossible or any longer surprising, let those who do not grant it cease denying that one and the same article of diet supplies the animal with both its function as nourishment and its function as a drug.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: Therefore, the use of all such things is twofold for physicians: both as foods and as medicines. For suppose that in someone the best temperament [Gr. *krasis*, mixture of humors] in the stomach has been altered toward the hotter. This person, as long as he is digesting lettuce, will be cooled and will acquire a due proportion of temperament; but once he is being nourished from it, he will increase the substance [Gr. *ousia*] of his innate heat. And it is in this point especially, it seems to me, that most of the more recent physicians deceive themselves, being ignorant that sometimes the quality [Gr. *poiotēs*] of the heat in us is intensified, while at other times its substance is increased, and that in either case the ancients say the living being has become hotter. For it does indeed become hotter, whether you intensify its heat or you increase the substance in which that heat is primarily contained

paragraphs.content: ὡς γὰρ, εἰ καὶ μηδ’ ὅλως ἐπέφθη, διὰ παντὸς ἂν ἐφυλάχθη φάρμακον, οὕτω πεφθὲν ἄμφω γίνεται. φέρε γὰρ μηδ’ ὅλως πεφθῆναι τὴν θριδακίνην, ἢ, νὴ Δία, τὸν χυλὸν αὐτῆς, ἐπειδὴ καὶ παραπλήσια τῷ τοῦ μήκωνος ὀπῷ δρᾷ εἰς τὸν ἄνθρωπον, εἰ πάμπολυς ληφθείη, ἆρ’ οὖν φάρμακον ἔσται τηνικαῦτα μόνον, ἄλλο δ’ οὐδέν; οὐκ οἶμαί τινα περί γε τούτου ἀμφισβητήσειν. ὥστ’ ἔχει πάντως καὶ τὴν τοῦ φαρμάκου δύναμιν ἡ θριδακίνη. ἀλλὰ μὴν ἔσχε καὶ τὴν τῆς τροφῆς· ἔθρεψε γὰρ πολλάκις.
paragraphs.claude_translation: For just as, if it were not digested at all, it would remain a drug throughout, so when digested it becomes both. For suppose that lettuce were not digested at all, or, by Zeus, its juice, since it also produces effects on a person similar to poppy sap if taken in very large quantities—would it then be only a drug at that time, and nothing else? I do not think anyone would dispute this point. Consequently, lettuce certainly possesses the property of a drug as well. But indeed it also possessed the property of nourishment; for it has nourished many times.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For just as, even if it had not been cooked at all, it would always have remained a drug, so, when cooked, it becomes both. Suppose, for example, that the lettuce [thridakē] were not cooked at all—or, by Zeus, its juice—since it acts upon a person in a manner similar to the poppy’s sap [opium], if a very large amount is taken: will it then be a drug only, and nothing else? I do not think anyone would dispute this. Therefore lettuce certainly possesses the power of a drug. Yet it also has that of food; for it has often nourished.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: For just as a substance would have been regarded entirely as a drug if it were not digested at all, so when it is digested, it becomes both. For let us suppose that lettuce—or, by Zeus, its juice—is not digested at all, since it acts on a human being in a way very similar to the juice of the poppy [i.e., opium] if a very great quantity were to be taken. In that case, then, will it be a drug only, and nothing else? I think no one, at any rate, will dispute this. So then, lettuce in any case also possesses the power [dynamis] of a drug. And yet, it also possessed the power of a food; for it has often provided nourishment.

paragraphs.content: ὥστ’ ἀμφοτέρας μὲν ἅμα τὰς δυνάμεις ἐν ἑαυτῇ περιέχει, δείκνυσι δ’ οὐχ ὁμοίως ἀμφοτέρας, ἀλλ’ ἐπειδὰν μὲν αὐτὴ πλέον ἐνεργῇ περὶ τὸν ἄνθρωπον ἢ πάσχῃ, τὴν ὡς φαρμάκου μᾶλλον ἐπιδείκνυται δύναμιν· ἐπειδὰν δὲ πάσχῃ πλέον, ἢ ποιῇ, τὴν ὡς σιτίου. καὶ θαυμαστὸν οὐδὲν, εἰ τῇ θριδακίνῃ καὶ δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν συμβέβηκεν, ὅπου γε καὶ τῷ ξίφει, καθότι καὶ μικρὸν ἔμπροσθεν ἐλέγομεν, μὴ μόνον δρᾶν εἰς τὸν κηρὸν, ἀλλὰ καὶ πάσχειν ὑπάρχει. τῷ δ’ εἶναι πολὺ πλέον ὃ πέφυκε δρᾷν, ἢ πάσχειν, λανθάνει θάτερον. ἀλλ’ εἰ σκληρότατον αὐτῷ παραβάλλοις σίδηρον, ἔμπαλίν σοι φανεῖται πάσχειν μᾶλλον, ἢ δρᾷν, καίτοι δρᾷ μέν τι καὶ τότε, παρορᾶται δ’ ἡ δύναμις αὐτοῦ διὰ σμικρότητα. θαῤῥοῦντες οὖν ἐπὶ πάντων μὲν ἁπλῶς ἀποφαινόμεθα τῶν σιτίων, ὡς οὐ μόνον πάσχειν ὑπὸ τοῦ σώματος ἡμῶν, ἀλλὰ καὶ δρᾷν εἰς αὐτὸ πέφυκεν· ἤδη δὲ καὶ περί τινων, οἷς ἐναργῶς καὶ σαφῶς ὑπάρχει τὸ δρᾷν, ὡς οὐ σιτία μόνον ἐστὶν, ἀλλὰ καὶ φάρμακα. θριδακίνη μὲν οὖν καὶ τροφὴ καὶ φάρμακον ψυχρόν· εὔζωμον δὲ καὶ τροφὴ καὶ φάρμακον θερμόν. εἰ δὲ καὶ καστόριον ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ πέττεται, εἴη ἂν καὶ τοῦτο τροφή τε ἅμα καὶ φάρμακον θερμόν. οὕτω δὲ καὶ νάπυ, καὶ πέπερι, καὶ τῶν βοτανῶν ἄνηθόν τε καὶ πήγανον, ὀρίγανόν τε καὶ γλήχων, καὶ καλαμίνθη; καὶ θύμβρα, καὶ θύμος. πάντα γὰρ ταῦτα καὶ τροφαὶ καὶ φάρμακα θερμά. πρὶν γὰρ εἰς αἷμα μεταβαλεῖν, ἔτι γε πεττόμενα, φάρμακα· μεταβληθέντα δὲ, οὐκ ἔτι μὲν φάρμακα, τροφαὶ δ’ ἤδη, κατὰ τὸ δεύτερον δηλονότι τῆς τροφῆς σημαινόμενον, ὃ οὔπω μέν ἐστι τροφὴ, οἶον δὲ τροφή.
paragraphs.claude_translation: So that it contains both powers within itself at the same time, but it does not display both equally; rather, whenever it acts more upon the person than it is acted upon, it displays more the power of a drug; but whenever it is acted upon more than it acts, the power of a food. And it is nothing remarkable if it happens that lettuce both acts and is acted upon, seeing that even a sword, as we were saying a little earlier, not only acts upon wax, but is also acted upon. But because what it naturally does is much greater than what it suffers, the other aspect escapes notice. But if you were to compare it with the hardest iron, it will appear to you conversely to be acted upon more than to act, although it does act even then, but its power is overlooked because of its smallness. Therefore, we confidently declare simply about all foods that they are naturally disposed not only to be acted upon by our body, but also to act upon it; and indeed also concerning certain things for which the capacity to act exists clearly and manifestly, that they are not only foods but also drugs. Lettuce, then, is both a food and a cold drug; rocket is both a food and a hot drug. And if castoreum is also digested in time, this too would be both a food and a hot drug at the same time. And similarly mustard, and pepper, and among herbs dill and rue, oregano and pennyroyal, calamint and savory and thyme. For all these things are both foods and hot drugs. For before they change into blood, while still being digested, they are drugs; but once changed, they are no longer drugs but now foods, according to the second meaning of "food" obviously, which is not yet food but is like food.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
Accordingly, it contains both capacities within itself at once, yet it does not display both in the same way; rather, whenever it acts upon the human being more than it is acted upon, it shows its power more as a drug [pharmakon]; but whenever it is acted upon more than it acts, it shows its power as a food [sition]. And there is nothing marvelous if it has befallen lettuce [thridakine] both to act and to be acted upon, since even for a sword—as we said a little earlier—it not only acts upon wax, but also is acted upon. Because what its nature is far more to do is to act than to be acted upon, the other aspect escapes notice. But if you compare it with very hard iron, conversely it will appear to you to be acted upon rather than to act, although even then it does do something; its power is overlooked because it is slight.

Therefore, speaking confidently, we declare in general of all foods that they are by nature not only to be acted upon by our body, but also to act upon it; and now also, concerning certain items in which the acting is plainly and clearly present, that they are not only foods but also drugs. Lettuce, then, is both a food and a cold drug; “good broth” [euzomon] is both a food and a hot drug. And if castoreum is digested in time, this too would be at once both a food and a hot drug. So too mustard/turnip [napy], pepper, and among herbs dill, rue, oregano, pennyroyal, calamint, savory, and thyme: all these are both foods and hot drugs. For before they are transformed into blood, while still being digested, they are drugs; but once transformed, they are no longer drugs, and by then they are foods—according, namely, to the second signification of “food,” that which is not yet food, but is as it were food.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ὡς οὖν ἔμπροσθεν ἐπὶ θριδακίνης ἐλέγομεν, μίαν μὲν κοιλίαν ψυχροτέραν τοῦ δέοντος, ἑτέραν δὲ θερμοτέραν, οὕτω καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ πάντων τῶν δυνάμει θερμῶν ὑποκείσθωσαν αἱ δύο κοιλίαι. τὴν μὲν δὴ ψυχροτέραν τοῦ δέοντος, ἄχρι περ ἂν ᾖ ἐν αὐτῇ περιεχόμενα καὶ πεττόμενα τὰ τοιαῦτα σύμπαντα, θερμαίνει τε καὶ εἰς ἰσότητα κράσεως ἐπανάξει καὶ ὠφελήσει λόγῳ φαρμάκων· τὴν δ’ ἑτέραν τὴν θερμὴν ἐκπυρώσει τε καὶ μεγάλως βλάψει. καὶ ταύτας μὲν τὰς ἀλλοιώσεις ἐργάσεται κατὰ ποιότητα. πεφθέντα δ’ ἀκριβῶς, καὶ μεταβληθέντα, καὶ χρηστὸν αἷμα γενόμενα, κατ’ οὐσίαν αὐξήσει τὸ ἔμφυτον τῷ ζώῳ θερμὸν, οὐ κατὰ ποιότητα. καθόλου γὰρ, ἄντε ψυχρὸν, ἄντε θερμὸν ᾖ τῇ δυνάμει τὸ σιτίον, ἐπειδὰν αἱματωθῇ, τὴν ἔμφυτον ὡσαύτως αὐξήσει θερμασίαν· ἄχρι δ’ ἂν ἄγηται μὲν εἰς αἵματος ἰδέαν, οὔπω δὲ τελέως αἱμαχθῇ, ψύχει καὶ θερμαίνει τὸ σῶμα δίκην φαρμάκου. ἅπας δ’ οὗτος ὁ λόγος ἐκ μιᾶς ἀρχῆς ἤρτηται. διὸ καὶ φυλάττειν αὐτὴν ἀεὶ χρὴ, καὶ μεμνῆσθαι διὰ παντὸς, ὡς ἕκαστον τῶν σωμάτων ἰδιότητά τινα κέκτηται κράσεως, οἰκείαν μὲν τῇδέ τινι τῇ φύσει, διαφερομένην δὲ τῇδέ τινι· καὶ ὡς, εἰ μὲν ἀλλοιώσειε τὸ οἰκεῖον εἰς τὴν ἑαυτοῦ φύσιν, αὐξήσει τὴν οὐσίαν οὕτω τῆς ἐν αὐτῷ θερμασίας· εἰ δ’ ἀλλοιωθείη, δυοῖν θάτερον αὐτῷ συμβήσεται, θερμαίνοντος μὲν τοῦ μεταβάλλοντος, ἐπικτήσασθαί τινα θερμασίαν, μὴ θερμαίνοντος δὲ, τὴν οἰκείαν ἀπολέσαι. δῆλον οὖν ἐκ τούτοιν, ὡς ἐν τῷ πρός τι σύμπαντά ἐστι τὰ τοιαῦτα. πρὸς γὰρ τὴν ἰδιότητα τῆς ἀλλοιούσης φύσεως ἕκαστον τῶν προσφερομένων ἢ τροφῆς, ἢ φαρμάκου, ἢ ἀμφοτέρων λόγον ὑφέξει. οἷον τὸ κώνειον τῷ ψαρὶ μὲν τροφὴ, φάρμακον δ’ ἀνθρώπῳ· καὶ τοῖς μὲν ὄρτυξιν ἑλλέβορος τροφὴ, τοῖς δ’ ἀνθρώποις φάρμακον. ἡ μὲν γὰρ τῶν ὀρτύγων κρᾶσις ἐξομοιοῦν ἑαυτῇ δύναται τὸν ἑλλέβορον, ἡ δὲ τῶν ἀνθρώπων οὐ δύναται.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Therefore, just as we were saying earlier in the case of lettuce, that one stomach is colder than necessary and another is hotter, so too now let the two stomachs be assumed in the case of all things that are hot in potentiality. Now the one that is colder than necessary, as long as all such things are contained and being digested in it, they will warm it and restore it to an equality of mixture and benefit it in the manner of drugs; but the other one, the hot one, they will set ablaze and greatly harm. And these alterations they will produce in respect to quality. But once they have been thoroughly digested and transformed and have become useful blood, they will increase the innate heat of the animal in respect to substance, not in respect to quality. For in general, whether the food is cold or hot in potentiality, once it has been turned into blood, it will likewise increase the innate heat; but as long as it is being led toward the form of blood but has not yet been completely turned into blood, it cools and heats the body in the manner of a drug. Now this entire argument depends upon a single principle. Therefore one must always preserve it and remember throughout that each of the bodies possesses a certain particular mixture, proper to this particular nature but different from that particular one; and that if it should alter what is proper to it into its own nature, it will thus increase the substance of the heat in it; but if it should be altered, one of two things will happen to it: if what is transforming it is heating, it will acquire a certain heat, but if it is not heating, it will lose its proper heat. It is clear therefore from these considerations that all such things exist in relation to something. For in relation to the particular character of the altering nature, each of the things taken in will have the character either of food or of drug or of both. For example, hemlock is food for the starling but a drug for man; and hellebore is food for quails but a drug for humans. For the mixture of quails is able to assimilate hellebore to itself, but that of humans is not able to do so.
paragraphs.openai_translation: As we said earlier in the case of lettuce, that one stomach is colder than it should be and another hotter, so now too let us posit the two stomachs in relation to all things that are hot in potential [dynamis]. The one that is colder than it should be, so long as such things are contained in it and being concocted [pepsis], will warm it
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: Φανερὸν οὖν ἤδη γέγονεν, ὡς ἡ κρίσις τῶν πρὸς ἡμᾶς ὑγρῶν, ἢ ξηρῶν, ἢ ψυχρῶν, ἢ θερμῶν, οὐκ ἔξωθέν ποθεν, ἀλλ’ ἐξ ὧν ἡμεῖς αὐτοὶ πάσχομεν, ἀκριβῶς ἂν γίνοιτο, καὶ ὡς πρώτην μὲν καὶ μάλιστα ταύτην εἴη σκεπτέον, ἐφεξῆς δ’, εἴ τι δεήσειε, καὶ τὴν ἔξωθεν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ἐναργὴς εἴη καὶ σαφὴς αἰσθήσει τοῦ προσαχθέντος ἡ ἐνέργεια φαρμάκου, ταύτῃ πιστευτέον, ἀμελοῦντας τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων γνωρισμάτων· εἰ δ’ ἀμυδρὰ, καὶ ἀσαφὴς, ἢ ἐπίμικτος, ἤ τινα ὅλως ἀμφισβήτησιν ἔχουσα, τηνικαῦτα καὶ πρὸς τὰ ἐκτὸς ἅπαντα κριτέον αὐτήν. οὐκ οὖν οὐδὲ πρὸς ταῦτα πόῤῥωθεν, ἀλλ’ ἀπ’ αὐτῆς τῆς οὐσίας τοῦ ζητουμένου, οἶον εἰ τὸ ἔλαιον θερμὸν, οὐχ ὅτι γλίσχρον, ἢ ὠχρὸν, ἢ κοῦφον, ἀλλ’ εἰ ῥᾳδίως ἐκφλογοῦται· τοῦτο γὰρ ἦν αὐτῷ τῇ δυνάμει θερμὸν εἶναι, τὸ ταχέως μεταβάλλειν εἰς τὸ ἐνεργείᾳ θερμόν. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον κᾀπὶ τῶν ἡμετέρων σωμάτων, οὐκ εἰ παχυμερὲς, ἢ λεπτομερὲς, ἢ ὑγρὸν, ἢ κοῦφον, ἢ γλίσχρον, ἢ ὠχρὸν, ἀλλ’ εἰ θερμαίνει προσαγόμενον. οὕτω δ’ οὐδ’ εἰ γλυκὺ, καὶ κοιλίαν ὑπάγον, ἢ εὔρουν ἐργαζόμενον ἐν ταῖς φλεβοτομίαις, εἰ ἐπισταχθείη τὸ αἷμα. καὶ γὰρ καὶ ταῦτα περιττὰ, παρόν γε σκοπεῖν, εἰ θερμαίνει προσαγόμενον. εἰ μὲν οὖν ἐπισήμως τε καὶ ἰσχυρῶς ἐποίει τοῦτο, καθάπερ τὸ πέπερι, πρόδηλον ἂν ἦν πᾶσι καὶ ἀναμφισβήτητον· ἐπεὶ δ’ οὐκ ἰσχυρῶς, εὐλόγως εἰς ζήτησιν ἀφικνεῖται. πολὺ δὲ μᾶλλον ἐπὶ ῥοδίνου τε καὶ ὄξους ἠπόρηται, καὶ ἠμφισβήτηται τοῖς ἰατροῖς, εἴτε δυνάμει θερμὰ πέφυκεν, εἴτε ψυχρά. χρὴ τοίνυν ἐξευρεῖν τινας ἐφ’ ἅπασι τοῖς δυνάμει λεγομένοις ὑπάρχειν ἢ θερμοῖς, ἢ ψυχροῖς, ἢ ξηροῖς, ἢ ὑγροῖς, ἀκριβεῖς καὶ σαφεῖς διορισμοὺς, ὡς ἔμπροσθεν ἐπὶ τῶν ἐνεργείᾳ λεγομένων ἐποιησάμεθα. προσήκει δ’, οἶμαι, τὴν ἀρχὴν ἀπὸ τῶν ἐναργεστάτων ποιήσασθαι· γυμνασάμενος γάρ τις ἐν τούτοις, ῥᾷον ἀκολουθήσει τοῖς ἀσαφεστέροις. εὐθὺς οὖν ἐν τῷ προσφέρειν τῷ σώματι τόδε τι τὸ φάρμακον ἢ σιτίον, ἀπηλλάχθω τὸ προσαγόμενον ἁπάσης σφοδρᾶς ἐπικτήτου θερμότητός τε καὶ ψύξεως. ὃν μὲν γὰρ ἐν τοῖς ἔμπροσθεν ἐποιησάμεθα διορισμὸν, ἡνίκα τά θ’ ὑγρὰ καὶ τὰ ξηρὰ σώματα διαγινώσκειν ἐπεχειροῦμεν, οὗτος οὐδὲν ἂν ἧττον εἴη καὶ νῦν χρήσιμος ἐπὶ τῶν δυνάμει θερμῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν. εἴτε γὰρ δυνάμει ψυχρὸν ὂν τὸ προσφερόμενον ἐκθερμήναις σαφῶς, εἴτε θερμὸν καταψύξαις, ἡ πρώτη τοῦ σώματος προσβολὴ τὴν αἴσθησιν ἀπὸ τῆς ἐπικτήτου διαθέσεως, οὐκ ἀπὸ τῆς οἰκείας τοῦ προσαχθέντος ἐργάσεται κράσεως.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
It has now become clear that a precise judgment of things that are, in relation to us, moist or dry, cold or hot, would be made not from anything external, but from what we ourselves experience; and that first and foremost one should examine this [i.e., the effect on us], and only thereafter, if need be, the external [signs]. For if the activity of a drug that has been applied is vivid and plain to sense, one should trust that, disregarding all other marks; but if it is faint, unclear, mixed, or in any way open to dispute, then one should also judge it by all external criteria. Yet even in regard to those [external criteria], not from a distance, but from the very substance of the thing sought—for example, if oil is hot, not because it is viscous, or pale, or light, but because it is easily set aflame; for its being hot in power [dynamis] consists in this: that it quickly passes over into being hot in actuality [energeia].

In the same way with our bodies: not whether it is thick-grained or fine-grained, moist, light, viscous, or pale, but whether, when applied, it warms. Likewise, not whether it is sweet, or loosens the belly, or makes the flow in venesection smooth when the blood is allowed to drip; for these too are superfluous to consider, so long as the question is whether, when applied, it warms. If, then, it were to do this conspicuously and strongly, as pepper does, the matter would be evident and indisputable to all. But since it does not do so strongly, it reasonably becomes a subject of inquiry. And much more has there been puzzlement and dispute among physicians concerning rose-oil and vinegar, whether by nature they are hot in power or cold.

We must therefore discover precise and clear definitions applicable to all things said to be hot, cold, dry, or moist in power, just as we previously established for those said to be such in actuality. It is fitting, I think, to take our start from the most evident cases; for once someone has trained himself on these, he will more easily follow the less clear ones. Immediately, then, when applying a certain drug or food to the body, let what is applied be free of any intense adventitious heat or cold. For the criterion we established earlier, when we attempted to distinguish moist and dry bodies, will be no less useful now for things hot and cold in power. For whether, the thing applied being cold in power, you have plainly warmed it up, or, being hot, you have chilled it down, the body’s first contact will produce its sensation from the adventitious condition, not from the native mixture [krasis] of what has been applied.
paragraphs.claude_translation: It has now become clear, then, that the judgment of things as moist or dry or cold or hot in relation to us would be made accurately not from some external source, but from what we ourselves experience, and that one should examine this criterion first and foremost, and subsequently, if there should be need, also the external one. For if the action of an applied drug is evident and clear to perception, one must trust this, disregarding all other signs; but if it is faint and unclear, or mixed, or possessing some ambiguity whatsoever, then one must also judge it in relation to all external factors. Therefore, one should not judge even in relation to these factors from a distance, but from the very substance of the thing being investigated—for example, whether oil is hot, not because it is viscous or pale or light, but whether it readily bursts into flame; for this was what it meant to be hot in potentiality: to change quickly into what is hot in actuality. In the same manner also with our bodies, one should judge not whether something is thick-parted or fine-parted or moist or light or viscous or pale, but whether it heats when applied. Similarly, one should not judge by whether it is sweet and loosens the bowels, or produces good flow in bloodlettings if blood is dripped upon it. For these too are superfluous, when it is possible to examine whether it heats when applied. If, then, it did this noticeably and strongly, like pepper, it would be obvious to all and indisputable; but since it does not do so strongly, it reasonably becomes a matter of investigation. Much more so has there been perplexity and dispute among physicians concerning rose oil and vinegar, whether they are hot or cold by nature in potentiality. It is necessary, therefore, to discover certain precise and clear distinctions that apply to all things said to be hot or cold or dry or moist in potentiality, just as we made previously for things said to be so in actuality. It is appropriate, I think, to make a beginning from the most evident cases; for someone trained in these will more easily follow the more obscure ones. Immediately, then, when applying this particular drug or food to the body, let the thing being applied be free from all intense acquired heat and cold. For the distinction we made previously, when we attempted to distinguish moist and dry bodies, would be no less useful now also for things hot and cold in potentiality. For whether you clearly heat something that is cold in potentiality when applied, or cool something hot, the first contact with the body will produce the sensation from the acquired condition, not from the proper mixture [temperament] of the thing applied.
paragraphs.gemini_translation: ERROR: Text too long and cannot be split further

paragraphs.content: ἵν’ οὖν ἀκριβής τε καὶ εἰλικρινὴς ἡ φύσις ἐξετάζηται τοῦ προσαγομένου, χλιαρὸν ὡς οἷόν τε μάλιστα ὑπαρχέτω, μηδεμίαν ἐπίσημον ἔξωθεν ἀλλοίωσιν εἰληφὸς ἤτοι θερμότητος ἢ ψύξεως σφοδρᾶς. ἡ μὲν δὴ πρώτη παρασκευὴ τοῦ προσαγομένου φαρμάκου τοιαύτη γιγνέσθω. προσφερέσθω δὲ μὴ πάσῃ διαθέσει σώματος, ὅταν ἐξετάζῃς αὐτοῦ τὴν δύναμιν, ἀλλ’ ἁπλουστάταις ὡς ἔνι μάλιστα καὶ ἄκραις. εἰ μὲν οὖν ἐσχάτως θερμῇ διαθέσει προσαχθὲν αἴσθησιν ἐργάζοιτο ψύξεως, εἴη ἂν οὕτως γε ψυχρόν. ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ εἰ τῇ ψυχρᾷ θερμὸν ἐν τῷ παραυτίκα φαίνοιτο, καὶ τοῦτ’ ἂν εἴη θερμόν. εἰ δ’ ἤτοι τῇ θερμῇ θερμὸν, ἢ τῇ ψυχρᾷ ψυχρὸν φαίνοιτο, μὴ πάντως ἀποφαίνεσθαι τὸ μὲν θερμὸν, τὸ δὲ ψυχρόν. ἐνίοτε γὰρ ἄκρως μέν ἐστιν ἡ διάθεσις θερμὴ, μετρίως δὲ ψυχρὸν ὑπάρχει τὸ φάρμακον, οὔτ’ ἠλλοίωσεν αὐτὴν, ἔτι τε πρὸς τούτῳ ψύξαν καὶ πυκνῶσαν ἅπασαν τὴν ἐκτὸς ἐπιφάνειαν, ἀπέκλεισεν εἴσω καὶ διαπνεῖσθαι τὸ θερμὸν ἐκώλυσε, κᾀκ τούτου μειζόνως ἐξεπύρωσε τὴν διάθεσιν. οὕτω δὲ, κᾂν εἰ τῇ ψυχρᾷ διαθέσει τὸ προσφερόμενον μηδεμίαν ἐπιφέροι θερμότητα, σκέπτεσθαι, μή τι μετρίως ὑπάρχον θερμὸν οὐδὲν ἔδρασεν εἰς τὴν ἄκρου θερμοῦ δεομένην διάθεσιν. οὐκοῦν οὔθ’ οὕτω χρὴ βασανίζεσθαι τῶν προσφερομένων φαρμάκων τὰς δυνάμεις, οὔτ’ εἰ κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς ἐργάζοιτό τι καὶ μὴ καθ’ αὑτό. κρίσις δὲ τοῦ κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς ἥ τε διάθεσις καὶ ὁ χρόνος. ἡ μὲν διάθεσις, εἰ ἁπλῆ καὶ μία· τῷ χρόνῳ δ’ ἡ κρίσις διορίζεται κατὰ τάδε. τὸ μὲν ἅμα τῷ προσενεχθῆναι ψύχειν ἢ θερμαίνειν ἐναργῶς φαινόμενον εἴη ἂν δήπου καὶ καθ’ ἑαυτό γε καὶ δι’ ἑαυτὸ τοιοῦτο· τὸ δ’ ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ, τάχ’ ἂν ἔκ τινος συμβεβηκότος εἰς τοῦτ’ ἄγοιτο, καθάπερ ἐπὶ τετάνου, θέρεος μέσου, νέῳ εὐσάρκῳ, ὕδατος ψυχροῦ πολλοῦ κατάχυσις θέρμης ἐπανάκλησιν ποιεῖται.
paragraphs.claude_translation: So then, in order that the nature of what is being applied may be examined accurately and purely, let it be as lukewarm as possible, having received no notable alteration from outside, either of heat or of severe cold. Let this, then, be the first preparation of the drug being applied. But let it not be applied to every condition of the body when you are examining its power, but to the simplest and most extreme conditions as much as possible. If therefore, when applied to an extremely hot condition, it should produce a sensation of cooling, it would thus be cold. Similarly also if to a cold condition it should appear hot immediately, this too would be hot. But if it should appear hot to a hot condition, or cold to a cold condition, do not declare absolutely that the one is hot and the other cold. For sometimes the condition is extremely hot, but the drug is moderately cold, and it has neither altered it, and moreover, having cooled and condensed the entire external surface, it has shut the heat inside and prevented it from being breathed out, and from this has inflamed the condition more greatly. Thus also, even if what is applied to a cold condition brings no heat, one must consider whether something that is moderately hot has done nothing to a condition requiring extreme heat. Therefore the powers of drugs being applied must not be tested in this way, nor if they should produce some effect accidentally and not in themselves. The criterion of what is accidental is both the condition and the time. The condition, if it is simple and single; and the judgment is determined by time in the following ways. What appears clearly to cool or heat immediately upon being applied would surely be such both in itself and through itself; but what does so over time might perhaps be brought to this from some accident, just as in the case of tetanus [spasm], in midsummer, on a young well-fleshed person, the pouring of much cold water produces a return of heat.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So that the nature of the thing applied may be examined accurately and without admixture, let it be as nearly as possible lukewarm, having received no marked external alteration, whether of heat or of intense cold. Such, then, should be the first preparation of the medicament to be applied. And when you test its power, let it not be applied to every bodily condition, but to those that are as simple as possible and extreme [diathesis: bodily state/disposition]. If, then, when applied to an extremely hot condition it produces a sensation of cooling, it would in that case be cold. Likewise, if to a cold condition it should appear at once to be warming, this too would be warm. But if it appears warm to a warm condition, or cold to a cold one, do not by any means at once declare the one warm and the other cold. For sometimes the condition is exceedingly hot, while the drug is moderately cold; it has not altered that condition, and moreover, by cooling and compacting the whole outer surface, it shut things in and prevented the heat from breathing out, and for this reason it inflamed the condition even more. In the same way, even if the application brings no heat to a cold condition, you must consider
paragraphs.gemini_translation: Therefore, so that the nature of the substance being administered may be examined with accuracy and purity, let it be as lukewarm as possible, having undergone

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅτι γε μὴ καθ’ ἑαυτὸ θερμαίνει τὸ ψυχρὸν ὕδωρ, δῆλον ἐκ τῆς πρώτης προσβολῆς· αἴσθησιν γὰρ ἐργάζεται ψύξεως, καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ψύχει τὸ δέρμα, μέχρις ἂν ἐπιχέηται τούτῳ, καὶ τὴν θερμασίαν οὔτ’ ἐπὶ πάντων σωμάτων. οὔτ’ ἐν τῷ καταχεῖσθαι παρέχεται, ἀλλ’ ἐπὶ μόνων εὐσάρκων νέων, ἐν θέρει μέσῳ, μετὰ τὸ παύσασθαι καταχέοντας ὥσπερ οὖν οἷς προσπίπτει τὸ ψυχρὸν ὕδωρ, ἐκ τοῦ παραχρῆμα ψύχει ταῦτα, κᾂν ἔμψυχα, κᾂν ἄψυχα σώματα ὑπάρχῃ, κᾂν θερμὰ, κᾂν ψυχρὰ, κατὰ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον, εἴ τις ἦν χρόνος, ἢ φύσις σώματος, ἢ διάθεσις, ἐφ’ ἧς αἴσθησιν ἔφερε τὸ ψυχρὸν ὕδωρ εὐθὺς ἅμα τῷ προσπίπτειν θερμότητος, εὐλόγως ἂν ἐζητεῖτο, πότερον θερμαίνειν ἢ ψύχειν πέφυκε καθ’ ἑαυτό. νυνὶ δ’ ἐπειδὴ τὰ μὲν ἔμψυχά τε καὶ ἄψυχα πάντα παραχρῆμα καὶ διὰ παντὸς ὁρᾶται ψυχόμενα, οἷς δ’ ἐστὶν ἔμφυτος θερμασία καὶ οἷον πηγή τις ἐν τοῖς σπλάγχνοις πυρὸς, εἰ τούτοις προσενεχθείη, ἐπανάκλησίν τινά ποτε ποιεῖται θερμότητος, εὔλογον οἶμαι, κατά τι συμβεβηκὸς, οὐ καθ’ ἑαυτὸ θερμαίνειν αὐτὸ τὰ τοιαῦτα. καὶ δὴ καὶ φαίνεται, κατὰ τί. πυκνώσει γὰρ τῆς ἐκτὸς ἐπιφανείας καὶ κατακλήσει τοῦ θερμοῦ τὴν ἐπάνοδον ποιεῖται τῆς ἐκ τοῦ βάθους θερμασίας, ἅμα μὲν ἀθροισθείσης τῷ μὴ διαπνεῖσθαι, ἅμα δ’ εἰς τὸ βάθος ἀποχωρούσης διὰ τὴν τοῦ περιέχοντος βίαν ψυχροῦ, ἅμα δὲ καὶ τρεφομένης ὑπὸ τῶν ἐνταῦθα χυμῶν. ὅταν γὰρ ἀθροισθεῖσά τε καὶ τραφεῖσα πρὸς τὴν ἐπιφάνειαν ὁρμήσῃ σφοδρότερον, ἐπανάκλησις μὲν γίνεται τῆς θέρμης, ἔνδειξις δὲ τοῦ μὴ καθ’ ἑαυτὸ τὴν θερμασίαν αὐξῆσαι τὸ ψυχρὸν ὕδωρ. καθ’ ἑαυτὸ μὲν γὰρ ἔψυξε τὸ δέρμα· τῇ ψύξει δ’ αὐτοῦ πύκνωσίς τε ἅμα καὶ εἰς τὸ βάθος ὑπονόστησις ἠκολούθησε τοῦ θερμοῦ· τούτων δ’ αὐτῶν τῇ μὲν πυκνώσει κώλυσις τῆς διαπνοῆς, τῇ δ’ εἰς τὸ βάθος ὑποχωρήσει κατεργασία τῶν ταύτῃ χυμῶν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But that cold water does not heat by its own nature is clear from the first contact: for it produces a sensation of coldness, and indeed it cools the skin as long as it is being poured upon it, and it does not provide warmth either on all bodies or during the pouring, but only on well-fleshed young people, in midsummer, after one has stopped pouring. Therefore, just as cold water, upon whatever it falls, immediately cools these things, whether they are animate or inanimate bodies, whether hot or cold, in the same manner—if there were any time, or nature of body, or condition, in which cold water produced a sensation of heat immediately upon contact, it would reasonably be investigated whether it is naturally disposed to heat or to cool by its own nature. But as it is now, since all things, both animate and inanimate, are observed to be cooled immediately and continuously, while those things which have innate heat and a sort of source of fire in the internal organs [splanchna], if cold water is applied to them, it sometimes produces a certain rebound of heat—it is reasonable, I think, that it heats such things accidentally, not by its own nature. And indeed it is apparent in what way. For by condensing the outer surface and shutting in the heat, it produces the return of the warmth from the depths, which is at once concentrated by not being dispersed through evaporation, at once retreating into the depths because of the force of the surrounding cold, and at once being nourished by the humors [chymoi] there. For when, having been concentrated and nourished, it rushes more vigorously toward the surface, there occurs a rebound of heat, and this is proof that cold water does not increase the warmth by its own nature. For by its own nature it cooled the skin; but from this cooling there followed simultaneously both condensation and retreat of the heat into the depths; and from these very things, from the condensation came prevention of evaporation, and from the retreat into the depths came the working upon of the humors there.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But that cold water does not heat of itself is clear from the first contact; for it produces a sensation of cooling, and indeed it cools the skin so long as it is poured upon it, nor does it afford any warming either in the case of all bodies or while it is being poured, but only in well-fleshed youths, in the

paragraphs.content: ὧν ἡ μὲν κώλυσις τῆς διαπνοῆς τὴν ἄθροισιν τῆς θερμασίας, ἡ δὲ τῶν χυμῶν κατεργασία τὴν γένεσιν αὐτῇς ἐποιήσατο. τούτων δ’ ἑκατέρῳ πάλιν ἡ αὔξησις ἕπεται τῆς ἐμφύτου θερμασίας. διὰ μέσων οὖν ἑκατέρων τὸ μὲν ψυχρὸν αὔξησίν ποτε τῆς ἐν τῷ ζώῳ θερμασίας ἐργάζεται, καθ’ ἑαυτὸ δ’ οὐδέποτε. καὶ μὴν καὶ τὸ θερμὸν ἔστιν ὅτε κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς ψύχει διὰ μέσου τοῦ κενοῦ, ὡς τὸ κατάντλημα τὴν φλεγμονήν. ἐπειδὴ γὰρ ὑπὸ θερμοῦ ῥεύματος γίνεται φλεγμονὴ, τὸ μὲν ἴδιον αὐτῆς ἴαμα κένωσίς ἐστι τοῦ περιττοῦ, τὸ δὲ τῇ κενώσει πάντως ἑπόμενον ἡ ψύξις τοῦ διὰ τὴν φλεγμονὴν τεθερμασμένου μορίου. διττῆς μὲν οὖν οὔσης ἐν τοῖς φλεγμαίνουσι σώμασι διαθέσεως, ὅσον μὲν ἐπὶ τῇ πλεονεξίᾳ τοῦ περιττοῦ, κατὰ τὸ ποσὸν ἐξισταμένοις τοῦ κατὰ φύσιν, ὅσον δ’ ἐπὶ τῇ θερμασίᾳ, κατὰ τὸ ποιὸν, ἡ τῆς ἑτέρας τῶν διαθέσεων ἴασις ἑπομένην ἔχει καὶ τὴν ἑτέραν. καὶ γίνεται κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς τὰ κενωτικὰ τῆς θερμῆς ὕλης φάρμακα καὶ τῆς φλογώσεως τῶν μορίων ἐμψυκτικά. ταῦτά τε οὖν διορίζεσθαι, καὶ πειρᾶσθαι κατὰ τὸ ποσὸν τῆς ἁπλῆς διαθέσεως ἐξευρίσκειν τὸ ποσὸν τῆς τοῦ φαρμάκου δυνάμεως· οἷον εἰ ἄκρως ᾖ ἡ διάθεσις θερμὴ, καὶ τὸ φάρμακον ἄκρως εἶναι ψυχρόν· εἰ δ’ ὀλίγον ἀπολίποιτο τῆς ἀκρότητος ἡ διάθεσις, ὀλίγον χρῆναι καὶ τὸ φάρμακον ἀπολείπεσθαι· κᾂν εἰ πλέον ἀπέχοιτο τῆς ἄκρας θερμασίας ἡ διάθεσις, ἀνάλογον ἀπέχειν τῆς ἄκρας ψυχρότητος τὸ φάρμακον. εἰ γὰρ ἀπὸ τοῦ τοιούτου στοχασμοῦ τὴν ἀρχὴν τῆς ἐξετάσεως αὐτῶν ποιοῖο, θᾶττον ἂν ἐξευρίσκοις τὴν οἰκείαν ἑκάστου δύναμιν. ὅλως γὰρ, εἰ καθ’ ἓν ὁτιοῦν πάθος ἁπλοῦν θερμὸν ὅ τι δήποτε τῶν φαρμάκων προσαχθὲν εὐθὺς ἅμα τῇ πρώτῃ προσφορᾷ ψύξεως αἴσθησιν ἤνεγκε, ψυχρόν ἐστιν ἐκεῖνο τῇ δυνάμει, καὶ πολὺ μᾶλλον, εἰ καὶ μετὰ τὴν πρώτην προσφορὰν ἕως παντὸς μένει τοιοῦτο. εἰ δὲ καὶ παντελῶς ἰῷτο τὴν θερμὴν διάθεσιν, ἐξ ἀνάγκης ψυχρόν ἐστι. προσφέρεσθαι δὲ χρὴ πάντως αὐτὸ χλιαρὸν, ἐπειδὰν δοκιμάζηται, καθότι καὶ πρόσθεν εἴρηται. γνωρισθὲν δ’, ὅτι τοιοῦτό ἐστιν, εἶτα θεραπείας ἕνεκα παραλαμβανόμενον, ἄμεινον ψυχρὸν λαμβάνειν, πλὴν εἰ τὸ μὲν φάρμακον ἄκρως εἴη ψυχρὸν, οὐκ ἄκρως δὲ θερμὸν εἴη τὸ νόσημα. ταῦτα μὲν οὖν ἐπὶ πλέον ἔν τε τοῖς περὶ φαρμάκων εἰρήσεται κᾀν τοῖς τῆς θεραπευτικῆς μεθόδου γράμμασιν. ἐν δὲ τῷ παρόντι τό γε τοσοῦτον χρὴ γινώσκειν, ὡς, εἴ τι τῇ θερμῇ καὶ ἁπλῇ διαθέσει προσαχθὲν φάρμακον ἐκ τοῦ παραχρῆμα κᾀν τῷ μετὰ ταῦτα χρόνῳ παντὶ τήν τε τῆς ψύξεως αἴσθησιν ἤνεγκε τῷ κάμνοντι καὶ τὴν τῆς εὐφορίας τε καὶ ὠφελείας, ἐξ ἀνάγκης τοῦτο ψυχρόν ἐστι, κᾂν ἐπ’ ἄλλων ποτὲ φαίνηται θερμόν εὑρεθήσεται γὰρ ἐπ’ ἐκείνων ἐξεταζόμενον ἀκριβῶς οὐ καθ’ ἑαυτὸ θερμαῖνον, ἀλλὰ κατά τι συμβεβηκός.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Of these factors, the prevention of transpiration produced the accumulation of heat, while the concoction of humors produced its generation. And in turn, the increase of innate heat follows upon each of these. Therefore, through the mediation of each of these processes, cold sometimes produces an increase of heat in the living creature, but never by itself. Moreover, heat sometimes cools accidentally through the mediation of evacuation, as a cold compress [cools] inflammation. For since inflammation occurs from a hot flux, its proper remedy is evacuation of the excess matter, and what invariably follows upon evacuation is the cooling of the part that has been heated by the inflammation. Since there is a twofold condition in inflamed bodies—insofar as concerns the excess of superfluous matter, they depart from the natural state in quantity, and insofar as concerns the heat, in quality—the cure of one of these conditions brings with it the cure of the other as well. And it happens accidentally that drugs which evacuate hot matter also cool the inflammation of the parts. These distinctions must be made, and one must try to discover the degree of the drug's power in accordance with the degree of the simple condition; for example, if the condition is extremely hot, the drug too should be extremely cold; but if the condition falls slightly short of the extreme, the drug too should fall short by a small amount; and if the condition is further removed from extreme heat, the drug should be proportionally removed from extreme coldness. For if you make the beginning of your examination of them from such an estimation, you would more quickly discover the proper power of each. For in general, if in the case of any simple hot affection whatsoever, any drug applied immediately upon first application produces a sensation of cooling, that drug is cold in power, and much more so if it remains such even after the first application and continuously thereafter. But if it also completely cures the hot condition, it is necessarily cold. And it must always be applied lukewarm when it is being tested, as was also said before. Once it has been recognized to be of such a nature, then when it is employed for the sake of treatment, it is better to take it cold, unless the drug is extremely cold but the disease is not extremely hot. These matters, then, will be discussed more fully both in the works on drugs and in the writings on the therapeutic method. But in the present context one must know at least this much: that if any drug applied to a hot and simple condition produces in the patient both the sensation of cooling and [a feeling] of comfort and benefit immediately and in all the time thereafter, this drug is necessarily cold, even if it sometimes appears to be hot in other cases; for it will be found upon careful examination in those cases to be heating not by itself but in some accidental way.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
Of these, the obstruction of transpiration produced the accumulation of heat, while the concoction of the humors brought about its generation. And in each case again an increase of the innate heat follows. Therefore, through the mediation of each, the cold at times brings about an increase of the animal’s internal heat, though never by itself. Indeed, the hot too sometimes cools incidentally, through the intermediary of evacuation, as depletion [katántlēma: draining/derivation] does for inflammation. For since inflammation arises from a hot flux, its proper remedy is the emptying of the superfluity, and what necessarily follows upon the evacuation is the cooling of the part that has been heated on account of the inflammation. Accordingly, since there is a twofold condition in bodies that are inflamed—so far as there is an excess of superfluous matter they deviate from what is according to nature in respect of quantity, and so far as there is heating they deviate in respect of quality—the cure of the one condition carries along with it the other as well. Thus purgatives of hot matter become incidentally cooling remedies for the inflamed parts and allay their inflammation.

We must both distinguish these points and try to discover, in proportion to the degree of the simple condition, the degree of the drug’s power; for example, if the condition is in the extreme hot, the drug too must be in the extreme cold; if the condition falls a little short of the extreme, the drug should also fall a little short; and if the condition stands further from the utmost heat, the drug should be proportionately removed from the utmost cold. For if you were to make the beginning of your inquiry from such an estimate, you would more quickly discover the proper power of each drug. In general, if, whenever any one simple affection is hot, whatever drug is applied immediately at the first application brings a perception of cooling, that drug is cooling in power—and much more so if, even after the first application, it continues to be such for the whole subsequent time; and if it even completely cures the hot condition, it must of necessity be cold.

It must, however, always be administered tepid when it is being tested, as has been said before. Once it has been recognized to be of such a sort, then when it is employed for treatment it is better to administer it cold, unless the drug is extremely cold while the disease is not extremely hot. These matters will be discussed more fully in the works on drugs and in the writings on the method of healing. For the present one should at least know this much: if some drug applied to a hot and simple condition immediately and throughout the whole subsequent time brings to the patient both a perception of cooling and a sense of comfort and benefit, that drug is necessarily cold—even if it may at times appear hot in other cases; for upon exact examination in those cases it will be found not to heat in itself, but incidentally.
